description:
Came here with a bunch of college friends and had a great time.  We made a resi and were able to get our own room for everyone.  It's AYCE with a wide array of options, even non hot pot items like fries and buns, and even lots to choose from when making your DIY sauce. 

Nothing on the menu particularly stood out, but everything was great.   Our server was really attentive and came by frequently to check on us.  AYCE and AYCD + tip and tax came out to $50/pp.  Although there is a time limit, it wasn't too strongly enforced...maybe because it was close to closing and a slower night.  

Overall a fantastic experience.  I give it 4.5 stars...after I visit again I may round up
author: Lyn C.

description:
This place is averagely good for hotpot but the taste doesn't stand out. It's buffet so you can try everything for your hotpot. Except beef or lamb, everything comes with smaller size so you don't need to worry about not being able to finish. 

Can't be picky on service. Also the parking is easy. There are a bunch of street parking spots across the street.
author: Jin F.

description:
Lots of hidden charges. 
Told us there was a discount when we sat down and when the receipt came they told us it only applies for non AYCE. Service kind of slow, and forgot our orders a few times.

Drink prices are 3.50, even if they're not on the menu. Split pot is extra charge as well.
author: Peter W.

description: Tonight it was busy, we have to wait for a table. But the foods was good. Even though only two servers but still nice services.  Foods came fast and very fresh for everything. Definitely will return back! Nice Hot Pot place.
author: Chloe D.

description: I took my fam bam here on Saturday and we loved it! My favorite thing was probably the sauce bar. It's so nice being able to just mix whatever you want and not having to ask repeatedly for staff to bring you sauce, which is generally my experience at other hot pot places. We made a reservation for 4 on a Saturday night at 7 but wound up coming an hour early and were seated right away. We had the miso broth for my hubby and me and my parents shared the clear broth. Meat wise we loved the beef tongue and Kobe beef. Totally overate but that's what happens when it's all you can eat!
author: Jennie C.

description:
This place is one of the more better tasting hot pots in the city. From what I hear, it has gotten renovated. Despite the renovation, I still feel like it's lagging behind in the "hot pot industry." Sure you got your sauce bar, but let's face it, everybody wants their own pot nowadays. This place still does the pot for sharing and irritatingly charges an extra $1 per person for doing a split pot or getting more than one broth. 

The one main thing that irked me about this place was having one of the workers tell me how to hot pot. I AIN'T A NOVICE. I got in "trouble" for putting too much spinach in my pot. Like seriously? Spinach wilts and significantly downsizes when cooked. They also turned down the heat at our table as if I weren't capable of gauging the boiling mechanism of the pot. 

Anyway, here's a run down of the place:
- TRY THE HOT POT SALTED EGG (it's house made!)
- no individual pots, extra $1 per person if split pot
- large portions, large selection of food
- DIY sauce bar
author: Christene M.

description:
The Pot located way out on 32nd street and Judah in the outer Sunset is the best AYCE hot pot joint in San Francisco. The menu is full of fresh hot pot ingredients. All of the the fish, shrimp, meats and vegetables were fresh and vibrant. The variety of the meats and choices of soup bases make The Pot a hugely popular place. We made reservations a week in advance and the lines were constantly stretching out the door. Our party of six were seated at a long table with two pots so we were able to choose 4 soup bases. Several TV's around the restaurant were tuned to the Warriors game and others to Chinese programming.  Besides the AYCE there us a $13 all you can drink option. 

Service was good even with the full house. Street parking only and could be a problem especially with the road construction going on. The one minor knock (could be designed and planned) is the uncomfortable chairs and benches. It could be the best way to keep the customers to the 90 minute time limit.
author: George F.

description:
Don't come here. I don't know if we just came too late in the night but whatever the case was, everything was so gross. We ordered the top 3 broths (kimchi, & the other two spicy ones) but it was not good. 

It was very salty and extremely harsh to take down. It was made out of 90% oil/grease 10% broth. I'm not sure if it was because it was closer to closing time and they served us the end of the pot or not. 

It was very expensive and we didn't even get our moneys worth. I'm adding a star because the service was great, along with their side dishes. 

This place could be better but please limit the amount of oils and salt you put in your broths. It's even scary to look at!
author: Jocey H.

description:
Went on a rainy Wednesday night, which is perfect hot pot weather.  We walked in and was immediately seated. The server gave us the ordering sheet and left us to select our broths and food. We picked the intestine soup, sour fish soup and the pork bone soup. All were tasty in different ways. The intestines soup was super peppery, a little over powering on it's own. As we cooked the meats and seafood in it, it was fine. The pork bone soup was a little bland in the beginning, but was great after cooking all the meats in it. The American Kobe was well marbled, better than most other Chinese hot pot places. The selection was vast and we only tried 30% of the menu. The lamb was melt in your mouth good. Don't forget to get some of the homemade dumplings. They were very good. 

Overall a good value for the quality you get.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
One of the more delicious AYCE hot pot areas in the city, the place can have rather slow service when it's busy, so service isn't quite the best, especially for ~$30/person, but I've seen worst.

This review is mostly for the food though, and not for the service. They provide a checklist of items for you to order, and then they slowly bring the food out. You can make various dipping sauces at the side bar, and bring them back to the table.

Of the soup bases, I liked the tomato and pumpkin the most, closely followed by the creamy pork bone, though I haven't tried all of them. The beef is excellent, as well as the fish balls with roe on the inside.

Overall a fun place to eat, but beware that the service can be slow when they are busy. We had to wait quite a while for the beef to come out the second time we came here.
author: Tyler T.

description:
When reviewing a restaurant, I usually try to enumerate every dish I tried and write a few lines about each.  That ain't happening here!  This amazing gem in the Avenues is essentially all-you-can-eat hot pot with a HUGE list of add-ins to order from.  They mention a 90-minute time limit, but they didn't seem to enforce it on a slow weeknight.  They also offer unlimited beer/sake, but I opted for the unlimited soda since I wasn't looking to rage during hot pot.  Order a lot in your first go since they seem a little hit-or-miss with taking subsequent orders; though they were always fast to give use more beef slices in particular.

My favorite meats were the thinly sliced beef and thinly slice lamb.  Quick cooking, great texture and great taste.  I ordered the marinated lamb too; the portion was large but the cut didn't seem as good as the un-marinated version.  Thanks to an introduction by regulars, I really got to love the shrimp paste.  It's basically ground shrimp (and maybe a little other fish for binding?) that you scoop into balls in the soup; tastes like an amazing shrimp dumpling without all the pesky dough wrapping.  Wasn't a fan of the regular shrimp because they came with full head and shell, causing a lot of wasted time unpeeling before you get a bite of two of the good stuff.  The various fish balls were kinda bleh and the "lobster" ball tasted nothing like lobster.

Also of note, I really like the fried tofu and fried tofu skin.  Both did an amazing job of soaking up the spicy broth and giving you quite a zing (compared to how the spices don't really stick tot he meat).  The fried tofu was nice and spongy.  The fried tofu skin starts off crispy but a few seconds in the broth turns into something silky and delicious.

The egg yolk dumpling is also notable.  Tastes like an egg custard tart inside of a light dumpling skins; gets that fun lava texture after a little time in the soup.  

Tons of veggies and noodles too.  They're pretty much as expected, so it's really a matter of what your personal taste is.  We saved the noodles for last and weren't that into them after gorging on all the meat and seafood.  So there could be a strong case for going carb-less to maximize on the good stuff.
author: Adam B.

description:
Overall rating: 3.5/5
Parking: Tough since it's on Judah
Best time to go: The closer to their opening time or on a weeknight

The first time around when I came around a year or two ago, I thought this place was mediocre at best. I'd give this place a 3.5 or 3.75 stars but rounded up. After returning this year, I noticed the new sauce bar they added! Before, their standard hot pot sauce was soy sauce which was way too salty for my liking. In my opinion, the sauce REALLY matters and can make or break my whole meal.

The amount of options you can choose from is pretty extensive. The food is pretty fresh as well. For $27.99 per person, it's all you can eat!

Soups are standard - not amazing but good enough to satisfy me. The beef seems fresh and not fatty so I enjoy it here. Came on a weeknight around 6:30pm and there's usually no wait but weekends are another story. Arrive early! Parking is tough around the area since it's on Judah and there's not much parking. I'll definitely be back since I live in the area.
author: Valerie T.

description:
Four sentences.

Food are fresh here.

Excellent customer services.

Worth every penny.

Much better than other hot pot restaurants that only focus on quantity not quality.
author: anna l.

description:
I used to think Little Sheep Mongolian Hotpot (in Union Square) was the only hot pot place in SF, until I heard about The Pot's. A friend recommended this place for AYCE hot pot, and I came with a group of 10 for a Chinese New Year dinner. 

They give you a menu, and you can check off as many ingredients + apps that you want. I honestly don't know how they profit, because there is no limit to how much you can order, or any penalty for unfinished food (like some other Asian restaurants have). The sesame balls, fried dumplings, and chinese donuts with condensed milk, and surprisingly, the curly fries, are terrific to start off with. I love the variety of veggies (recommend the bok choy, a choy, and spinach) as well as the meats. I couldn't tell a difference in quality between the lamb/beef here vs other places. My favorite are the different types of fish balls, as well as the fried tofu skins. 

Perhaps it was because we came on a busy night, but I felt like there were a few things from our menu that they had forgotten. We ordered green onion pancakes twice, and they never came out. I mean, we had such a disgusting amount of food that it didn't really matter, but some consistency would definitely be nice. 

It's $27.99/person, and $13 for all-you-can-drink sake. If you come with enough people, I'd say that it's totally worth it. I pay around the same amount for when I go to Little Sheep.

TIP: Call and make reservations! They're not difficult to get (I called the night before), but I saw people waiting 40+ minutes for a table on a Saturday night, whereas we got seated immediately.
author: Denise L.

description:
relatively decent AYCE hot pot joint. They have a lot of different options for both soups and ingredients to add to your hot pot, but overall I felt like there wasn't anything that stood out to me.

I don't know if I'd come back with all the different options in the area, but definitely something cool to try  with your friends if they are visiting the area and love hot pot!

Something very unique I saw here was the fact that you could get 3 different soups in one bowl separated into thirds!

The dessert options here are definitely really unique and awesome though! You can get some deep fried buns, churros, and more!
author: Andrew T.

description:
I came back in early June 2017, and it looks like they re-modeled the inside and some slight upgrades. At least, they are upgrades in my opinion. They redid the flooring and now there's a self-serve sauce bar which is amazing. It reminds me of iPOT on Irving, so there's a lot more options for your dipping sauces! This is definitely bonus from before.

Also, I don't know if it's because I came on a weekday but the service was amazing. They were very attentive to everything, and was quick. I was thoroughly impressed. Also, their menu items expanded too! They have more items and now they have those delicious "Chinese doughnuts" which is basically deep fried buns with condensed milk. I really like iPOT for that (I know it's crazy for liking that at a hot pot place) but they're good.

I think this place tops my list of best hot pot places in San Francisco. Each hot pot place has their pros and cons but after the upgrades to this place, it's my go to now for hot pot.
author: Margaret L.

description:
The Pot's was a lot of fun. Went with my husband, daughter and a friend.  

The interior was clean.  I believe it had been recently renovated.  We sat at a table with benches on both sides. The induction  burner was in the center of the table. 

We chose 3 soups to cook in; spicy miso, prom bone with coconut and chicken.  All three were good.  The spicy miso added a kick to those items cooked in it, even if they were only in it a few seconds.  The pork with coconut gave a sweet flavor to the items.  

Our selections included beef, lamb, pork, bok choy, napa cabbage, eggplant, beef marinated in wine, taro balls, shrimp balls, and several more.  All of them wee tasty.  I liked the beef marinated Ian wine and was surprised how much the flavor of the marinate remained after cooking. 

The all you can eat buffet was $27.99 per person.  They give a 5% discount for cash.  

The only downside is their location is way out in the avenues, so it's hard just to pop in unless you live on the area.  

I will try to go back.
author: Kim B.

description: Amazing authentic shichuan flavor hot pot!
author: Yu-Ting C.

description: Didn't realize that The Pot's was in outer Judah, because the storefront is a little unassuming. But come inside the restaurant, and the decor and interior all look newly-renovated and clean. The menu stated that parties were limited to 90 minutes. However, considering that there weren't many people in the restaurant to begin with, my friends and I didn't feel rushed at all to leave by that time frame. AYCE is normally $29, but we were able to use the back-to-school special to reduce our cost to $24/person. Overall, the food we ordered tasted fresh, save a few exceptions, such as the mussels and wood's ear mushrooms. On the up side, the broth was extremely flavorful, service was pretty responsive (constantly checking to make sure we had enough broth in our pot), and dishes came out fairly quickly. On the downside, we had to call back a waiter several times, because we had some dishes that just never came out of the kitchen (like our rice and A choy). Regardless, I really enjoyed my experience at this hot pot place. It was cheaper compared to other hot pot restaurants around, and it's a great place to chill with friends surrounded by food.
author: Connie X.

description:
Oh wow. This is probably my new favorite AYCE hot pot place in San Francisco.

A friend and I showed up around 6:30 on a Friday night, and got seated almost immediately. We seemed to beat the rush - at around 7:00 PM, the line started to get long.

The area itself is super cute. It's well light, bright, and open. It can be a little cramped if they put you in the side room but it's not a big deal at all. 

We got a pork bone broth, which was absolutely delicious. You can choose two broths for an extra dollar a person, but there were so many options that it became overwhelming. This is true of the food items as well - there are so many meats, buns, and veggies for you to choose from, which is truly a dream. The service was great - the employees were always checking in on us, and brought our food out super fast, even if they did forgot our meat once or twice. The Pots is located way out in outer sunset, so it is a bit of a venture for me, but I'll definitely be back!
author: Jessie Y.

description: This place has a bunch of variety. The meat is really good! I love the Szechuan broth and the spicy chicken broth, definitely must try!  The environment is super chill, and they two rooms available for karaoke.  They also have all you can drink beers and sake for just $13!
author: Jason W.

description:
[+] Called to make a reservation since Fiery Hot Pot was an hour wait. Was able to get a reservation for 4 adult and 1 baby right away.
[+] Newly remodel, not sure how long they have remodel since I haven't been here since they first open yearrssss ago.
[+] Sauce bar so you can make your own sauce
[+] Owner was extremely friendly. Service was pretty good.
[+] Good selection and variety.
[+] TVS to watch

[-] Even though the owner was nice. He explained to us that 4 adults would share 1 pot even though our table has 2 stoves. They said it would be extra $5 to have 2 pots for our table. We thought that was kind of ridiculous because we always hot pot at all the different hot pot restaurants and they never charge us for the pot...and 4 people sharing 1 pot on a 2 stove table? I might understand if you have only 1 stove on that table but you have 2 stove for that table and you want to charge extra $5 for using it when we have 4 adult and 1 baby? 
[-] Then they said it would also be extra $1 charge per split pot if you would like 2 soup base. 
[-] Don't like how they try to "nickle and dime" you with these extra charges. It just says All you can eat is $29.99 on the menu. It doesn't say all these extra fees. 
[-] Meat quality isn't that great
[-] Some of the items we ordered on the menu did not come. We had to ask for it again. 
[-] Grapefruit soju was $15 each when the market sells it for $4. I understand the restaurant needs to make profit, but really? Many restaurants I have gone to sells it for $10 and I think that's fair. 

Maybe they are trying extra hard to get more money from customers. I'm not sure if we will come back because of all the nickle and diming, and there are so many better locations for hot pot in San Francisco.
author: Tammy F.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite Hot Pot places in the city! Was pleasantly surprised to find no line at 6:30 on a Friday but I'll take it. 

My favorite parts of The Pots
- The broth was so flavorful! I didn't really even feel the need to use much sauce because it was so well seasoned
- Serving sizes are more reasonable for smaller groups so you  can get a large variety of food

Variety of food and quality of meat was fairly standard for hot pot. Nothing that blows your mind but nothing that will ruin the experience for you! I'll definitely be back
author: Cassie Z.

description:
I can't believe it took me this long to give this place a try. This AYCE hot pot restaurant is everything that I've been looking for. The restaurant is very modern, clean, and the servers are extremely kind, attentive, and helpful. I came here with a friend this past Friday and from the moment we walked in, we were treated with the uttermost respect. Unfortunately I didn't get the name of our server, but she was just exceptional. She showed us to the sauce station and she was kind enough to answer all of our questions and follow through with all of our requests. 

I really felt like this place has a HUGE variety. Not only were there many broth choices to choose from, but there were food options to fit anyone's cravings. We decided to go with the sake broth and the miso broth, however we weren't too big of fans of the sake broth, as it really brought out a bitter flavor. We ended up just using the miso broth side for all of our cooking. 

For meats we ordered the lamb slices, the beef tongue, beef slices in wine, and beef tripe. All the meats were thinly slices & very fresh. 

For the veggies we had the baby corn, spinach, enoki mushrooms, deep fried tofu, and seaweed. 

A bonus is that this place has homemade dumplings which are quite delicious. We tried a really big variety and they were all super tasty. Another one of my favorite items was the crispy tofu skin. This was something very different than I was used to tasting, but it turned out to be amazing, especially when dipped with some ponzu sauce. 

The meat portions were very generous, so it's good enough to order 4-6 plates when starting out. In addition, there are a few precooked appetizers, such as curly fries and potstickers which are very good to start with if coming here extra hungry. 

The overall experience at this restaurant was 100%. Not only did I enjoy everything that I tried, but the service was top notch. There was never a longer wait time than 5 minutes. By the time my friend and I were leaving, around 8:30pm, there was a long line of people waiting to get seated. I'm guessing that it gets busy on the weekends and during evening hours. 

If you're looking for a hot pot restaurant that's nice, clean and ready to serve their customers with the best service, this is the place to go.
author: Julia K.

description:
The Pot's is a popular ayce (all-you-can-eat) hot pot spot in the Sunset at a flat rate of ~$30. I met two other friends on a Saturday around 6pm and thankfully had no wait (it started getting busy around 7). The location was recently remodelled so nice to see new tables and induction burners. They have a separate DIY sauce section. The pot allows you to choose two soups -- I preferred the spicy soup to the pork bone broth. You order on a sheet of paper and you can have multiple rounds. Here are my thoughts on some of the food items: 

- Beef: decently marbled and not too much fat. This was my favorite protein
- Lamb: also thinly sliced but didn't have a lot of flavor.
- Spicy Fish: overly salty and a huge serving. AVOID!
- Veggies: Pretty average. I generally like Napa cabbage and mushrooms. Don't forget your greens. 
- Fish Tofu: My favorite dish ball! It is brown and rectangular. 
- Fried Sesame balls: not for your soup but it was a tasty snack
- Fried Taro: I didn't know what to do with this as it was rock hard. Soaking it in soup helped but still.... 

Overall it's an a-okay spot but nothing special. I'm ready to try more hot pot places before settling.
author: Tammy T.

description:
This place is soo out of the way, but my friend was visiting from Honolulu and had heard great things about this place. It's an all-you-can-eat hot pot buffet, where you order on a form (and you can order more later). Staff are very accommodating, patient, and friendly. At one point, we wanted to try a dish but wouldn't have been able to finish it all, so our server brought us a half portion as requested. 

The malatang broth we got ended up being way too spicy for us, so we just kept asking our server to dilute it with regular broth. The coconut broth was unique and interesting, though I wasn't the biggest fan. 

We definitely tried a fair share of the menu, and enjoyed everything. Definitely get the red bean balls for dessert! Prepare for serious food coma afterwards.
author: Annie K.

description: Portion sizes for everything is huge ranging from meat slices ( beef, lamb, and pork slices are thick and bigger than other regular hot pot restaurants offer!) Also, fish balls, meat balls, shrimp balls include cheese filling which are so unique. Pretty satisfied with the Pork Bone and Spicy Mala ( salty a bit)! Good experience when it comes to The Pots in SF! However, they need to install the fan so it wont be boiling inside! Too hot!
author: Jenny N.

description: Of all the hot pot and shabu shabu houses in the city, I was slightly underwhelmed by the Pot's. I was expecting it to be delicious because of the Yelp rating, and the authenticity of service. It fell short with me because of the broth. I wasn't a fan of the miso broth that we ordered, and this led to everything else falling short too. It was unfortunate. If you go for the first time, I might recommend sampling he broth before ordering if this is an option
author: Ross S.

description:
1st time at the pot's, I've read such good reviews about their tasty broth, so I had to tried them.  We've Stood outside in the cold waiting for 1 hour and 25 mins. 

We had the spicy miso and pork bone broth. I tasted both, the broths were okay not great. the major negative factor for me was that all night after the meal, my mouth felt parched and dry and throughout to the next morning.  I even got up in the middle of night to drink more water.  So back to the broth, it had so much MSG to cause that dried mouth reaction in me.  If you were wondering if drank the broth, NO! I only dipped food in to cook in broth. 

Service however was surprisingly good for such a chaotic  environment.  Kudos to the servers. 

Will I go back?  NO! Not worth the wait

(Just a comparison, 2 days afterwards I went to QPot in SJ, and didn't have the same MSG effect)
author: Agnes K.

description: Im a fan since they remodel the interior,  more bright than before. and the food is much better than before as well!! definitely a fan this time!!
author: Faye L.

description:
I had no hope of ever having good chinese food in SF. I have been shown the light. This place is absolutely delicious with incredibly high quality ingredients and delicious soup bases. It took a while to get seated but it was so worth it. All you can eat hotpot and $13 extra for all you can drink! Amazing!!!

Goodbye Little Sheep. From now on I will get off my lazy butt and travel extra for the angels caressing my taste buds at Pot's
author: Desmond C.

description: BEWARE! This place dilutes their sake. If you get all you can drink, after the 3rd round, the sake became super diluted and if it's not diluted the pourer was straight up filled with water. Be careful and do not get ripped off. Terrible practice! Do not get scammed!!!!
author: David W.

description: Meat too bad.  No taste. And not enough server.  Whatever we order always missing.  Beef doesn't taste like beaf.  After couple pieces.  I don't wanna come back again.   But handmade ball is ok.   Worth for 1 star
author: Xueying D.

description:
We came on a Friday evening around 7:30 PM after finding out Terra Cotta Warrior was closed for summer vacation. It was $27.99 + $1.00 per person for two different soup bases acye. 

Pros: The food is amazing. I haven't seen such an extensive hot pot menu before, and there are a ton of sauce options i.e. peanut sauce, fermented bean curd. This is the first hot pot place I've had where there is dim sum on the menu, and I loved the options. Definitely get the hot pot salty egg yolk bun!

Cons: When we signed up on the waitlist, the server gave us an estimate wait of 10-15 minutes. The server was dead wrong - we waited around 40 minutes before getting seated. When we did get seated and ordered our food, we realized the servers don't bring out everything you order, so we had to check with the servers often to make sure they brought everything out.

Pro tip: If you didn't get all of your food within 20 minutes of ordering, order again because the servers probably forgot to bring them out. Also, you can buy the dim sum items separately frozen; they hired a dim sum chef from Hong Kong and make them all in-house.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Remodeled and has become even better. We got both the spicy soups and it satisfied our spicy craving. Food is better than ever and with their new sauce bar, nothing will ever be bland there. Was not disappointed and they now have cooked food too! Gyoza was really good! You must try the egg custard dumpling at the end, definitely one of the reasons why I come here! You must go!
author: Darlene T.

description:
After a recent renovation, this place is so much better! New touches include a more modern design and a create your own sauce bar! 

My friends and I would go here all the time and was sad to see it was closed for quite a while for the renovation. After they reopened, we made it a point to check it out and so glad we did! 

As far as I know, the menu remained the same, but the sauce bar is a new addition. I love being able to brew up my own sauces, so that's a plus. The broths here are always flavorful and tasty, as well as the meats & sides. Also want to mention that this place is AYCE.

Service is always great here. I remember one time, we called ahead to put our name down and ended up arriving 15 minutes late. The host was understanding and was able to sit us immediately. 

Overall, a great AYCE hotpot spot in the sunset. Would definitely come back again and again.
author: Danny C.

description: Great service and food.  Also love the different variety of sauces to choose from and mix.  Kobe beef slices are delicious.  Many TVs then to watch the games as well.
author: Michael H.

description: First time eating here. Most of the food were good, i.e., proteins were good, snack/desserts were average, cucumber salad not as tasty. Only half of the wait staff were able to communicate in English, which made ordering very frustrating.  The entire ordering process was confusing and disorganized.  Our large party had three burners, so each burner was given a menu.  We ordered different broth and food for each burner, but to our surprise all the food were consolidated between two trays, so all of us had to resort to yelling up and down the table...who ordered this or that. By the time we sorted this out, we couldn't remember what we ordered vs what we received. We were missing several items that we ordered. We filled out another menu, yelled back/forth and didn't receive the complete order again.  Since we only have 90 mins from the time we seated to order otherwise be charged, we finally just told the English speaking waiter what food items we wanted. Why make us fill out the menus if we're never going to get the items we ordered?  To minimize the confusion and disorganization, each party should have one designated wait staff to offer direction (esp for first time diners), to make sure parties receive what they actually ordered and for better customer service all around. Probably better suited for parties with only one burner.
author: Alice C.

description: Enjoyed the dumplings-salted egg, bbq pork, chives.  Lamb marinated in beer. Fresh vegges-chinese cabbage and spinach.  Make your own sauce.  I can eat garlic and satay sauce with everything with cilantro and green onions.  AYCE - too many choices. Conch!  Hot tea is complimentary.  Pretty clean place out of no where land on judah.  Parking is limited.  Service is limited due to just 2 wait staff.  Time limited but they didn't enforce.
author: Helen L.

description: The pots is my new favorite hot pot joint in the city. The have a nice mixed selection of items such as fish balls, dim sum and have all the usuals that you'll find at most other hot pots. I've never had to wait an extensive amount of time which I appreciate. Their beef has had some amazing marbling which made for a very tasty experience. I think the sauce bar could benefit from a bit of an upgrade, but overall, my favorite in the city.
author: Erinn P.

description:
Pros: 
Big variety of soups: try the spicy miso and pork bone soup. Super good!!! (They charge extra if you order multiple flavors of their soups)
Everything we ordered was flavorful: try the Kobe Beef and pork dumplings!! Also their mussels were delicious! 
Decent selection of sauces
Their service was probably one of the best I've had when it came to all you can eat locations. They were super friendly, kind of slow coming to our table with check ups, but whenever we were able to wave them down, they were super helpful and nice. 

Cons: 
Small selection of meat 
Small selection of seafood 
Didn't give a last call for our order
author: Natalie L.

description:
YAY IM SO HAPPY I think I've found my go-to hot pot spot! Of all the hot pot places around SF/East Bay, this place really has the best quality toppings, broths (flavorful but not overly salty), and fair prices ($26 AYCE).  

The broths I've tried here are all on point (tom yum, spicy, and spicy miso), and you can tell that they make all their hot pot toppings in-house -- the fish balls, lobsters balls, ramen, and pork & shrimp dumplings were especially memorable! The meats and veggies are also all really fresh.

Our waiter also recommended we try the salty egg yolk bun which was probably my favorite of the "buns" on the menu (they're actually more like glutinous rice ball). It had a sweet and salty egg-yolk filling similar to fillings you can find in Asian pastries. All the "buns" have a sweet filling so at first I thought it was kinda weird to cook them in the hot pot broth, but the buns taste so good I didn't mind too much after a while haha 

The atmosphere here is clean, bright, and casual, and although the waiters can get pretty busy they defs get the job done. Look forward to becoming a regular here!
author: Jennifer T.

description: With my  family here for hotpot tonight .  Recommended from my friend to This place... Foods are so good and fresh, especially the beef dish!  Super friendly service! Definally will come back again.
author: Hong Z.

description:
Handsome boss The best hotpot I've ever eat in SF
The clerks here are very nice and patience to introduce the food. Service is very good.
author: Vickie C.

description: It was an amazing experience and food was great. The wagyu beef was amazing. I really can't explain it. You have to try out in order to find out. The broth was incredible. I will go back for sure.
author: Jaclynn C.

description:
Rain Drop
Hot Pot
My bf said this place was good but its not not not...

So I was craving AYCE hot pot and my go to place is Little Dipper down in South Bay but like we were in SF so we decided to go here and much to my dismay, it did not satisfy my craving -.- so u noe someone got in trouble that nite. Lol jk. Anyways, I got the miso broth and is was really salty. They didn't have a lot of options either in terms of meat selection compared to the other AYCE shabu that I've been to. Like bruh how you not gunna have pork belly???? The other kinds of meat was alright so I'm a bit baffled as to why this place has such high rating. Overall, I'd prob won't come back unless it's paid for lol.
author: An B.

description:
The Pot's makes for a fun, delicious meal with friends. It's all-you-can-eat hot pot. They have so many items, everything from plain and marinated meats (lamb, pork, beef, seafood) to seafood (tilapia, shrimp), and veggies. They also have a wide variety of noodles and dumplings. I wasn't a fan of the shrimp paste or Shanghai Pork Dumpling (XLB). That kind of dumpling is not meant for hot pot. Come with a group so you can order everything! The portion size of each order is pretty big. You are guaranteed to get food coma.

One negative is that they don't have many sauces. The hot pot restaurants back home in MD and VA have a full sauce bar allowing you to make your own tasty concoctions. I guess they make up for that with their many soup options. If you get more than one soup base, it's an additional $1 per person. Definitely worth it! We went with the Pork Bone and Spicy Miso.
author: Priscilla Y.

description:
So, this was my second time having eaten here and it was worse than the first. Came here thinking it was a different restaurant because a friend had planned for a bunch of us to come eat and got this mixed up with a different place. Would have told him to go somewhere else if I didn't mix it up. 

The service has gotten better. The people working this time were much friendlier and more attentive. 

HOWEVER my main issue with this place has gotten worse. They serve DIRTY ASS VEGETABLES. To the point where some of our Bok Choy wasn't just dirty it had MAGGOTS/LARVA. It was disgusting. We told them about it and they tried to give us some free drinks to compensate for it and gave us 10% off the bill, but still slapped gratuity on our bill. Okay. You serve us dirty food and still give us a mandatory 18% tip? It wasn't just the bok choy that was dirty either. A lot of the vegetables had either dirt or bugs on them. We forgot to take a picture of some of the stuff before we told them about how gross it was, but I found some more dirty vegetables later that I did take a picture of. 

I know some Asian restaurants aren't the cleanest (I've worked in the industry before), but at least properly wash and check your vegetables. This is something that's been constantly going on. 

THEY ALSO DONT WAIT FOR YOU TO LEAVE TO START CLEANING THE FLOOR WITH BLEACH. I could taste bleach as I was trying to finish eating my food. One person in our party had to run outside to keep from puking because they're really sensitive to bleach. 

Tl;dr disgusting, dirty food, they'll make you taste bleach.
author: Julio N.

description: For a hot pot virgin, this was place was awesome. Fast service. Endless ingredients. Good recommendations when you don't know what you want. Definitely coming back!
author: Alex G.

description: Favorite hotpot restaurant in the city, huge selection of food and soup base,awesome service and food quality, definitely my first choice of a hotpot restaurant
author: Oscar S.

description:
I live around the block from this place and was pretty bummed when they closed down for renovations a few months ago.

However, after they reopened, I think the place looks even better than before.  The ambiance is surprisingly chic for a hot pot place with fine lighting and new floors.  They installed a bunch of high end TVs everywhere and set up benched seating to accommodate more people.  In addition, their menu is even larger than before, with more meats and dishes available, as well as 5+ (if I recall) types of broths.  I also appreciate that they've got a personal sauce station in the middle of the restaurant where you can prepare your own dipping sauces.  The area is quite large, but I can imagine it'd be a fairly crowded area once more people are inside.

The service is quite expedient and efficient.  Since it's all-you-can-eat hot pot, the servers were very attentive, keeping an eye out for our table so we didn't need to stare or wave at them to flag them down.  The food came rather quickly and in bunches so we were rarely lacking for food (a very good thing for this sort of venue).

What sets this place apart from most hot pot places, other than the wide selection on their menu, is that their "dessert" dumplings.  I would come for just those alone, and I save room (if you can call it that) for them specifically.  They're basically the insides of the Chinese buns (sweet egg paste, red bean/lotus paste, custard, and taro) with a wrapper that keeps it compact as you soak it in the broth.  A fantastic way to end the night if you've got a dessert stomach.  

I'd also recommend their herbal tea (new, I think), which tastes like a saccharine, iced version of a grass jelly drink; I think we refilled our pitcher over half a dozen times.  We also made our money's worth on kobe beef too.  I personally avoid cabbage and rice as fillers, but I did order things like sesame balls and onion pancakes, which rival those of high-end Chinese restaurants in quality.  One last bit of advice is to start slow and don't order things en masse unless you know exactly what you want.  The service is good enough that you can ask them for paper menus and expect your food orders within 5-10 min while you're cooking or eating.

Parking is usually not too bad, and the N Judah streetcar stops about a block away.
Obviously, it's not cheap, at about $27 min per person, but if you're celebrating something (they take reservations and have special seating for large parties) or want to impress a date, I'd certainly recommend the Pot's.
author: Matthew W.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend and BF. This place is not that great. I prefer Ipot more. There is only 4 small plates of which you can make your own sauce. Basically soy sauce and some peanuts and chives. Disappointed by the sauce. The lamb here is better than the lamb at ipot but beef is way better at Ipot. I like that you can order dimsum at ipot but unfortunately you cannot here. I came here as my friend said it was the best place in SF. With some doubt I came here to try it. We ordered two soups- spicy miso and pork bone soup. The meats come i various marinations, and the beef and wine are okay. I recommend getting the regular beef.

It's $25/person for it and trust me, Ipot is so much better. (I'm sorry I can't stop comparing this place to ipot. Even boiling in fremont is better too!!) The pot can be two soup but they will charge a dollar each per soup, which adds more to your price. The food is definitely mediocore, and the shrimp paste is better. I highly recommend trying IPOT and comparing it to this place.
author: Amy Y.

description:
HOT POT IS MY JAM!

Taiwanese hot pot is seriously one of the most comforting things on a cold day. And in SF, there are plenty of cold days to go around. It's hard to get a good broth flavor, so when our good friends invited us to try out their new favorite hot pot place, we had to go. And we were not disappointed.

SERVICE
We came in on a Monday night at 7pm and had no trouble getting a table. Our server was so kind and eager to please. He apologized for waits (even though we weren't even waiting) and any slight inconveniences. He was quick with the water, tea, and beers refills. Finished plates were also cleared very quickly.

FOOD
The hot pot itself is AYCE (all you can eat), which I've never had before for hot pot. They give you a paper menu to order from. We selected 1/2 spicy broth and 1/2 pork bone. Both were delicious. The spicy was laden with Szechuan peppers dripping red oil, but was not so spicy that people couldn't eat it. There's a little tray of add-ins to your personal dipping sauce -- ginger, onion, peanut sauce, etc. I added all but the chili to mine, and everything I ate was delicious from then on!

As for what to order, the kobe beef and enoki mushrooms were my personal favorites. The cuttlefish balls, fresh shrimp balls, and mixed meat dumplings were also really good. The flavors were on point and the meat was always tender and soft, never chewy. I was especially impressed with the calamari squid -- it was not chewy at all and I could cut it with my wooden chopsticks! We also loved the black fungus and noodles, as well as nappa cabbage and baby bok choi. And the radish was divine -- it cooks up so soft and warm, and is a perfect complement to the sauce and meats. We ended up going big and getting 4 rounds of ingredients. The staff never once stopped us or made us feel anything other than excited to be ordering more.

We washed it all down with big bottles of Asahi. They've got a decent beer selection and you can do AYCD (all you can drink) beers for an additional fee ($13 I think, but don't quote me on that). 

I loved my experience here and will definitely be back.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I've definitely experienced better hot pot but I think this place deserves two over three stars.

I decided to try a hot pot place in San Francisco that was not Shabu, and something that had AYCE available for less than $30/person. 

Limited street parking, but my boyfriend and I got lucky. We snagged a spot less than a block away from the restaurant. The place isn't spacious so I would expect a crowd on Friday nights or weekends. 

A table shares one pot. I've read from a previous review that it cost $1 extra per person if you want two broths. I think that's just plain stupid. 

My bf and I selected miso broth and ordered imitation crab, fried fish cake, napa, lamb, beef, and a variety of seafood and meat balls. Huge thumbs down for their beef, too chewy! Y
Yes, miso IS salty but I think the broth was TOO salty. Salty to the point that sauce is completely useless.. 

We requested peanut and ponzu sauce. I think their peanut came straight from a Skippy's jar but whipped till it was viscous lol .. 

Overall I wouldn't come back given that I live closer to another hot pot restaurant that serves similar food at a cheaper price.
author: Danae L.

description:
Um why is this place four stars?

Came here for dinner, and there's plenty of seating. How this AYCE hotpot restaurant works is that you check off the ingredients you want from a list, but don't worry you can always order more from the list later. 1 soup base is set at a standard price, but if you order a mix of 2 or 3 soup bases, it'll cost more. There a wide range of different options for ingredients which is a huge plus, and the stove is simple to manage. The price here for AYCE is $25/person, which isn't a bad deal at all. Service was friendly, and there's always waiters walking around. Poor ventilation in here though. As I was dining, I felt like I was stuck in a hot box. I mean even the glass windows fogged up.

Got the Spicy Miso and Pork Bone for soup base and tried the Kobe Beef and Lamb.

Both soups tasted nice, but I would prefer the Spicy Miso over the Pork Bone. The kobe beef barely had barely any marbling fat to it. The lamb meat was sliced way too thin that when I tried picking it up, it fell apart into little pieces. The enoki mushrooms and A-choy didn't quite taste as fresh as I would like. They sparked my appetite though with the options for Chinese donuts and Egg Yolk Buns.

Hotpot is one of my top things to eat, and this place did not satisfy my taste buds.
author: Kevin S.

description:
If you like hot pot, this place is a pretty solid bet. Located in a convenient section of the outer/central sunset on Judah, it's easy to get here on public transportation.

At about $28pp, it's not a bad price. There are tons of choices for food and soup bases. It's definitely improved, especially with the recent makeover. You get to make your own dipping sauce, which is so nice! I tend to go overboard overboard with kobe beef, but their cheese-filled meatballs are good, too! They have a wide selection of vegetables -- and it's fresh veggies, too! 

If you're in the main dining room, you'll probably find that service is impeccable. If you're in the side room, you're often forgotten. I was in the side room the last time, and we only managed to get another order of food a couple of times. HINT: if you're here, order tons of food!

Food: 9/10
Staff: 9/10
Atmosphere: 7/10
Value: 9/10
Overall: 8.5/10
author: Evan K.

description:
Large portions, a $13 AYCD (all you can drink) of sake/beer. We went on a Wednesday and it was pretty relaxed-- we were seated right away (we got there at 7, it did fill up pretty much right away at 730) and then c'mon food! I did feel a little bad because the servers were so so busy, but they kept our plates full and our pot filled with broth, so was I was very appreciative. 

AYCE on Wednesday was $25 ( give or take a couple cents) and then my sister ordered a large sake, so total for four of us was a little over $110. Quality of meats was very high-- I am only sad I didn't save room for their made-in-house dessert dumplings!
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
I was visiting from Los Angeles and my friend suggested this place to me as a local favorite. I was skeptical at first because I already have my favorite hot pot spots in LA. However, after eating there, I finally understood why it was a favorite amongst the locals. It's the best place to be in on a chilly day in SF!

First off, it's ALL YOU CAN EAT! Nothing to complain about that. There is usually a long wait but it's pretty worth it if you go with a group. I took off one star because the service was extremely lacking. It was a full house that night and they only had 2 waiters. I didn't mind the slow service at first, but then I got annoyed when the female waitress continued to ignore my table and not the others. 

If you love spicy broth, I recommend ordering it for the whole pot instead of the half/half option. My group and I agreed the house spicy broth was way better than the regular pork bone soup base. 

Don't forget to ask for satay sauce!
author: Ida C.

description: Had a late Sunday dinner after a Warriors game, just before closing.  Seated immediately, ordered pork bone and curry stock for our vegetarian guest.  Portions were generous, noodles delectable and vegetables scrumptious. Sampled "small plates", green onion pancakes, shrimp dumplings, veggie eggrolls; all well prepared and served promptly.  From a So Cal perspective, this hot pot restaurant is a gem and far exceeds our local Shabu shabu offerings.  Keep up the great offerings, will definitely return.
author: Lavinia C.

description:
I've been here before and after the renovation, and either way, I'd give them 5 stars. 

The restaurant feels more spacious and looks more upscale after their renovation. They now have a small sauce bar that you can use to customize your own sauce, which is definitely a plus!

I always get the spicy miso soup, and it's so good. Their meat is always good and doesn't ever taste gamey. They've included some snacks and fried buns with condensed milk on the menu. Those fried buns are so delicious!! The only thing I will say is the orders for the fried buns do not come out consistently. I think if you order them, they make enough for the people in your party. But sometimes they're off and bring less, but you can order more since it's included in AYCE. 

The Pot's is definitely my favorite hot pot place in the city!
author: Alyssa P.

description:
Best place to be in a rainy chilly day! We had a full stomach of food and felt very satisfied after. The three soup bases we tried are all good, and I can't wait to try more. They have a good variety of meat and vegetables, includes black wood ear mushrooms, tofu vege wraps, and silver ear mushrooms(we didn't try). They also have dessert items, the salty egg yolk bun is the best!

A few points to improve: 
They didn't have yogurt that night--sadness 
Out of the items we ordered off the menu, at least 4/5 items didn't show up to our table. No explanation 
The service was kinda of slow, they need more staff, the people working there seemed pretty busy
author: Julia Z.

description:
Loved this hot pot place (compared to socal) for many reasons. Here are a few:

1. Hot tea was served for free. Amazing beverage to have on a very cold San Franciscan night. 

2. How many order of items you want is exactly what you get. Ex: we ordered 3 kobe beef so we got 3 giant plates of kobe beef. Places in socal might put 3 orders in one plate and it definitely did not look like 3 orders. 

3. Lots of food options available. 

4. Lots of soup bases available

5. I asked for satay and they brought out a whole container of it!! Socal places will give me a bowl's worth with more oil than satay itself. 

6. Sauces were already on the table for you to mix and match. Didn't have to get up for anything! Yassss! 

7. $26 a person for ayce 

8. Great service. 

I would hope to come back the next time I'm around sf. Parking is a little hard to come by but San Francisco is known for their long walks everywhere so I can't really complain.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
The crystal egg yolk lava dumplings and taro dumplings are delicious still. Service was a bit more attentive the second time around since we went near closing time when the restaurant was at partial capacity. BUT(T)...

Shit:
I was going to bump it up a star until I was rudely reminded of the aftermath from my first visit... after spending the next two hours giving birth to a small village of monsters in the bathroom, while my new dining partner from this time told me that he basically shot firecrackers from his ass after.


~~HEALTH INSPECTIONS FAIL~~

Out of curiosity, I looked up their health inspection records. Their latest inspection records from summer 2013 includes high risk for the following violations: high risk vermin infestation, unclean or unsanitary food contact surfaces, high risk food holding temperature.

No re-inspection followup records since then, but 2013's records include more violations than inspections from the summer before (2012), so you can think about how seriously they take the health measures while you explode in the bathroom.
author: Tian Q.

description:
4.5 stars! 

Ever since Hot Pot Garden on Taraval closed down I've been looking for somewhere to take its place. Up until now I haven't had any luck and have had to resort to go to the Hot Pot Garden in Millbrae. But The Pots is a definite contender for the number one hot pot spot! 

First of all the ayce is 25.99 and a steal for the amount of options you get. And you can choose up to 3 different broths! We got the spicy fire, pork bone, and the curry broth. I've never had a curry broth for hot pot and it turned out really great! The spicy fire is packed with chilies and is a spice lovers dream. Definitely get the Chinese donut! If you're thirsty and craving something sweet get the passion fruit green tea (you can get a pitcher for the table instead of individual drinks) I am leaving with my tummy fully satisfied. Until next time!
author: Sam L.

description:
My first hot pot experience was a success!

Yes, this place is pricey. On a Saturday, the meal cost $25 plus tax and tip, or $35 total; I was in a group of 11 people, so the tip was high. So worth it! Felt like I had 2 meals. 

The Pot's has a great selection of food to put in our pot, including beef, seafood, bok choy, chinese donuts, etc etc. There was a variable selection of noodles--from udon to ramen. Aside from the delicious slices of tenderloin, I loved the Chinese donuts and egg custard "bun," which was more of a custard dumpling. The Chinese donuts came straight from the fryer and was wonderful to dip in the soup. Melt-in-your mouth goodness! 

Restaurant is a little out of the way. You have to take Muni. Sorry, BART does not traverse the Outer Sunset. However, if you've never experienced hot pot, it is well worth it!
author: Joanna S.

description:
I have been to the Pots twice and both times, the food is delicious. It is an all-you-can-eat hot pot establishment and is accommodating is large parties. They have two separate rooms from the main dining room to accommodate private parties (we had a party of approx 13 the first time and approx 10 the second time.) The selection is pretty impressive with broths, sides, and meats. They even have sweet balls stuffed with red bean and custard in addition to the savory fish balls.

The only thing I can say is that I wish the service was a little better, when we checked off that we wanted three orders of Kobe beef we only got one. And for the second time we were there, we were celebrating a birthday and had asked for the cake to be delivered out. They just took out the pink box the cake came in and gave us a knife. Granted, I know it is not a fancy dining establishment but it would've meant a lot if they had offered to even set up the cake with the candles we gave them.

TL;DR: Food is good, don't expect them to go the extra mile for your meal doe.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Most reviewers forget to add that their Sake Broth is not bad too. Overall, this is a great place if you are very hungry, the nice part is they can provide up to three different soup bases in one pot (other places only offer up to two) Their spicy broth is more of chili oil and lots of pepper, and leaves your mouth feeling full of pepper and oil, but it was rather spicy for my standards. 

The meat and vegetables were quite fresh and I was impressed. What I was not impressed was that the soup broths all had msg added. I left feeling very dry and salty.
author: SB W.

description:
They take credit cards! When I first came here two years ago, they didn't, but I'm glad they accept credit cards now.

All you can eat for about $26 is not bad at all. I enjoy their broth - pork bone, spicy miso, and curry. I like that they have an assortment of dishes, dumplings, veggies, bean curds, meats, seafood and other appetizers - well balanced meal. I tend to always over indulged on meat at other hot pots, but this time I've learned to eat whatever I was in the mood for.

My go to's: Beef tongue, scallop shao mai, kobe beef slice, lamb slice, beef tendon, bok choy, enoki mushroom, spinach, chinese donut (to dip in broth after all the meat flavor have soaked into the broth), fried pumpkin slice (first time I had was much better than the second time), deep fried tofu skin roll.

Service is a bit lacking, but the servers are nice.
author: Mandy D.

description:
As Elsa would say, "The cold never bothered me anyway." 
Uh, no storm can come between me and my hot pot. It was one of those stormy SF nights with heavy rain combined with the disgusting winds. But my friends and I still came to hot pot, and surprisingly HELLA people were ELSA as well. Like, the storm didn't phase anyone at all.

::FOOD::
AYCE HOT POT $25.99
We got the pork bone broth and the miso soup. $1 additional added to each person to do the halfsies. You also have the option of 3 soup bases, but its quite pricier. 
The pork bone was plain and flavorless but I liked it more than the miso soup. Something about the miso soup threw me off. It was extremely salty where it made the items not as great. 
They provided the starter kit for making your sauce with soy sauce, garlic, cilantro, AND SATAY (IM SOORRRY... DONT JUDGE... I FINISHED THE ENTIRE CAN. IT WAS MEEEEEE:p). Satay is the best thing to go with hot pot.

MEAT
Small variety of COMMON meat I have to say. They do have a big selection but it's stuff I wouldnt order like pork intestine, pork blood, pork ear, beef tongue etc. Super liked the Kobe beef slice though as it was pretty tender. The pork slice was good too. 
~fav one: Kobe Beef
MEAT/SEAFOOD BALLS
Variety like beef tendon ball, fried fish ball, lobster ball (so artificial tasting you find a pic under ARTIFICIAL in the dictionary), pork meat ball, etc. 
HAND MADE MEAT & SEAFOOD BALLS
they got stuff like beef or shrimp with cheese filling, fresh shrimp ball, scallop shao mai, cuttlefish ball, fish ball (SUPER good btw, you can actually taste the freshness), shrimp or fish paste
~fav one: fish ball
SEAFOOD
 fish fillet (not that fresh tasting), shrimp, imitation crab, cuttle fish, mussel, fried fish cake (pretty good)
~fav one: Fried fish cake
NOODLES& OTHERS
thin rice noodle, ramen noodle (ehh i would skip next time it was hard no matter how long we cooked it), egg noodle, udon (my fav:), thick noodle, instant noodle, flat rice noodle, taro thread, hot dog, chinese donut, rice, hotlink, bean vermicelli
~fav one: UDON
HOME MADE DUMPLING
shrimp wonton, pork & shrimp (not that good, full of veggies and my friends who like veggies did not like it), shang hai pork dumpling, chicken & chives, hot pot taro bun, hot pot red bean bun, hot pot egg yolk bun, spinach dumpling, shrimp dumpling, etc. 
~Fav one: Shanghai pork dumpling
VEGETABLES
IF YOU LIKE VEGGIES OR ARE VEGETARIAN, this is probably HEAVEN for you. Not gonna name it all since there's so many
~Fav one: deep fried tofu 


::Service/ Atmosphere/Parking::
Service was pretty decent. Only one girl who was a bit shorter was SUPER nice to us. The guys there never had much emotion. There were hella people running around so it wasnt too hard to flag down. 
Atmosphere super loud and waiters/waitresses running around like any other hot pot places. 
Parking SUCKS. This area has 0 to oh 0 parking. Its always full here for some reason. I had to park maybe 3 blocks in the residential area and my friends parked even further. 

Overall, a pretty good place to hot pot. Wish they had more meat selections though for carnivores like me.. Other than that, not much to complain about.
author: Chena N.

description:
My friend told me that this was a Shabu place, Yelp told me that this is a Hot Pot place and when I called to make a reservations they spoke Cantonese and so I know at that point that it is a definitely Chinese place.

I made reservations because I saw Yelpers say that they take reservations and I just don't feel like getting to a place and waiting for a table anymore. I got here around 6 and was promptly seated.

Note: Like most Chinese places, you have to flag down waiters for service, if that's something that you aren't used to, that's how this place operates. You ask and they come to you right away and give you service, it's standard around Chinese places, so don't be alarmed and I didn't take off a star for it because of that reason.

For an all you can eat place, the meat was pretty average, but not bad. Vegetables were fresh and the fish balls, pork balls and beef balls they had was tasty and of the standard fare. Overall, things were pretty fresh and there is a variety of broth to choose from (although it seems like most of them are pretty greasy, so if you are health conscious, might be best to stick with hot water and make your own broth by making the food yourself).

Parking in sunset is hit and miss, the good part is that there is a MUNI Rail station half a block away. (I believe it's the N Train, or whatever train that's headed to Ocean Beach).

There is value here in the price, if you are a big eater, or just don't want to have it nickel and dime you, this isn't bad. (I've been to a per plate place and came out with a $100 bill without even knowing). Price on Weekdays are $24.99 and weekends are $25.99, and i would say that you get what you pay for, it's not the $12 Hot Pot place that gives you crap.

Overall I would come back to this place again for the value and the selection. I would skip the broth next time and just go with water and maybe a couple of chilis if I want something spicy.

For $13, you can also get unlimited beers (and the price of an uber ride home afterwards).
author: Duncan H.

description:
If you are an extraordinarily hungry couple or group not looking for intimacy, "The Pot's" weekday all you can eat for $24.99 or their weekend price of $25.99 just might be for you. 
.
Although the atmosphere seems somewhat like a meat market to me, the servers are very willing and attentive, thanks so much guys. 
.
Note: I prefer spicy broth and here it seems more salty than spicy. 
.
They have an impressive variety of meats that include intestine, tongue, ear, stomach and tendon just to name a few... They also have many homemade dumplings of meat and seafood not to mention an equally large variety of noodles.
.
Despite what might sound a bit harsh my friends and I do come here on occasion.
author: Caesar A.

description:
A very good hot pot place with good quality meat and lots of food options.

It's pretty popular but they do accept reservations, although there's still a bit of wait.
author: Karen L.

description:
Overall:  Causal/big place offers traditional hot pot experience.  Lots of food options for $25.99 AYCE within 1-1.5 hrs.   (i can't remember if it is 1 or 1.5) but it was PLENTY of time for our group.  

NOTE:  There is 'additional' charge on the bill for sauce per person.  (It wasn't a lot but not really a fan).  If you add some beer, the price/pp really add up. :) 
NOTE:  They do take reservation.  Call ahead so you don't have to wait. 

Review was based on weekend Saturday dinner with 6:30 Reservation.  Street parking only but you will find something since you are all the way out around 33th.

Services:  4 stars.  The servers come check on you very frequently on food request, water, remove dirty plates.  

Food/drinks/ Value:  
Soup base:  Each pot is divided into 3 sections.  You can have 3 soup options.   
- Spicy hot pepper was very flavorful and spicy.  It is anise star so you might feel a little 'Ma La' tingly.
- Satay - I like this one too.  Good satay favor on the meat.
- Beef bone - very mild.  Good for kids
- Sake - Very light mild with ginger inside. 

Hot pot options: 
- Kobe Beef - Like other yelpers suggested, it is very tasty and soft.
- Wine Beef - Good wine taste but the meat was thicker cut
- Beef Tongue - Delicious if you are a tongue person. :) 
- Intestine and Tripe - Both are delicious if you can handle them.   I can't do hot pot without tripe :)
- Fish paste - Not that much place will offer fish paste.  There were actually 2 kinds.  
- Pork
- Fried Fish cake - OK
- Veggies - so many options.  All fresh.  
- XLB little dumplings - Skip it.  Not good. 

Decor: Causal and lots of seating based on SF standard.

Kids friendly:  Yes BUT you are paying 1/2 price for them.   For $13 each, my kids only had a couple slice of beef and some fish cakes.    :)  BTW, they go by counter height and not by age.  My super petite girls are half price.  I think it is best for adult and get the kids a babysitters instead.

Gluten Free/Sensitivity:  Nothing was labeled with GF.   Ask the server or use your judgement.  I do not believe they use GF soy sauce.
author: May Y.

description:
Let's not get confused - hot pot at a restaurant, for whatever reason, is never quite as good as hot pot at home.  That being said, going out for it is definitely a lot more convenient; it looks simple, but doing hot pot at home is a lot of work, given all of the prep and clean up.  Plus, at restaurants, it's AYCE!  Well, it's AYCE at home too, but at least it's a fixed price at a restaurant.

With my favorite hot pot joint currently out of commission (Hot Pot Garden), the Pot's is now my go-to hot pot joint.  Much like with Hot Pot Garden, menu variety certainly isn't lacking - a dozen different soup broths, along with numerous types of seafood, meat, vegetable, meat/fish balls, dumplings, and noodles to choose from (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-pots-san-francisco?select=0evdtLvTtI4mPMe7ZNWa9Q#0evdtLvTtI4mPMe7ZNWa9Q).  

On this most recent visit, my friend and I got a split pot with the HK Style Satay and the Spicy Miso (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-pots-san-francisco?select=0evdtLvTtI4mPMe7ZNWa9Q#T9JbIYxdEXfJ8PPIZ5te0A).  I also tried the Fire Sauce on a previous trip here and of the three, the Spicy is definitely the best one.  It's more flavorful than the HK Style Satay and has just the right amount of heat, but isn't as heavy on the spices as the Fire Sauce.

As for their other menu selections, most are pretty decent, though there are a few things that aren't all that great (particularly the dumplings).  The fishcakes/balls are a little hit and miss (fried fishcake good, lobster ball meh), but the vegetables have all been fresh and the meats (Kobe beef and lamb) have been pretty tasty (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-pots-san-francisco?select=0evdtLvTtI4mPMe7ZNWa9Q#VdIcsG79p75mSjBF0TYeGQ).

While The Pot's is a more than adequate substitute until Hot Pot Garden reopens, it should be noted there's a gap between the two.  Both are good, but it breaks down to quality versus quantity.  The Pot's has much more to choose from (12 soups versus 8, more types of meat/goodies), but Hot Pot Garden simply tastes a bit better.  Better Spicy Miso broth, better meat, and better (friendlier) service.  Not that I won't be coming back, especially since the lines are a little shorter...and prices are cheaper ($25 Fri-Sun, $26 Mon-Thurs).
author: Mike L.

description: The worst hotpot meal ever! The base soup has no flavor but MSG. The meat is not the freshest. Fried tofu is aweful, so stuffed. Tong Ho is so old! Nothing can be praised this place.
author: Emmy P.

description:
The Pot's serves really authentic Hong Kong style hot pot! Their menu has a lot of choice and my favorite item is the fried bean curd sheets (I only find them in Hong Kong). I never went to a hotpot place in US that served it, so I was pretty amazed and surprised when they brought it to my table! 

Service was awesome! All the staff were very attentive and quick with everything. Shout out to the boss!! He made my family feel really welcome and we would definitely go back when we crave hot pot.

They also have special deals on big holidays (like Black Friday and New Years). If you download this app called "Dealmoon", enter their Chinese name, and share it on WeChat, you might get discounted prices!

Black Friday: $18/person (Cash Only)
New Years Day: $20/person (Cash Only)
Regular Price: 25.99/person (Cash or Credit)

I wish they offer this discount on yelp or as a check in offer, it makes sharing and using it much easier.
author: Melody L.

description:
First time here. It was good. My family & I came on NYE for dinner. It was a cold evening. Perfect for hot pot. We were a party of 7 people and arrived around 5:15pm. We did not make reservations. Waited a few minutes for a table. The menu is printed on one large sheet of paper. There were a variety of items to choose from. You mark how many you want. It's all you can eat. For $25 + tax AYCE, it's actually not that bad considering the amount they give you. 

We had 2 pots with one broth each: regular miso and bone broth. We were going to get 2 split broth in each pot but noticed in small print...they charge $1 extra for each person if you split the hot pot. Portion is great. I didn't care much for the kobe beef slices. I prefer the regular lamb slices over the beef. If you forget the beef and was cooked longer than it should, it becomes tough & chewy. The lamb remained tender even if it's cooked long. The lamb marinated with beer was like whoa. I can really taste the beer. Definitely, not for kids. The beef marinated with wine was good. Not that bad. Shrimp, swai fish filet, tendons & all types of veggies were good. The dumplings were very filling! I requested hot sauce and was given sriracha only. I was expecting a house-made spicy chili sauce but none.

Make sure you get all the items ordered. They forgot our egg noodles. By the time we noticed it, we were already full and didn't bother with it. It would be nice if it was brought out during the beginning of our meal. At the end of our meal, we scooped out some broth into the empty sauce bowl. Drank it and yum! So much flavor & tasty. Warms up the soul. Overall, we enjoyed dinner. By the time we left at 7pm, there was a line out the door. They were busy & packed. I would definitely come back again.
author: Amy H.

description:
owner change, food quality get lower, service only
okay.
author: Grayson C.

description:
Outstanding place! Brian, the server, provides the most courteous service here & the hot pot he advised to order was simply out of this universe! HIGHLY recommend!
Great job, guys!
author: Konstantin A.

description: My go to hot pot place! I have to say they have the most variety selection on their menu than any hotpot place within the city.
author: Kitty Z.

description: Good food, the owner is very friendly and approachable. Only thing I didn't like was that fact that the sauce bar, could use some more variety. One of the waiters keeps forgetting things that we asks. Other than that, I would still come back again.
author: Kevin K.

description:
My family and I came last night (Christmas Eve) for my dad's birthday, and good thing we made a reservation because they had a whole list of people waiting for a table! 

What we ordered: 
Soup: spicy miso and pork bone
Meats: fish fillet, Kobe beef, pork slices 
Veggies: iced tofu, enoki mushroom, a choy, Napa cabbage, spinach, fried yam, fried pumpkin, eggplant, all the dumpling varieties, fried stuffed tofu skin
Starches: rice, udon, ramen 

My favorite was the iced tofu and the fried tofu skin, the fish fillet was pretty good but the pork was really fatty so after our first round we just stuck to the beef. Also the rice was hard/undercooked. 

Overall we enjoyed the food, they had a lot of variety. The only downside was the service, it was hard to get anyone's attention. For $25 I think there are better hot pot places to go.
author: Linz C.

description: First visit and my mom's first time having hot pot. Super clean and plenty of food   . Just long lulls between visits by your server. Price was right also. I'll go back
author: Jonathan K.

description:
They say location is everything. Thanks to the Outer Sunset's cold and foggy microclimate, The Pot's definitely caters the perfect meal for this type of weather. My experience with hot pots have been limited to Little Sheep, but The Pot's has a lot more variety and better quality ingredients. There were 13 different soup bases to choose from! While the fire spicy may look intimidating, it's not that bad if you exclusively cook the meats in there separate from your vegetables. We split half that soup base with the coconut pork bone for some variety.

In addition to the soup bases, there were so many meat, seafood, and dumpling choices. All the ingredients looked fresh, not frozen including the meatballs. The variety of noodles was vast as well. Favorites included the lamb, enoki mushrooms, ramen noodles, fish fillet, and the many different types of dumplings. 

Dinner was limited to 90 minutes and came out to be around $35 per person with tax and tip. This place was insanely packed at dinner so I recommend getting here by 6:00 pm at the latest for a walk-in table.
author: Bailey Z.

description: Very nice decor, friendly service, good food. Kind of pricy, but I guess that's how AYCE is. Came here on July 4th and it wasn't too busy.
author: Emery Y.

description:
The Pots done let me down! I reserved a table for 10 people a few days in advance. They didn't say we'd have to split tables or anything, they said no problem. 

We go there and they put us in two tables of 6. Okay... Can you not put us together? They point was for all of us to eat together but they gave the bigger tables to other people. -.- so what did I reserve?? Heck do I know.

Anyways, we end up splitting 5 and 5, and then they only let us get one pot per table because you need 6 people on a table to get the second pot. Well. Okay then. So we all squish to one half of each of the tables to get to the pot. What the heck is this?

Then we thought, well since we're basically separate parties, at least they can split the check so we can use more cards. (2 credit cards per party) Despite being on separate tables, they said no. 

The food, from previous times I've gone, is delicious, but our mood had soured. Service is slow. They mixed up the food order a lot. It was a disaster. I'm disappointed because this used to be my favorite. :(
author: Brandon L.

description:
DO NOT GET THE COCONUT PORK BONE SOUP BASE!!!
Tasted horrible and bland, and they only made it worse by just refilling with water instead of base. The artificial flavoring was obvious and disgusting!
Pork bone is most popular one here and I should have gotten that one.    
They charge extra to have more than one soup base and it's an extra dollar PER PERSON....what the heck?!  So you have to pay more for soup base if your party is bigger.  That is such a dumb policy.  It's the same pot and the same amount of soup base......-2 stars just for that! 

Also, they have dipping sauces you have to explicitly ask for.  We didn't find out until the end when we noticed it on other tables.... 

My favorite thing here are the dessert dumplings.  First them having them and it was delicious!!! YUMMY!!! I will come back just for that! 

But seriously, fix the silly soup base charge policy.....
author: David W.

description:
The Pot's is my favorite hot pot place in the Bay Area. It's a no nonsense hot pot sort of place that brings me back to when I used to hot pot back home with my parents. I'm a traditionalist and always get the clear broth, but they have a vast selection of broths including spicy, curry, and even coconut.

Definitely order:
-fish paste
-shrimp paste
-fish filets
-egg yolk bun

-1 star for the semi sub par/ absent minded service, but + for its all you can eat goodness. Simple and quick - you just sit down and eat!
author: Patricia K.

description:
If you are a hot pot lover then you must try the pot.  There are so many interesting broths to choose from so we had a tough time deciding which ones to go with. They have fresh meats especially snow flask beef which comes in thin slice pieces. 
Customer services is good.
author: Emily L.

description:
All you can eat, so come hungry!! Really good quality food. They provide spicy and non-spicy hot pot, so you can bring people who don't like spicy food with you. But we all know the spicy hot pot is were it's at! A couple comments of the food:

Kobe beef is really good, can't get enough of this stuff
Lamb is good as well, can't go wrong here
Pork blood is okay, somewhat bland flavor, but I like the texture
Fish balls have a texture equivalent to chicken nuggets, flavor was okay
Winter melon was good
Chinese donut is actually pretty good when you dip it into the broth for 3 seconds
Veggies are a must if you're eating a lot of meat
You have to get all the dumplings, they were very good

Also, make sure the clothes you wear are easy to wash, because your clothes will reek of this place when you leave!!

Prices: $24.99 (Mon-Thurs) and $25.99 (Fri-Sun), but it comes out to over $30 when you include tax and tip.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Honestly, every hot pot are the same right and why this one is any different than others? For me personally it is all about the broth. I still haven't found a place that can replace the coconut pork bone soup yet. The nice thing about the Pot's is that they have so many options just on the broth itself. I don't need to go in too much details on the meat selections since everyone has their own preferences on the meat but I usually order their prime rib slice, lamb,and beef tongue (those are the must for me). You will never have enough of it. 
That's why this place is always pack!! Make sure to go there early.
author: Christopher L.

description: This place is expensive, and their soup is not even good service sucks dipping sauce sucks I don't have any good thing to say about this place I don't recommend this to anyone n yeah i felt like meat was a little old.. so sorry I will not be coming back to this place. Hope the owner stop buying yelp stars to make this place looks good
author: Saige A.

description:
I come here on a regular basis.. I love their pork bone soup base. Also they have alot varieties of side dishes and meats.  I love the pork intestines. Not many places have that.. 
Now they have a karaoke room.. eat and sing at the same time...love it..
author: Jim T.

description:
3-3.5 stars. Probably wouldn't come back, just because there are other options (really want to try Nabe!) and the broths are too salty here. Our party of 6 made reservations so luckily didn't have to wait at all, though there was definitely a wait for others. We shared 2 pots, and for each we split it into 3 so we tried: pork bone, chicken feet & mushroom, sake, miso, congee, and black pepper pork stomach. We were surprised to learn that all their broths, except the sake and congee (I think), have sugar in them, which made it a little challenging for one of the people in our party who cannot have sugar.
