But, we made do! 

They've got a large variety of items, and there was nothing that we wanted that they didn't have. All the meats were good- lamb, kobe beef, pork, and also the marinated meats (in red wine and beer) were interesting and tasty! Recommend the fish and shrimp paste, too, over the balls (though I can't resist a fish ball anyway), as well as the iced tofu and fish cake. The salty egg yolk dumpling was also interesting, and a nice mix of salty and sweet. I think the $25 price tag for AYCE is appropriate for the amount of items they have and the quality. If only the broths were less salty! They come pre-made/packaged, so you can't really adjust that unless you add more water or tea to the pot. Oh, and the sauce they give you to dip your food in is also salty, so it's like salt on salt. 

Tip: Definitely get some instant noodles to make in the miso broth to finish your meal (but don't drink the soup 'cause, again, salty!).
author: Kathy L.

description:
I'm pretty disappointed about the spicy broth which describes as "super spicy" as it is not spicy at all. Just extremely salty. 
Plus it is pretty hot inside. I notice that there's a big fan at the corner, I assume that they don't have or have poor a/c. Can you imagine that a hot pot restaurant have no a/c? That's unacceptable!
I heard a lot about their bad service, for me they are ok. 
For this quality, even though they are cheaper than my favorite hot pot places, it is quite expensive. It just a pot of MSG. Not recommended.
author: Cherlyn H.

description:
This is my go to spot if I want to hang out with a group of friends. You definitely get your money's worth. The beef marinated in wine is a must try. My favorite broth would have to be the pork bone. Everything is in large quantities so it is always good to come with a completely empty stomach~ 

I will be back.
-A
author: Alison L.

description: This place is great but be aware that they are on vacation! The restaurant is closed until April. Be warned!
author: David D.

description: If you have a large party, I urge you to make a reservation. This place gets super jam packed at night. Parking around the area is horrible, so you definitely need to go a littler earlier than your reservation so you can find some street parking. The food was nothing special. We got the pork bone base. It wasn't bad, but wasn't memorable. The meat wasn't frozen which bumps it up a star. Service is slow but everyone is super friendly.
author: Ada H.

description:
I give the food 4 stars but the service 2 stars. It is all you can eat, however, it took 30 minutes for each round to get to our table. We were there for a total of 3 hours for 2 rounds of food. The servers would usually be behind the counter just hanging out while people would try to constantly get their attention. 

My group ordered 2 broths, spicy miso & cilantro with preserved egg. They were both really good!

The menu has a wide variety to choose from which is good! 

$25 for AYCE dinner but we had to stay 3 hours to get our money's worth (which was only 2 rounds because they took forever or forgot to bring our order). 

I'd say give it a go for the experience and food but don't expect speedy and efficient service.
author: Sarah G.

description:
3.5 star review

Surprisingly, this place is decent. The first time i came here, my bf and I thought this place was MEH. But since we didn't quite remember our impression on this place the first time, we came back the other night. The first time we came we had tonkatsu and spicy miso broth, the spicy miso was good and the tonkatsu was forgettable and bland. This time around we got the Very curry and spicy miso broths, let me just say, it was a good choice. The Very curry looked a bit oily to begin with but it had a good amount of curry flavor and it was spicy. Do try the Very curry broth, if you like curry! Spicy miso, had good flavor and it was pretty spicy! But not burn your mouth spicy, it packed a good amount of heat.

 I was craving all kinds of dumplings and balls that night so we got an assortment and lets just say those were not bad. We got shrimp balls with cheese, shu mai, fish balls, fish cake, imitation crab, lobster balls, shrimp balls, and xiao long bao. all of them cooked were not bad at all, except skip the xiao long bao, it was not good. 

We went with kobe beef, the first 2 dishes had really lean beef but when we ordered an extra plate of beef, this plate was not lean. it was some pretty fatty slices of beef. Even though i do like the marbling of beef, these slices were way too big and fatty. 

Overall, I would come here again. That very curry broth was so good, and the dumplings and balls were all delicious. This is actually closer to me than hot pot garden and it seems to be less crowded, will make another trip here again soon!

Total for 2: $ 61
author: Stella J.

description:
When you put AYCE and hot pot together, consider me there. We had a large party and made a reservation in advance and we ended up in our own private room which was cool, though it was super hot even though they put the fans on.

They have a really decent selection of soup bases and plenty of meat and veggies to choose from as well. If you do a half and half soup base, they charge you more though. How lame. But since there were so many of us, we got more than one pot which meant we could choose more than one soup base.

We got the pork bone which was pretty good. It could have a little more flavor though. The miso was pretty good. Probably one of my favorites of the night. And the tomato one was... interesting haha

The veggies were pretty fresh which I appreciated and the meat was alright. We pretty much tried a little bit of everything and some it was good and some of it was just alright. They have some really interesting picks like cheesy meatballs, and beef with beer or wine and you can totally taste the alcohol. I would eat these last because they will change the flavor of your soup base. Everything tasted like wine afterwards!

Overall, it was okay. The soup bases could have more flavor and the meat quality was just okay. Large selection of things to choose from though.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
We took my mother in law here for her bday on a Wednesday so it wasn't that packed...which is a good thing. The food was great and the service was attentive. We ordered all varieties of meats and sea food items. You have to come here really hungry to get your money's worth...lol. 

Price is average for a hot pot which was at $25.99 I believe. Price might be alittle higher on the weekends. 

I was stuffed and satisfied when I left :-)
author: Phi N.

description:
Usually I'd pick shabu shabu over hot pot ANY DAY, but The Pot's definitely evens out the playing field a bit.

GREAT selection and can accommodate big groups. I liked that they had items like pumpkin and winter melon...its not your typical menu items for hot pot places in the city. Great selection of veggies and seafood balls outside of the typical meat selection.

Definitely go for the spicy broth! Even though its a bit of a trek from SOMA, you won't be disappointed!

Tip: No Liquor License as of 4/22/2015, so if you're looking to do shots or drink beer, this is not the place!!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Be prepared for the extreme. Pork blood. Intestines. Cow's tendon. This just to name a few.

If you are an adventurous eater, this is the spot to try out. Even for vegetarians, there are good choices, lots of vegetable additions and broths.

However, if you are a carnivore, be prepared to be in heaven. You will get to try some unusual stuff. Beef tongue is a must and as others have said, spicy miso is very very tasty. For only a buck more, they will let you split the pan in half and prepare multiple soups on one burner. Speaking strictly foodwise, this was a 5 star experience. However, once I factor in service, there is more left to be desired. 

Although the waiters seemed to be busy, there was simply not enough of them. We had to make a substantial effort to flag somebody down to bring us a check and given that it was my first time at the restaurant, nobody even bothered to explain how everything works. Such as: how to order, what the soy sauce is for, how long to cook for roughly, or anything else that would have been nice to hear from a waiter. Yes, when I stopped them to ask a question, they would answer, but not happily. Also, No American Express accepted, lame.
author: Alex P.

description:
Service: Fast

Food: quite good, you have 90 minutes to eat so be ready.

Parking: can be tough, carpool or plan ahead. You can take muni N Judah or taxi.

Overall the food is quite good. Nothing amazing but hot pot is hot pot. Service was quick and friendly. Parking is tough. I say carpool if you live far and save gas. 

Not bad for a party of 4-6. Place ain't that big but good enough size. Try it if you enjoy eating hot pot and can find time to park.
author: Michael C.

description:
Pros:
-Only a 15 minute wait on a Saturday night! Woot! I waited over 2 hours before at other places
-They offer up to 3 broth choices, at an additional $1 per extra choice (The first broth is included with your table)
- the broth already comes filled with some ingredients ! (Such as tofu, veggies, meat)
- Cooked food available! Such as potstickers, or "fried dumplings" they like to call it
- Free residential parking 
- Large variety of food choices (from greens, seafood and meat, they even have beef tongue!! )
- The service was excellent!
- You can have "half" orders on almost everything (except the meats)

Cons:
-We were told it doesn't cost extra for having more than one soup base but they do. 

Other notes/tips: 
-Costs around $27 per person
-The spicy miso is extremely hot! I usually eat medium and this soup had me sweattting!
- beef tongue ! Yummy !
author: Jenny N.

description:
Having break out on my face for two days after I ate the spicy pot...sorta over priced compared to other hotpot buffet..taste so so..
but does have a variety of food to choose from guess that's how it gets 4 stars
author: Xia J.

description:
THE POT!! 
This place is like someone you have a crush on and they're sending you mixed signals. 

The food here is good, not great. But they have the biggest selections of foods I've seen at all you can it.  Still memorable

I would give this place a solid 4 but because of the service it knocks a star down. It's a small place, it's obvious, but when it gets really busy here, you'll be waiting a while for your server to return. So my advice will be to order as much as u can the first time. The servers are pretty nice and from my observation they're bilingual too. But they just get overwhelmed. It's like watching human dinner dash. It would be nice if u put in a reservation but we got in with a group of 4 without one.

Overall I'd give place another shot
author: Arron E.

description:
Once again another 5 star rating for our most favorite hot pot place! It continues to be worth the lengthy drive from Roseville (thought we usually do tack on the visit with another purpose in the city! lol). 

Usually we come here at 5PM when it opens to avoid any lengthy lines but this time we were coming after the Cirque du Soleil Amaluna show and could not arrive until 8PM. That being said i was super nervous about an hour long wait and was already yelping for alternatives just in case. When we arrived we saw about 30 people outside and were already getting depressed, but then we went in to put our names on the list and there was a table for 2 available immediately! So... tip for those who are going there, tables for 2 seem easier to get than larger parties - seems like most folks go in large parties and that's where the wait will be!

The price is still consistent $25.99/person on the weekends, with an additional $1/person if you do different broths. The kobe beef was beyond this world, even better than we remember it - we ate 3 or 4 plates of the stuff! We love the fact that there is a HUGE fish ball and dumpling variety too - we got our typical foods, fish balls, dumplings, tofu (the frozen/iced is really yum too!), shrimp, pork, kobe, napa cabbage, and bok choy. We were in a meat mood so that's mostly what we got - the food was again delicious. 

The service was meh but that's to be expected with a packed house. There seems to only be one main waiter with a lot of additional waiter helpers who move food and clean up but one that takes the orders. The main guy was SUPER nice to us - continously apologizing for the service, but we were not at all concerned, it was a great experience.

Of note - all the people in here are Asian, I assume mostly Chinese, that's what I heard being spoken most of the night. My husband is white and he was the only non-Asian in the restaurant - but for those who are not Asian - do not be intimidated - the menu is in English - everyone for the most part speaks some English - and it should not be enough of a hinderance to NOT come here and eat. YUM-MY! :)
author: Vivian P.

description:
This place was just OK for me.  I'd like to give it 2.5 stars but IDK how to do that.  I went here with my wife after a long day of sight seeing in the city.  My wife being from HK, I thought this would be good for her.    We tend more toward seafood and vegetables.  Here is my review of the good, the bad, and the ugly...

Two thumbs up for the selection.  They have a wide selection of fish balls and other seafood...fish paste, crab balls, prawns, etc.  I cant name all the vegetables but they have plenty of green things to choose from.  

Two thumbs up: On the plus, plus side, good selection of beer and the price was not bad. A bottle of Sierra Nevada IPA for $4-something.

One thumb up for quality.  My wife "surprisingly" linked it more than I.  For me, most of the food was a bit too salty, leaving me dry and dehydrated.  (we used mostly the spicy soup base, I don't know he name of it but the one with about a million red cilli peppers).  When we got home, I immediately downed about a gallon of water to bring some sense of normalcy to my mouth.

Neutral:  Overall Price came to just over $100 for the two of us and our daughter.  Thats 2 adult AYCE , 1 child AYCE and 3 beers, tax and tip.  Thats more than I'd like to pay esp for mid tier quality but Ive come accustomed to high prices.  Im sure we can find better quality for about the same price or a little cheaper.

Two thumbs down:  Ambiance, decor and service.  How do I put this?  The place was not very clean.  Some tables were empty that needed clearing (seems like for some time).  About  1/2 the tables have gas burners on top of them (not built into the table).  Does not seem very safe so we asked to be moved.  The building is a bit run down.  Some walls needed to be wiped down apparently from customers days or weeks ago.  Several TVs on walls in the main dining area and one in the little room to the side (where we got moved to), but not especially high quality.   Lastly, our waitress was very nice when she came around but she did not come around very often.  We repeatedly had to ask the waiter from another table to help us.  He was nice too and didn't complain.  

Oh and one of my pet-peeves about restaurants, bars, stores, etc..: This place has NO WI-FI!!  If youre looking to stay connected, you cant.  

Net-net: No particular reason to come back but plenty of reasons to look elsewhere if looking for high quality, high value hotpot.
author: E. T.

description:
I was extremely disappointed with my experience here. I came here with my family for dinner one night and had high hopes based on the reviews and the large group of people waiting. We waited for about 45 minutes to get seated and it was apparent from the moment we sat down that they were understaffed. To say that service was horrible would be an understatement! It takes over 30 minutes for anything to get to the table each time you put in an order and every time, they would get something wrong. They'd either forget something or add random items that we didn't order. After awhile, we gave up and just dealt with it since it took so long for anyone to come over to our table. 

Onto the food: I thought that everything was very average. However, I'm almost certain all their "homemade" items are store bought and frozen. We also got an order of mushrooms that still had chucks of dirt all over them. For the quality and price they charge, I think it'd be cheaper get the same meal at home. 

Lastly, the restaurant opened a side room (probably because they ran out of space) that we were seated in. Unlike the main dining area, the pots in this room were placed on gas stoves on top of the table. Not sure if the restaurant owners aren't aware or if they just don't care, but I'm pretty sure this would be in violation of SF safety codes. 

I was thoroughly disappointed with the Pots and am quite surprised at the positive reviews. If service and food quality aren't important, then I guess this would be the place for an ayce meal.
author: Rhonda T.

description: Best hot pot in town. Newly remodeled and added sauce bar! Quick and fast service and tons of new item on the menu. My favorite soup base is pork bone and spicy. What's best is they have kpop videos!!!
author: Chloe Z.

description:
I give this place a solid 3 for several reasons. First off, the waiters rarely waited on our table. I came here with my friend on a Friday night, and it wasn't too busy, but while the waiters were waiting on the tables on either side of us, they failed to wait on us. Mind you, we were done with our first round of meats and veggies and wanted more, and it took at less. 5-10 minutes until they noticed us just sitting there. Second, most hot pot places add more broth as time goes by, they did not do that for us. Third, the slices of Kobe beef were too thick that it was hard to chew. I like my meats sliced a bit thinner for easier consumption. We waited for our check for a while. Tip: you have to flag them down if you want any type of service. 

Overall, the food was alright. There were a lot of foods to choose from. A lot of variety. There's something for everyone! It's $25 all-you-can-eat, and I'm sure we ate our money's worth. The service could be way better though.
author: Vanessa M.

description:
I give it 3 stars. 3 good stars for the food I enjoyed. NO stars for the ridiculously shitty service we received. 

We had a small group of 4. We were seated in this smaller room which was nice but boy does this place need to practice on what is even decent service.  

We changed our own gas can because these guys were too engrossed in watching the basketball game. Someone from my group had to go to the counter and grab a gas can for us because they wouldn't help us.  I know it gets busy and you have a lot of people to serve but we really did not get any service at all, and that's not okay. We didn't have items come out, out of the 15-20 plates of meat the boys ordered only about 6-8 plates came out, we were constantly asking about food, constantly waiting and not receiving anything. 

No offers to give us water. No explanation as to why our food wasn't coming out. My boyfriend said to cut them some slack since it seemed busy. We walked out of the room to an almost empty restaurant and we still got shitty service? There's no reason to cut slack for inconsideration. 

The food was great. It wasn't my groups favorite in terms of quality but I enjoyed what we ate and the broths. But I couldn't handle how awful the service was. We had to wave them down multiple times to just get water and napkins. 

It's unfortunate how bad the experience with service was. Maybe we'll give it a shot again as we did enjoy the food. But I'd rather go to another hot pot and receive good service than come back here and watch some young servers stare at a TV screen more than do their job unfortunately. :l
author: Jay K.

description:
I came, I ate, and I was conquered.

I didn't realize how much I ate here until I stood up, then I realized I was very, very full. This is a sign for me, and it means the food was too good.
author: Steve C.

description:
This place is now added on one of my go-to hot pot places. I really like the selection of broths they have. You can even choose 3. We got a pork bone, spicy fire, and curry, which I haven't seen at a hot pot place before and it was delicious! 
There are tons of things to throw in the pot and since it is ayce, go crazy. The meat and food didn't look as pretty as at nicer places like little sheep, but it tasted way better. I still think hot pot garden is my favorite but this is a strong contender if I want hot pot in the sunset since hot pot garden is still destroyed on taravel.
author: Peter H.

description: The meats and vegetables were clean and fresh.  We went here for my mother's birthday dinner and had good service and left very full and satisfied.  Will definitely go back again.
author: Austi And London's Mommy N.

description:
I was craving all you can eat hot pot and for that, The Pots does suffice. 
They do things differently here than I've seen before which I was excited to try- you fill out a paper with all the different toppings/additions you want. There are over a hundred choices. My friend and I were excited to try a whole array of veggies and meats but we ended up being underwhelmed. 
The beef was cut too thick and was chewy. The veggie choices were lacking compared to the other categories. With so many choices I wish they had had carrots or bean sprouts. You could get soup dumplings to add to your broth but they were bland. The spicy broth was good but it is just covered in whole red pepper which I had to fish out of the broth just to be able to cook my meat.
The saving grace was our server who was a complete sweetheart. And also the guy who kept refilling our waters. 
Tip: They do not take discover card
author: Rachel M.

description: The menu can be confusing, but this is an all-you-can-eat place. The service was just so-so. Had to wait quite a bit for food and service in general. The food was also just so-so. Not bad but nothing to crave or come back for.
author: Kimberly H.

description: I don't normally leave reviews but I was blown away by the wonderful service my party of 3 was given. The wait for our tables was quite long (about 50 minutes) but it was a Saturday evening and the place was packed when we got there. When we got to our seats the waitress very kindly introduced us to the menu items and pointed out that they can serve 3 broths to one pot at a time, which is impressive as most other hot pot restaurants normally only put out two broths to parties of the same size. We got tbe spicy miso, pork bone, and very curry broths, they all tasted amazing!The menu had what you would expect from a traditional hot pot spot and the sauce table was neatly labeled, organized and kept clean. Our food came very quick after ordering and all the items were delicious. We were surprised to see about 3 waiting staff handling a full house of customers while still giving warm and attentive service. Great food, A1  service, nice atmosphere, 5/5.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Maybe it's because I've lived in the city proper for almost a year now (and it makes me broke AF) or maybe it's because my Dutch boyfriend has an affinity for saving money-- either way, our date nights consist of finding the best affordable AYCE hot pot or korean BBQ place and going to town on all the food. I'm always down for AYCE hot pot because there really aren't many places that serve it in the city. This is one of the cheapest hot pots in the city, and it's pretty delicious. They have tons of room for people, and they're never really that crowded-- unlike my other favourite AYCE hot pot place-- so it's good because we didn't wait for a long time. 

The Pot's is a good, affordable place with lots of soup base and meat choices. They even had lamb in beer, which is something I didn't think happened, but tastes delicious. The slices of here are thick and serve more than 1 person, so you don't need to order more than one serving at a time. They definitely give you enough proportionate to your party (maybe even more-- it was only 2 of us and we were stuffed a good hour and a half in.) This place is AYCE, and you order from a menu and check off what you want. They have a wide variety of soup broths, and you can order up to 3 (!!!) at an additional $1 per person per soup broth (that was confusing, but if you ordered 2 soup broths, and you had 2 people-- you pay $2, get it?) We ordered the fire spicy (which the waitress recommended as their most popular soup broth) and the miso. Even though I shared with my BF, he ended up eating more of the miso and I ended up eating more of the fire spicy. They will refill your broths if they see most of it boiling off lol. They also have drink choices, but they are not on the menu-- so you will have to ask about separate drinks PLUS the prices, since they aren't listed on the menu. 

Overall, I really like The Pot's. My only qualms are that the service can be spotty at times, even when you circled something on the menu: For instance, we circled large noodles and rice on our menu, and while we received EVERYTHING ELSE at the first go-around, we didn't receive our starches. However, when we stopped a waitress to ask for rice, she brought it around immediately. Also, I miss an 'all you can eat sauce' bar, which is prominent at other hotpot places. This place has a house sauce (they don't specify ingredients) which you can customize further with chunks of minced garlic, scallions, jalapenos and other stuff-- but there's just the one sauce. I think I'm still a fan of other places, but I will come to The Pot's when I want fast, simple good hotpot and service at an affordable price point ($26 per person.)
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
It's about $33 (tip and tax included) per person for all-you-can-eat Chinese style hot pot. I love the egg custard dumplings in the pork coconut broth, this is always a must eat when I come here. The fact that they have several different types of broths and dividers to share with friends and family is a plus for me. 

The veggies are fresh and really like the fact that they have seafood. Whereas other places they typically only give you red meat options. 

This place definitely good for vegetarians! You will be so full after eating here, and you will smell like the place after you leave. It gets super steamy in there. I would say that downside to this place is that service isn't always great. You definitely need to wave down a waiter or do something to get their attention when you want a refill on the next order and sometimes they forget to give you what you checked off in menu chart they give you. Other than that, food is awesome.
author: Sarah W.

description: We went here on a weekday and it wasn't busy. The service was great. They where really attentive and hella friendly. The bone broth and the spicy broth were tasty and they weren't too salty or too spicy. They were really fast with bringing out all of our food as well. Overall it was a really awesome hotpot place and I'll definitely come again.
author: Jean Luke C.

description: This place is good. They have a bigger broth selection than ipot, which is also good. It is a little harder to get a table than at ipot. I think they also show some basketball games here, but it is inconsistent. This place has some items ipot does not.
author: Karl K.

description:
3 Stars because I'm disappointed that the meat here kind of sucks. everything is cut way too thin. Even the pork. it rips and tears upon contact/being picked up. it's like paper thin ... and i'm not one to complain about thin slices of meat but .. you'll undestand it when you see it. 

Also service is lacking. It's a small restaurant with a big ol' wall in between two rooms as a separator. Im assuming most days they only fill one room, if even that. I really enjoyed the spicy miso, the curry and the pork bone broths? Especially the curry broth :D

AYCE always makes me happy. Obviously, I've tried just about everything on that menu. GET THE FISH, YOU WONT REGRET IT. for some odd reason, fish, try all the dumplings. I promise, you'll like more than half of them. 


TABLES. tables&kids. If you have a child... whom you know reaches across the table and is at risk of spilling broth on themselves, you might want to wait for a specific table. I noticed some of them have dips / inductions. some have inductions .. built in. and some tables are just tables with a gas stove on top. decide which is best for you. it will put some strain on the workers figuring out where to seat everyone else but .. just to keep you, your kid, and the rest of us safe.. choose wisely. 

PS, get the egg. poach it in the broth. you'll love it.
author: Kimm H.

description:
OMG, why didn't I know about this place earlier?! Some of my coworkers picked this spot for a group dinner. Thankfully we came early because there were people lined up out the door waiting for a seat by 7pm.

This is a hot pot buffet. I was surprised by the quality and sheer variety of the ingredients. We tried basically everyone on the menu and everything was good. I will be taking my parents here.

Remember to put on your most stretchy pair of pants and don't wear anything fancy because you will smell like a hot pot buffet for a while.
author: Alice W.

description:
Not a bad option for AYCE hot pot.  You can easily eat more than $26 worth of food per person which makes this place a good value.  They definitely don't skimp on quality on the meats and vegetables which is a rare for an AYCE place.  The handmade dumplings are surprisingly really good, especially the taro dumplings.  However, the sweet dumplings are not ideal to cook in a pot filled with all other savory items.  I would advise emptying out what's left in your pot and filling it with water to cook the sweeter items as dessert.

Expect to wait at least 20-40 min on the weekends.
author: Michele L.

description:
We got the spicy broth, pork bone and miso. Spicy was definitely favorite--lots of chili peppers resting on the top. Pork bone was also good: it tasted nice and clean, and it complemented all the things we cooked in it pretty well. The miso was a little too smoke-y for me, but still delicious.

I thought it was strange that they offered soup dumplings, shumai, and just other dumpling things as part of the hotpot experience. It tasted delicious, but it doesn't quite absorb the broth as well as the lamb, the bok choy, or mushrooms.

But they have a good selection of things to try. I especially liked the numerous amount of noodles that they had available (ramen, rice noodles, egg noodles), although they didn't have flour ones like I wanted.

Next time I'm coming back I'm getting more lamb, though.
author: Rosy H.

description:
Food (5/5): Spicy miso broth is really flavorful, and the meats, veggies, etc that you can order are all fresh and good quality. We ordered lamb, kobe beef, napa cabbage, udon, soft tofu, chinese donut (you tiao), golden fried dumplings, and egg york dumplings. They don't skimp on the portions at all - each item was a good serving for a party of 4. My friend and I hit a wall and it was a struggle from then on, but hot pot is too good haha.

Service (4/5): Friendly, fast service. A little slow to fill waters but that's probably because I chug water like no other when I eat hot pot haha.

Value (5/5): We didn't take full advantage of the AYCE, but for the variety and quantity they offer, $30 after tax and tip isn't too bad of a splurge!
author: Abby S.

description:
There was a period of my life in which i really didn't like Hot Pot. I don't see the point of going out to a restaurant and cooking when you can cook your own food at home. But as my friends started to drag me to more and more hot pot places i started to like it. I have to say The Pots is pretty high up on my list. Mainly because their soup bases are strong and has enough flavor, were i don't have to use any condiments. 

Pork bone- The base was sweet and a meaty taste to it. There's veggies, like napa cabbage in the base so i think that's made it so sweet, 

Hong Kong Style Satay- It taste exactly as it sounds. However, because it's satay and it's a soup base so it will taste extra "hot"

Tomato Potato Pumpkin - So much as i love the 3 ingredients i actually dislike this soup base the most. I don't know what i was expecting but i think i should've expected it. It was a very tomato-y soup base. It tasted like the tomato soup i would make a home. This was the one soup base where i had to use condiments

Miso base- This was really good, it might be a little on the salty side, but you can actually find tons of seaweed in this broth

Congee- I do not know why this was my favorite soup base of all.  I'll admit, i usually like my congee plain, But it wasn't plain enough where i had to use condiments to eat my meat.  The base had a lot of flavor.  And there was so much rice on the bottom that i didn't even have to order rice to go with my food. By far this is my favorite base

The meat choices here isn't a large as Hot pot Garden, but it was still enough. I loved the beef balls with cheese. You should wait until this is cooled down before you bite into it, because the cheese can come squirting out and into the eyes of your friend right across from you. ... just kidding.. 

The best items on their menu is the fried taro, yam and pumpkin slices.  It's so much better than the ones at hot pot garden.  Because they fried it, it doesn't melt if you try to cook it in your pot. The yam is fried to the point where it taste like a potato chip to me, i don't even place it on the pot, i just eat it when they serve it.  

Because i usually get the congee base, i get the red bean bun. It tasted pretty good when you cook it because since the congee don't have a strong taste it doesn't take away from to the flavor of the red bean bun.  

I would recommend coming here before 7 if you have a huge party, they have private rooms here, so i think they take reservations.  The only think i don't like about this place is that when it gets packed getting out of here can feel like a maze because of all the tables and their trays of ingredients.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Came here with my sister and boyfriend for dinner on a Sunday and got seated within 15 minutes. You order on a paper which they collect. They serve all the items you request for at once, so that they don't confuse it with other tables - which I found that it worked well for them. It's around $30 per person for hot pot, which isn't bad. We had many dishes of kobe beef, wine marinated beef & the beef tongue - which was my favorite. My sister liked the dumplings and they have such a variety. Definitely will return with my mother. Also!! - their spicy miso was not too spicy for me, but enough to give the meal a kick :)

One suggestion: Fix the tvs - they were all fuzzy and pixelated, which made it super hard for me to watch the AMAs that was going on.
author: Amanda C.

description: All you can eat....Just remember that. I wanted fish balls, but they aren't that great for that :(. The dumplings also are not that great. Other than that, very standard place. You need to keep filling out a form and have to ask for a form everytime you order more items, so that was a little annoying. You also have to pester them for orders sometimes because they forget. In terms of the food though, it was pretty standard good hot pot. Nothing really stands out, but by no means is it bad.
author: Victor D.

description:
Not bad, not bad. It's different from Hot Pot Garden in the sense that it's a little smaller and has a little less selection but they do have cheaper AYCE on Tuesdays at 22.95. What made this place stand out are they little dumpling buns that I've never had anywhere else, the exploding egg yolk one was SO yummy, so was the taro. The meat was whatever but it is AYCE. The wine beef was kinda yucky but their homemade fish paste and shrimp paste had us ordering more. The veggies were the same everywhere. 

I'd consider going back just bc of the reasonable price (don't know how much it is on other days besides Tuesday), the service was good for a Chinese restaurant especially since I sent three plates back. The broth was decent and we got the spicy miso and hk satay and they refilled it often. And the sauces were good too without them charging. I'd recommend this place if you are in the neighborhood and don't want to wait two hours for hot pot garden and want to try something different.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
My go-to AYCE hot pot place in San Francisco, this place is your traditional Cantonese hot pot. They have a myriad of soup bases (I like the spicy miso a lot) and a lot of food choices, with the meats available in various marinations. The beef in red wine sauce did get a little too inventive and might not be for everyone though - I recommend getting the regular beef. The lamb is really good as well.

The service is generally pretty good, although they can be a little slow in bringing the food. It's $25/person for it, which seems pretty standard for AYCE in the area. Variety therefore becomes a big differentiator and The Pot definitely stands out to me with the wide selection of food of food offered.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Great place for groups/families. I think the line could be for a while but I like the all you can eat buffet concept for $25.

Good selection of broths and veggies/meats to choose from! The waiters were all very friendly too, very attentive about refilling!
author: linda y.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed The Pot's yet! This is my go-to in the city for AYCE hot pot. The Pot's doesn't boast the fanciest interior or the most convenient setting, but you can't beat it for price and quality in the city. 

I appreciate the authenticity of the mala broth without watering it down to cater to different tastes. I also appreciate the sheer quantity of meats, dumplings, veggies, noodles, and much much more. My favorite broths are the mala, classic pork bone broth, and coconut bone broth; and of course you should do split broths to really get the full experience. I also love their housemade dumplings and fish balls. 

The price has risen of late and it will set you back easily $30 but if you come with an empty stomach and a willingness to eat to your heart's content, it's well worth the money.
author: Kate M.

description:
This is a restaurant in a the middle of a residential neighborhood.  For a hot pot AYCE, it's not bad.  They give generous and decent quality meats (lamb, prime rib, pork, etc.), fresh veggies including enoki mushrooms.

We picked the very spicy soup and it was extremely spicy, too much chili pepper oil and it was packed with real chillies.  Otherwise, the soup was full of flavor.

The service was pretty good and restaurant was clean.  It's cheaper from Sun to Thurs, and it's a good deal for your money.  Suggest that you come early, as this place fills up quickly during peak hours.

Recommended, especially during a cold night!
author: Addie L.

description:
*Torn by the incredible deal and the haughty server!*

All you can eat hot pot: $24.99.  Drinks are extra.  

Select it yourself menu, check off what you like and let the server bring it over for me to cook at my own pace.  Love it.  The owner is very sweet and like family.  

If only for that one server.

Most of them are really sweet.  One in particular is full of attitude.  I have seen her huff at me, roll her eyes at my party.  She is impatient, rude, forgetful and if it were not for everyone else, I probably would never come here again. 

As it is I won't let her cost anything but one star and will still recommend this place.
author: Rimi K.

description:
Really good hot pot. $25 a person for all your can eat with lots of tasty meats, dumplings and veggies. The menu is extensive and you can order a ton of different items in small quantity to try. 

The complaint here is that they only had 2 workers who were overwhelmed. Definitely need to add another person, it's not fun to wait 10-20 mins for each single item of food you want to request.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Been coming here for years now, everything still taste delicious and service is attentive and warm as usual. The broth here simply taste best, better than every other hot pot/ Shabu I've been to. And they offer so many more  hot pot dishes -- i.e. Dumplings, different types of noodles, Asian vegis. 

Thank you pots for being the same all these years, and being so nice to us. 

=)
author: Wes Z.

description:
My girlfriend has been bugging me to try her favorite hotpot place for a while and I finally caved and said I'd go. Besides being expensive, I'm just that usually into eating soggy meat in water, but she assured me that The Pots would be different. I apprehensive agreed to give it a try.

We ordered the spicy miso soup, which I immediately liked better than Little Sheep's spicy soup. Besides being more flavorful, it also didn't have all of the little chili pieces that are really annoying to pick out. It's all-you-can-eat, so we got a little bit of everything. Prime rib, fish balls, veggies, noodles, and more, we tried them all. My favorites were definitely the dumplings and you rarely see them available at most places. They even had some unusual meatballs with cheese in them! Overall, I was actually kind of impressed with The Pots. Expect I spend over $30 per person here so come hungry to maximize your meal.

Hot pot is something that's never really gotten me excited, but The Pots is actually quite good. At $25/person it's not the most affordable dinner in the world but offered a huge selection of items to try. I'm still not the world's biggest hotpot fan, but I would definitely return to The Pots.

Food: 8/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
OMG the spicy miso broth was to die for! It gave everything that extra oomph without being too spicy, which was perfect. 

There were a bunch of sides to choose from. I recommend getting the enoki mushrooms and the bok choy. Definitely fresh. 

Avoid eating too fast, you're gonna burn your tongue like me and my friends did!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
As a lover of almost all Asian food, I am ashamed to say that up until a week ago, I had never had the hot pot experience. I came on a Friday night and came back two nights later because I couldn't stop thinking about it - I HAD to have it again ASAP. It was that good!

Being the first time, ordering was a little intimidating. My sister and I had to kind of guess at how to do it, and asked the waiter a couple of questions (but didn't want to look stupid). So if you're a hot pot novice like I was, and ready to try something new and amazing, here's what to expect...

(For anyone who has had hot pot before, this will sound redundant and lame.)

You get a menu, and just mark off everything you want from each category. Careful though, because you aren't supposed to order more than you can eat - they say they will charge you for leftovers. Assuming you come in a party of two, you each choose a broth (I had the preserved egg and cilantro - delish, and my sister had the spicy miso - also great), and then just mark off everything on the menu that you want, from noodles to seafood to dumplings to vegetables. 

I'd recommend starting with one or two noodle orders to share, since you can get more if you don't have enough. There are so many other things to fill up on! There are about 6-8 different types - thin rice noodles, wide rice noodles, soba, egg...

As far as seafood goes, it's like paradise: there are all kinds of dumplings, filled with everything from shredded crab and spinach, to shrimp, to lobster... They come out uncooked, so you need to put them into the broth for a minute or two (might seem obvious, but I when I got them, I thought maybe they were already ready and were just to be eaten as a side to the soup). There are mussels, prawns, lobster balls...It felt too good to be true. Side note - some of the dumplings just say "spinach," or some other vegetable, but be aware that ALL of the dumpling and wonton options have seafood or meat in them, even if it's not listed. So if you're allergic, avoid them.

There's a huge list of vegetables - bok choy, eggplant, multiple types of mushrooms / fungus (we tried them all - they were all SO good), yam, taro, spinach, bamboo, soft tofu, fried tofu, radish, lettuce. Probably some I'm forgetting too!

Another little thing I was unsure about was where to put the food once I'd dipped it in the pot...I was wondering why they didn't bring us little bowls. But under the ginger soy sauce, there's a little plate to use :).

Lastly - it's not on the menu, but they do serve beer, so you'll have to ask.

For $25 each, we left so satisfied and full - can't wait to go back!
author: Jessica C.

description:
found this place because of all the great reviews on yelp and from friends but i was pretty disappointed. The place was pretty busy but understandable because it was a Saturday night. What I didn't understand was why they squeezed a party for 6 at such a small table and made us wait a little longer when they next people the sat was a party of 4 and a party for 2 at tables that could have been combined. We were there first. Instead of being seated at a more spacious setting, we were blocking walk ways because a side table was added to a table of 4. We were just in everyone's way and made the experience not memorable. The food also took awhile to come and some food we order didn't even come. It was busy so i can understand the customer service but I was already upset with the seating arrangements and hungry from the extra wait. 

The food was pretty decent. Tried the bone soup base and the fire spicy. The meat was a decent cut. The first few plates were DELISH then as we started ordering more and more the meat just got fattier and fattier. That was disappointing. I did like that they had a huge variety. They even had congee and chinese donut! Really random in my opinion but I love that stuff so can't complain. I may go again maybe on a day where it will be less busy.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Found a cockroach floating in my broth. 

After waiting half an hour to be seated even though there were open tables.

Disgusting.
author: Diana P.

description: Very good, solid AYCE hot pot with a good wide selection.  Beware the spicy fire soup base though!! I always thought I ate very spicy but this soup almost ruined my experience. It was delicious, but waaaay too spicy. My stomach hurt for next couple days after due to the intense spiciness... I'm still debating if the pain was worth it. :)
author: Bella C.

description: We got the pork bone soup, spicy, and spicy miso. the meat was tender. The vegetables where fresh. We also ordered hot sake and a Sapporo. The service was great and everything tastes good. I highly recommend going here if you need a hot pot fix.
author: Michelle P.

description:
I've always liked this place but had to minus one star from our previous experience.  I can't believed we were charged $50 for 2 pitchers of beer.  What made it crazier was that the pitchers were different sizes! ....... speechless

And minus another star for the slow service.  I think they just need more staff sometimes.

Other than that, I love the food.  Whenever I seem to be in San Francisco, it's always cold and hot soup is always the answer.  Who can turn down AYCE hot pot.  There's plenty on condiments to be creative with your own personalized dipping sauce.  Vegetable are always fresh and I like my meat sliced thinly for quick cooking.  There's plenty of meatball and noodle variety to choose from.  The menu has something for everyone.
author: Stacy O.

description:
I'm definitely a fan of this place! I love their dipping sauce with tons of garlic, chili, cilantro, and green onions. For me, the sauce really makes everything else enjoyable. My favorite item on the menu would have to be the shrimp paste. It's not the shrimp paste you're thinking... it's basically a lump of ground shrimp and you scoop it into chunks to throw into your broth. It's delicious!! We both love tendon too.. but the ones here are too thin and small unlike Little Sheeps, which are big! It's AYCE so we pretty much stuff ourselves silly: dumplings, beef, lamb, veggies, shrimp, tofu, etc... I love Enoki mushrooms.. (just sharing). This is my favorite hot pot in the city :) 

The only complaint would be that the service is slow. There is never more than 2 servers working at a time.. and even asking for the check takes a while. One more server would make a difference!!!!
author: Meemee T.

description: So many hot pot places popping up in the city now days, I've tried tons of them, but I keep coming back here for some real hot pot from time to time. Their pork bone coconut broth is out of this world and the the large variety of dishes I can order is also a big plus. Their prunella tea is also made in house and taste just right. Make sure you order it!
author: Kev P.

description: This plsce is closed. I called them on Saturday 3/24,no one picked up. And I popped by  just now,the restaurant was closed.
author: Mallorie H.

description:
I was here with my family on Chinese New Year day . Before I think there service was just ok. Maybe there always busy.  But that nite was great . Allot better now . And I love there beef and hand make meat balls & dumplings. Special the egg yolk one. So yummy and sweet.  Before I always go boiling point. For $18 just one pot.  I rather paid $26 for all you can eat. 

Highly recommend this place .
author: Liu J.

description:
Sunday afternoon I made a reservation for 6 at the pots for 6pm and good thing that I did, too! This place gets packed!

Since hotpot is such a smattering of things this review will also be a smattering of pros and cons. 

Pros: 
- Variety! So many different things to try and all for a set price. Ayce hot pot is the only way to go. 
- Price! Similar to above point, everything is on the table (literally and figuratively) for a good price. 
- Quantity! Omg one order of pork intestine was enough to feed a person for a meal. 
- Quality! Self explanatory

Neutral factors: 
- The cold. Sitting by the open door kinda sucks cuz it's cold. But it's hotpot so it gets real hot real fast. All in all evens out. 
- The broths. Pretty standard. Nothing too stand out. Expect to eat a lot of sichuan peppercorns if you order the hot and spicy one. I love those little nubs tho. The dried scallop and whatnot one is pretty fishy. 

Cons:
- Service. I get that they're busy but do I really have to ask for something three times before I get it? Didn't get my sauce until halfway thru my meal. 
- Sauce. That weird vinegary soy sauce thing was weird. Ask for some "sacha" or chinese bbq & sesame paste from the beginning! 

Overall the pros outweigh the cons. If only it were closer I would go more often and try different soup bases and order my sauce from the get go.
author: Kat T.

description:
I ate so much last night I had to sleep sitting up! AYCE has been adding inches to my waistline but The Pot's made every bite worth it. 

I like The Pot's because of their large selection of shabu additions. IMO, the must-gets include:

-spicy broth
-lots of premium beef and lamb
-egg yolk and taro bun
-fish filets
-black fungus 
-enoki mushrooms
-tong-ah vegetable
-lots of meatballs and dumplings

The price is very reasonable, lots of big tables and good selection of drinks although no alcoholic beverages available. 

The drawback is that service is poor. We had to wave our hands shamelessly to get more water, more broth added to our pot, and also to order more things. I'm pretty sure every time I've come here, they've messed up on our order or forgot to give us something we ordered but since it's AYCE, it's not a big deal since you can always order more. The waiters here work their butts off to keep everyone happy but unfortunately, they can't always attend to everyone all the time. 

There are so many AYCE shabu places in the city but few AYCE hot pot places so although service is bad, I still appreciate the presence of The Pot's in outer sunset!
author: Gloria C.

description:
Expect the service to be pretty slow, and you have to be proactive about getting their attention. Other than that, the food was very good quality and up to expectations. I'd highly recommend the beef prime rib and the homemade balls. For the soups, we got the spicy miso and pork bone broth. The spicy miso was very good, but definitely got really spicy by the end. The pork bone wasn't very flavorful -- just tasted like salted water, but was a nice balance to the spicy miso. 

We didn't order all you can eat, and it came out to $27 per person after tip and tax. Note that there is a separate menu for non-AYCE that you have to specifically request. We ordered three plates of meat, a couple plates of seafood, and other smaller dishes. Pretty stuffed by the end, but still had room for some dessert afterwards in the area.

The sauce provided was like a sweetened soy sauce (but not as salty as soy sauce). You can add your own "toppings" like fresh garlic, scallions, cilantro, and chili. They pre-pour the sauce for you into a bowl though, and I thought there was a bit too much sauce, so I could barely taste the garlic that I tossed in. 

The complimentary tea was pretty good quality with a nice nutty flavor to it.
author: Audrey L.

description: I LOVE HOT POT.  But this place was meh for 35 dollars per person after tax and 18% gratuity we were charged for having a party of 9. My friends were smart to call for a reservation beforehand. The xiao long bao, lobster balls, fried taro, beef ball with cheese was so disgusting. The only thing that i liked about this place was how fresh the veggies and meat were. As for the service, i guess they did their job of bringing the things we ordered and cleaning the tables after we were done eating but nothing more than that. I heard this was one of the better places in SF for Chinese food, good thing i live in LA.
author: Connie C.

description:
$24.99 per person might seem a tad steep, but recall that you're getting all that you can eat (all you want to eat?) and the selection of items is humorously long. At one point during dinner, I found myself reading aloud the different types of dumplings, and there were at least twenty: Lobster balls, beef balls with cheese stuffing (no one allowed me to get these), cuttlefish balls, etc. 

The choice of broth is important here, and we waffled for a while over coconut pork bone versus Hong Kong satay, ultimately settling on the former. You can also pay an extra $1 per person to get two or three types of broth. 

The paper-thin meats for hot pot are well-done here and very fresh. We liked everything we got, but you definitely have to try the beer marinated in beer, and the lamb marinated in wine. I might have mixed up my protein and alcohols, but you'll know which menu items. Shrimp and fish is also great here, with big plump filets of tilapia. 

There is even dessert you cook in your hot pot, so remember to snag some taro buns and salty egg custard buns. These are more dumplings than buns and you'll boil them in the broth until they're just about to eject their tasty goo (I'm so good at this food-writing bit).

My only complaint may be that there is no separate chopstick provided for handling raw meats, and it'd be great to have an extra bowl to hold mussel and shrimp shells. 

Not as far in the Sunset as you'd think, and it's right on the N line, so when SF is especially foggy, come out and get your hot pot on!
author: Kevin L.

description: All you can eat hot pot! We did not realize that until after sitting down with a black and white menu without price beside each item. For around $26 (before tax/tip), the variety was worth it. Many soup base choices, we got spicy miso and tomato potato pumpkin. Spicy miso was about medium hot (I'm sure they have spicier options), and I thought the tomato potato pumpkin soup base was pretty unique. Big menu they had, we got a bunch of different meat, seafood, veggie, and even dessert items. Would totally come back next time, with empty stomach.
author: Jaclyn C.

description: Best hot pot in SF.  Food is very fresh.  Major complaint is the wait is too long and I cannot wait if I want to bring my elderly parents.  Although they take reservations, I have never been able to get through to put my name on the list.  Every time I call, I get the answering machine and message that the VM is full.  That is why I have not been back for half a year and hesitant to try again.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
Mmmm hot pot! Best for cold days when you're angry and you need to get happy with some hot hot food. I decided to try this place with my friend yesterday and we weren't disappointed at all. The service was a little slow at first, but it's alright. I'll let it slide only because I worked at a Shabu restaurant briefly and it sucked... ANYWAYS!!

We opted for the fire spicy broth and the pork bone broth. The fire spicy was full of dried chilis and Chinese spices - BOMB!! but I was sweating (it was that spicy). The pork bone broth had some pork bones in it so you know it's the real deal. It was really flavorful, but I caught myself eating from the fire spicy more. All the sides were great and they weren't out of anything which was a bonus. My only complaint was that the red bean and yolk bean bun was frozen... so we had to cook it in the broth. Kinda weird to have a dessert bun cooked in such a meaty and savory broth. We had to dunk them in our water cups before we ate it... 

All in all, I will return soon when I have another craving. Their portions are smaller and vary depending on group size.. which allows you to order more of everything ;)
author: Kenitha Y.

description:
I love all you can eat hot pot.  At The Pot's they have all you can eat for $24.99 (Mon-Thurs) and $25.99 (Fri-Sun).  We chose two different hot pot bases: Fire Spicy and Very Curry and have tried the following items from the menu
 
Meats:
Kobe Beef - not like the kobe beef you get a shabu places, but this was pretty decent kobe beef
Beef Tendon Ball - this was really good
Preserved Vegetable Meat Ball - I'd skip this
Luncheon Meat - this is pretty much spam, so if you like spam get it
Veggies:
Bok Choy
Tong Ho
Ice Tofu - good because it becomes spongey and soaks up the broth
Deep Fried Tofu - good and soaks up the broth
Fried Yam Slice - surprisingly good in hotpot, since it's fried you can eat it by itself too
Enoki Mushroom
Bamboo Shoot
Chinese Donut - this was so good dipped in the "Very Curry" soup base
 
All of the above was really good and I thought enjoyed the meal, but one thing that stood out to me which I found interested was the "Hot Pot Egg Yolk Bun".  At first I thought it was just a dessert item, like a custard bun.  But actually it was a frozen small, round, dumpling like thing that you cook in your hot pot.  I found the concept of cooking a sweet item in the hot and spice soup base very odd, but once I tried it it was actually very very good.  I would recommend people to try this.
author: Mia N.

description:
wow i totally missed the memo on the fact that this place is AYCE. the bf and i came early on a sunday evening because 1) we were craving hot pot, 2) it was easier to get here on our way back from south bay than anywhere else in the city, 3) there's plentiful free street parking, and 4) it was cold outside.

it didn't immediately strike us as weird that there were no prices on the menu, and we ordered as we normally would have. when the dishes came out in much smaller portions than we expected, that's when we finally caught on that it was AYCE. an overzealous second round of ordering ensued, leading to stomachaches for the both of us from overeating, and unfortunately lots of leftover food on the table. next time, knowing now that it's an AYCE hot pot joint, we'll come with a better plan of attack.

i'm honestly not a fan of AYCE anything because i feel like i can never get my money's worth (unless you're STARVING, but even then....), and it's not that fun/interesting unless you go with a large group of people.

that being said, i give the pot's 4 stars because of its SPICY SOUP BASE and its KOBE BEEF (mmmm marbling). everything else is just average hot pot fare in my opinion.

service is good though with soup refills, water refills, sauce refills, etc. so that's a nice-to-have as well.
author: Yiwen S.

description:
This was my first hot pot at San Fran so nonetheless, I was pretty skeptical cause for me, Asian foods are less flavorful here (perhaps cause some groups can't handle the spice? Lol). 

Anyways, we had double soup: the pork broth and the spicy soup that was recommended by other reviewers. 
Normally, I love drinking the soup at other hot pot places. Here, I just avoided it and cooked my meat and veggies. Pork broth was just decent and spicy broth tasted like nothing with pepper oil. At least it was spicy lol. 

What I recommend: kobe beef, shrimp, and fish balls. Kobe beef is amazing. Get it a lot! Fish balls were juicy and nice. Shrimp is shrimp. 

What I recommend u avoid: fish cake, tongue, deep fried tofu, cabbage(unless u like eating a whole iceberg cabbage), and lobster ball. We were recommended to get the ox tongue(?) by the waitress and it tasted so gross lool. I didn't know how to eat it. I would normally be mad at the waitress but she was so nice, I can't. 

Seriously, don't get fish cake. I think there was two diff kinds; just play it safe and don't get either. It's dried sponge or some shit idk I didn't feel like I was eating food lol. 
Lobster ball tasted like imitation crab meat. Deep fried tofu is literally tempura. 

They charge u extra if u leave a lot of food behind. Thankfully, me and my bf hid the fish cakes and tempura shit in the soup and napkins. 

Honestly, for $25 per person and unlimited Kobe beef, this place isn't that bad. I'd come back here again one day if I was nearby. Emphasis on the "If".
author: Michelle K.

description:
AYCE. Yummy!!!

1 star off for being racist (I brought my black friend to this place and they did NOT treat us well).
author: Betty T.

description:
I think I may be dead as I write this, because I ate so much that I may have gone blind. Or dead. I'm not sure. Basically, this was my first hot pot experience ever, and I clearly had no idea what I was getting into.

If you're a big eater, this place is absolutely for you. If you're not, then ~$30 may not want to be the amount you spend for AYCE hot pot. I still thoroughly enjoyed myself, despite not realizing how full I was. Really, you can't blame anyone but yourself about the way you cook things. The dumplings were pretty good. The ramen noodles were really tasty. The spicy miso was spicy and tasty. There were a lot of times during this meal where I thought, "If only I could get a simple bowl of ramen noodles and dumplings, that would be good. But...but somehow, they keep bringing me food..."

So. Food: good. Service: pretty quick. Cleanliness: good. Ambiance: plain enough for you to stare listlessly out into space when you realize you have no more room in your stomach, but still continue eating anyway.

If you want hot pot, get there early, because voracious eaters know that they can stay there for as long as they want. I saw people waiting outside for some time, so I'm glad I went with some hot pot veterans who knew what was up.

That said, this was indeed my first hot pot experience. I enjoyed myself. I may not go back because hot pot is not my thing. I also don't know much about the quality of the food. Everyone else was like, yeah, NOMZ, but I was like, "yeah, food, cool", and nothing in particular to write home about except the ramen noodles, which I am unsure were actually ramen noodles.
author: Robbin A.

description: If your ever in the neighborhood and want some comfort food the pots is the place to be, the ambiance is cute and a relaxing surrounding to be with a great group of friends, the soups base is full of flavor, my favorite is the pork bone soup and the cilantro with preserved egg, the food is fresh and the selections are great. The price is a steal as it's 27.99 ALL YOU CAN EAT, be prepared to come with an empty stomach, and if you like some alcohol it's for all you can drink and eat for 40.99. I will definitely be back.
author: Fanny F.

description: The temperature was so cold the last few nights = it's a good night for hot pot...It is located at a  good location.  Parking was good.  No wait when we got here at 7 on a week night, unsure of weekends.  I like their special handmade dumplings.
author: Han L.

description:
not worth it, my first time coming here got seated right away on a Wednesday night. service sucked took for ever to receive our food.
some of the meats arrived with ice still stuck to the meat. u can tell it's not fresh.  overly priced. for $24.99 thinking it would be cheap. they charge an additional $1 person for broth. $3.50 for fountain drink soda (coke). bill came up to $60+ for two not including gratuity.
author: Janie S.

description:
Inexpensive AYCE hot pot! I think I paid $25 when I came here, and they have all sorts of things on their menu. This is some of what I remember ordering:
-beer-marinated lamb
-more lamb
-kobe beef
-more beef
-udon/other noodles
-different dumplings, meatballs, and fishballs
-tofu
-enoki mushrooms
-vegetables/spinach/cabbage
-taro and egg custard buns (MY FAVORITE! Definitely order these and put them in at the end because it tastes kind of like the Chinese glutinous balls stuffed with sweet filling)

Only gave this three stars because they have pretty terrible service. They lost our menu so we waited 30 minutes for our food to come out, but we found out later that they somehow threw it away so we had to reorder. Also, it took us about 1.5 hours to get seated, and another 30 minutes to get our food going. I think they only have about 2 waiters for this entire restaurant so come early or be prepared to wait!
author: Jeanette S.

description: Came here for the first time the other night and was pretty disappointed. The quality of the ingredients was good but the two broths we tried (curry and pork bone) were pretty bland. Not enough flavor to make any of the meats taste like anything. The service left a lot to be desired as well. Pretty underwhelming experience, won't be returning.
author: Hannah R.

description: Loved this place BEFORE the remodel and now it's top notch! Great food, excellent service. Try the coconut curry broth with fish filets... my favorite!
author: Erin L.

description:
Lacking service for large groups.
Beer comes from a can. Just FYI. It's also really expensive.

Dirty vibe all around like "how clean is this dish I'm using?" or "do they keep their meat products separate from their vegetable products?"--probably...but I just did not feel like eating when I was here...and it's an all you can eat hot pot (for two hours) joint.


Lamb tasted pretty good so I'll give them that, but we hardly had any food given their poor service. Or ya know what I mean, because of the slow service we got full faster. First world problems I know...Anyway, I'll give it to them that they were probably understaffed, but at $35/head, I'm not returning. Noooope, just nope.
author: Sarah W.

description:
My favorite hot pot place! 

The spicy broth is indeed the spiciest in SF in my opinion and they have a huge selection of foods

The ingredients are always fresh when I'm here and they have the traditional Chinese herbal drinks!

Feels like I'm in Hong Kong again whenever I come.

Another plus is there's a karaoke room you can reserve. So it's great to have gatherings. 

All you can eat for about $25.... Not bad at all
author: Josie L.

description: Been here couple of times but this time the service is worst. It took one of the servers 3 minutes to acknowledge me. I have to write my name down on the waiting list. People who come after me are already seated. The waiters are lost on either call out names or seat people yelling out the number of their party.
author: Serena L.

description:
I'm actually torn between a 3.5 and a 4 but giving this place a 4 because they take reservations. We went here last night for CNY dinner and were seated a little bit after our reservation time. The menu is pretty extensive. You have a lot of soup base choices as well as the other meats, veggies, dumplings, etc. The items are not as fresh as say Hot Pot Garden but still pretty good. I feel like they def had more meat choices such as pork stomach, tripe, etc. They also had some other stuff such as the asian donuts and pork blood. The only reason that i was considering docking off .5 stars is because they didn't always bring out everything that we marked. I swear I asked for the salty egg yolk dumplings twice and it never came out. Also they weren't quite as attentive with the water so it did burn at the end. Place is smaller as well with two random rooms. 

Overall though good place and more sauces too. If you did need service, they did come quickly after being flagged down. Will be back.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
Eh...I'd steer clear of The Pot's, as there are way better shabu or hot pot places out there. #justsayin

We had a party of six, so we were given the option to choose four different broths. We went with the pork bone broth and dry scallop winter melon chicken feet mushroom broth (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-pots-san-francisco?select=oGyYPKoH1x-Dai0Q4r7wSQ#oGyYPKoH1x-Dai0Q4r7wSQ) and the spicy miso and hong kong style satay (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-pots-san-francisco?select=_JfBogmmKVemmkU9A2SV0Q#_JfBogmmKVemmkU9A2SV0Q). I like that they had a large variety of broths to choose from, but other than that, there was nothing to write home about. The broths were alright at best and they did not have a good selection of vegetables and mushrooms to choose from. Many, if not all, of the meats and dumplings were previously-frozen too. The fact that our waitress seemed annoyed that we asked for more sauce, made it even more of a disappointing experience. NEEEXT!
author: Lien T.

description:
First...review...ever. I don't care for hot pot places, mainly because you pay to cook your own food and typically, the broth isn't flavorful enough. The latter isn't an issue here. I went with my girlfriend and a good friend of mine and we had a split pot with two broths: the coconut beef bone broth and spicy MaLa broth. I loved the coconut beef bone broth...light, yet hearty! And the spicy MaLa broth wasn't overwhelmingly hot, and packed with flavorful spices. I kind of stay away from gluten these days (not sure if the broth has gluten in it...I assumed no) and the meats cooked in the broth were so flavorful that there were really no need to use soy sauce, which is a good thing since soy sauce has gluten in it. The quality and variety of meat was good, ranging from spam ham (dirty pleasure) to thin sliced kobe/wagyu beef. You get get rice noodles, ramen and your typical asian carbs as well. They also had these interesting egg yolk/custard balls wrapped in rice paper too. I say interesting because you cook it in a savory broth so if you're into sweet and salty...the egg yolk/custard balls will be...interesting in a good way. Not bad for an All You Can Eat joint. I ate to my hearts content. At $24.99/person, the price was reasonable. 

The food and experience were definitely 4 stars.

But I give this place 5 stars because my girlfriend and good friend got greedy and ordered WAAAAY...too much food and couldn't finish. We were scared that the owner would charge us for left overs, but he let us off the hook with a very stern warning. And it was fair. 

You'll have a good time and won't leave hungry. Just don't order more than you can eat.
author: Kasey C.

description:
Food + Taste : Five stars! The meat was good quality for AYCE hot pot. All the ingredients were fresh and there was a large variety in their menu. Only thing that could make it better is if there was a build-your-own sauce bar :D 

Price: A little bit expensive but for the quality, you get what you pay for. 

Parking: Welcome to SF, where parking sucks! Tips for future goers: carpool or take the bus there.

Service: This is the part where I had to take off two stars. 

1)We had made a reservation for a party of 10 and when we came in, they split our table up into two separate tables. Most restaurants for parties 6 and up, there is a surcharge of 18% tip, which is reasonable. We were also charged 18% tip even though they split up our party.

2)Also, keep track of what you mark on the menus because we have had items marked but never came out. During our second round, we marked similar items, and then finally the server came out to tell us they were out of those items. Way to not tell us earlier!

3) We were charged for having two soup bases, when we only had one. It was a minor mistake and the staff corrected it after I told them about it. 

To reiterate, the food was great, but there is room for improvement for the service.
author: Jessica C.

description: Love this place, and it's so close to my house. The food is really good and fresh, and the staff is really nice and helpful. My friends and I came right after they opened which was perfect timing before the rush.
author: Cat E.

description:
I was here on Monday nite. Full house but no need to wait. Nice. they have remodel. and they said new tables will be coming.

Surprisingly great hot pot.  Most hot pot places seem to run by an Asian mantra of profits first, food second.  The Pot's has clearly focused on delivering freshly made, delicious and reasonably priced "fire pot" fair w/ great aplomb and success.  

As a shab snob myself, I was happy to find high grade cuts of meats coupled with mushroom-stuffed dumplings, fresh vegetables and even "ni wong bao" (custard filled dumplings) and they have allot of hand made meat balls. and dumplings. the most we all like there hand made fish & shrimp paste.(the best)

Service was attentive and prompt, with all you can eat items arriving even before we had finished the last plate.  It was as if they had eyes in the sky delivering hot pot goodness on demand.

Will definitely come back here on a cold day.(they been improving)
author: Erica T.

description:
Decided to give this AYCE hotpot place a try. This spot is packed right when we got there but soon enough we were seated right after a table is cleared. 

We got the fire spicy which is their spiciest soup base. Yes, it was VERY spicy. You can also add $1 to each person to get double soup base which we didn't get. We ordered the Lamb, Beef, fish?, noodles, assorted veges, dumplings, and some fishballs. I am not a big fan of lamb, and fishballs but everything else was just right. The beef is thinly sliced to perfection, but not marbleized. Veges were as fresh as they could be. Dumplings were okay, but nothing to be excited about. 

Service on the other hand was okay. We were seated but not served. Menu and water came after 10 minutes. The "ingredients add-on basket" for the sauce was never given or asked if we need/want them. We had to ask two different server to get the basket. There were too many tables and only 3 servers so service was quite slow and inattentive. If you want better service, go early!
author: Maria H.

description:
The first thing I noticed, as I was about to walk in, were the fogged up windows! They should definitely keep the door open. 

Since we had a party of 8, we made a reservation. I believe parties of 6 or more can make reservations. The soup base was alright. I didn't find it to be particularly tasty or amazing. I love spicy stuff, but the spicy broth did not have that kick that I usually like. However, the spicy broth did give the food more flavor than the non-spicy broths. There's a lot to choose from in terms of meats, fish balls (some even have cheese in it!), mushrooms, and vegetables. 

Service was lacking here. The whole time I was there, the servers never checked up on us. 

Parking is street parking here. It was very difficult.
author: Judy L.

description:
Great deal if you want an interactive experience with your group, hot broth (regular pork bone variety or the one with chili oils, star anise, and spices), and all sortsa dippables (meats, veggies, fungi, fried donut), The Pot's is the spot.

Really great deal for the price ($23 or so, +/- tax, tip, $29). My favorites: red wine marinated beef, beef, fish, mushrooms, sliced taro, sliced sweet potato, chinese fried donut, fish paste, dumplings, etc. 

I love the amount of garlic they give you for your vinegar/soy sauce dipping bowl.

I was hurting at the end, but that's because I'm greedy.
author: Grace M.

description:
This may be my favorite hotpot in the Bay Area. So good. 

Super friendly staff and affordable all you can eat. 

What we ordered: 
Hong Kong style satay broth was delicious as was the the spicy broth. The pork broth was plain, we mostly ate the other two. 

Kobe beef ( so so good )
Lamb (delicious) 
Beef in wine (we preferred the Kobe beef over this, but it had really nice flavor profiles) 
Chicken dumplings 
Shrimp dumplings 
Beef meatballs 
White mushrooms (yum) 
Cabbage 
Bok Choy
Tofu 

Everything was delicious and fresh!
author: K D.

description:
Overall Impression: This place should take and enhance the slogan for Arby's... We have the meats, and it's so freaking delicious!

Cost: It costs 26 per person on the weekends but ultimately ends up around 35 per person after tax/tip.

Taste: The Kobe beef and lamb plates were on point. We would recommend choosing a spicy broth to add some additional flavor to the meats. My personal favorite was the deep fried tofu, while my girlfriend enjoyed the enoki mushrooms. We also got udon noodles, but the noodles were pretty thick, so next time we'll probably try a thinner ramen. 

Customer Service: I thought our waiter visited frequently and was very polite. Our pot ran out of gas and he replaced it promptly.

Ambience/Atmosphere: We were placed in a small extension room that was painted baby blue. It was kind of off putting, but bearable.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Definitely my favorite hotpot place in the city. Love the spicy and the pork bone soup bases. I usually get half and half of each.

The variety of vegetables and meats is decent; although there are places with better selections. 

So why 5 stars and not 4 .... Well, overall, it's the best hotpot experience.
author: Ankur V.

description: Fantastic experience. Tons of food (meats & vegetables) options.
author: Jonas C.

description:
Heard many great things about this place, but was thoroughly disappointed after giving them the benefit of the doubt. 

Before coming, I was very excited that this was the restaurant we'll be going to since everyone raves about their spicy broth and the overall quality of their meat which held true for the most part. However, the deal breaker between the two stars I'm giving them and a higher rating was the poor service we received. It's understandable that with a high volume of customers coming in it may get stressful, but we were given quite a lot of sass everytime we requested something... not because we're trying to be "that table," but rather because they forgot it from the beginning.
