The service was also slow for AYCE, and we for sure were not able to get our money's worth because we didn't even get most of the items we requested on the paper. We asked four times as a reminder and put it on our paper twice for one item and it never came out... not even when we left. Perhaps they ought to have a better system for this to keep their hungry customers satisfied with what they actually want to eat.
author: Brian T.

description:
Great place for group dinners on cold SF nights.  Vast amounts of hot pot ingredients, including all kinda of meats (beef and lamb are my favorites), seafood, vegetables, tofu, mushrooms, and noodles to name just a few add ins.  The Pots makes their own fish, shrimp, cuttlefish, meat and pork balls, as well as homemade shrimp wontons and other dumplings.  Get the half pork bone broth and half spicy broth!  

They only serve all you can eat Friday-Sunday, but not a bad price such high quality ingredients at $25-ish per person.
author: Wendy S.

description:
First off, I been to this place twice. I had a great experience as I did enjoy their food. Their quality is a bit above average. 

I am currently writing this review as we order because I am something interesting to report. I was going to enter this place expecting to eat some good food and write a awesome review. But it has taken a unfortunate turn. My smile instantly turn to a frown. 

The first thing I did was go to the bathroom to cleanse my hand of any bacterial filth. As I reached for the soap... I pumped once pumped twice and realized the soap bag was empty after inspecting the dispenser.  

Being a germaphobe, this was very upsetting. I quickly flagged down a waiter and inform them of this... sanitary violation. Note that the restaurant was pretty empty when we came in and the waiters were idly standing by with nothing to do. 

Second red flag came in the secret sauce. A restaurants worst nightmare ; we have identified a bug in the soy sauce bowl. So we understand maybe this was one case in a million. We immediately signal the waiter and let him know this needs to be replaced.

Being utterly disgusted by the sanitary of this place makes me questions what these buffoon of a staff is doing all day. What is more disgusting is I've also continued to eat despite all these events. So I am going to give it a 3.5
author: Baldwin W.

description:
First time coming to The Pot's, what an amazing hot pot experience! All you can eat for only $22.99!

We got a combination hot pot with spicy miso and coconut pork bone. I recommend the spicy miso broth, it was definitely the table favorite. I particularly enjoyed the pork dumplings and prime rib slice. I can also recommend that you finish eating all of your meats and other items and then try cooking some noodles in the broth to finish off the hot pot. This was a great way to bring dinner to a close and the noodles were really quite delicious.

Service was really great. As recommended by our waitress, the taro and egg yolk dumplings are a MUST HAVE for dessert!! Will definitely be back.
author: Tim K.

description:
Pros:
- Save $3 if you come here Sunday - Thursday, $22.99 AYCE vs $24.99 AYCE
- Amazing homemade dumplings (must order)
- Red bean, Taro, and Egg Yolk dumplings are sweet dessert 
- Taro Chips
- Different broth options and you can split the pot 2 or 3 ways
- Large variety of items and all very fresh

Cons:
- Service is a little slow, granted I went on a Tuesday night when they weren't at max staff
author: Emily Y.

description: Good, delicious, amazing, cozy, warm, food, spicy, beef, udon, service , quality, tea, friendly, munchies, hot, cold weather food, will come back again.
author: Saan S.

description: Went to the city for dinner n ended up at the pots.  I expected to get normal service and nothing to brag about soup.  OMG!!!  Service was way above what I expected and food was excellent.  My husband and I were asked if it was our first visit, which it was and we were given instructions.  Everything from how to order, what went well with what, what to place in the broth 1st, 2nd etc.  We enjoyed both the spicy meso and pork bone broth.  I'm not a spicy person but the meso was exceptional.  I'd visit The Pot's any day.
author: Toblessedtobestressed G.

description:
The Pot's has been here for a while. They seem to have really upgraded their decor. It used to be some cheap tables and chairs in the restaurant, but now it's filled with nice looking chairs and tables. Some tables have an electric stove top and some use the old fashion butane stoves.

== Food ==

A lot of different soup bases to choose from ranging from traditional clear water to spicy miso. There's soups such as pork bone and many other traditional hot pot soups.

There's a lot variety of meats and fish to choose from. About anything you can imagine would be there. Imitation crab, fish balls, beef balls, beef slices, etc.

The veggie selection also was very good. Enoki mushrooms, napa cabbage, many variety of tofu, etc.

== Service ==

Even though I made reservations at 7 pm. I had to wait 15 minutes for a waiter to come to the front where they had a sign that said "Please wait to be seated". After being seated, we had to make several attempts to wave down one of three waiters working the entire restaurant. After placing our orders, it took about another 15 minutes for the soups to come. However, the meats, veggies, and other stuff did not come with it. The soup sat there boiling for around 20 minutes before the food came. I looked at the time and it was after 8pm that we actually could start.

The waiters are very rude here since it looks like they hate their lives. They probably do with the large amount of people they're trying to serve. Dishes will be tossed on your table in a hurry. No one will come by to see if you need anything else. Good luck waving one down since they have tunnel vision.

== Overall ==

This place is really really misnamed. It called "The Pot's", but it should really be called "The Wait". Three waiters running the entire restaurant during the weekend does not work for this place. Food-wise, there's a very nice wide variety of different things to choose from. The quality is pretty good for the price also. This would be a 4 star but the long wait and rude service ruins the dinner.
author: Steven B.

description: came here with my girls for dinner after work. the owner was really nice and helpful . they won't let you order more unless you finish what you already have on the table. It is a bit pricey and we didn't eat much. Ayce doesn't include the drink vs other places does.
author: Siling C.

description:
I finally tried The Pot's especially since I live so close.

Pretty good selection. Lots of variety too.

I thought the all you can price was reasonable and I would definitely come again. The service was quick and efficient and plus i didn't leave the place smelling like food or get "yet hay" from the broth!

The Pot's is a better alternative to Shabu House.
author: Carol Y.

description:
All you can eat hot-pot with no time limit? Fellow Yelper Greg L. brought a group of us here and it was nothing short of awesome. Not a bad deal for ~$25 per-person and they accepted a reservation for 4 people (most other hot-pot places never take reservations unless you have a huge party).  

We were feeling spicy and went straight for the fire-spicy broth.  You'll be handed a sheet of paper where you can note down your items of choice.  They have a huge selection of meats, seafood, veggies, homemade dumplings, fish and seafood balls, noodles, and tofu.  The menu is extensive but here are some of our favorites: 

VEGGIES: watercress, enoki mushrooms, spinach, napa cabbage
MEATS: kobe beef, lamb, beef marinated in wine, and lamb marinated in beer (the marinated slides were interesting and flavorful but we unanimously preferred the plain meats that absorbed the spicy broth.)
OTHER: fish, cuttlefish, pork dumplings, fish balls, fish paste, fried tofu, taro noodles, ramen noodles

If you are craving something on the sweeter side, I highly recommend the dumplings with red bean or taro and fried Chinese donut. I can't wait to come back here on an empty stomach. There is street parking around but you may need to walk a few blocks.
author: Kristin C.

description: Parking was very hard to find during 7pm! Decided to come since me and my cousin were craving for hot pot! Four stars for the good food! Highly recommend the spicy miso broth it was very flavorful. You don't need to really dip any sauce! Just the broth gives the meat a lot of flavor. The service was just OKAY. We had to call them every time when we need something.
author: Tina C.

description:
Let me first start off by saying this establishment is highly understaffed. Adding an extra couple of servers can definitely enhance customer's experience here. We waited almost an hour for our table and the entire time I watched four poor guys running around trying to wait on a full restaurant. There were tables that needed to be cleaned, people who needed to pay/order, and food that needed to be served. 

All that aside, the servers were, when we did interact with them, friendly and apologetic for the wait and always thanked us for our patience. 

It was our first time eating here and weren't sure how ordering worked. Since they were so busy, there wasn't anyone to explain it for us. When we finally did begin to eat, there were a lot of different meats, broths, vegetables and other assortments to choose from. The beef and lamb (marinated and plain) were the highlights of our meal but I was not a fan of their meatballs. 

The total price for two came out to be about $56 which wasn't too bad but slightly pricy for my taste. Be warned that they will only split the check two ways if you go in a group. 

While the food was pretty good, I don't think I would go back again.
author: Jourdan A.

description:
First time here and it was pretty good. Usually for hot pot buffet, we would go to little sheep in Union City since it's a well known brand and we like the flavor of the broth. We went around 7pm on a weekday and they weren't very busy. Their other room was not opened and they didn't want to open it so we (a group of 5) had to sit at a table meant for 4 with a extra chair on the side. As for price, I don't see how they can justify charging $1 per person for half-n-half broth, unless they're putting more spices into the soup, which I doubt.

As for the food choices, this place has a lot more choices compared to little sheep, and there is no time limit I think. However the only complaint I have is that the service sometimes is very slow. When I asked for a water, I never got it until the server saw me look at him and he had another server bring the water. Then we gave them another menu for more food and it took them literally 10-15 minutes to bring. And they didn't bring everything that we had marked. So we gave them a 3rd menu and this time they brought everything on there. However when we were finally finished, we realized they didn't bring the shanghai dumplings that we marked on the first menu. Oh well.

Next time I come here, I'm going bug them a lot more if they don't bring the food.

PS: One guy didn't speak Mandarin, only Cantonese and English, it was funny watching my friend's mom asking him for more shrimp and him having no idea what she was saying so I had to ask for her.
author: Da X.

description:
This place might even be better than Shabu House!  I didn't have a great experience with Chinese-style hot pot at Little Sheep since it's so expensive for such little food, so I wasn't very excited about this place.  My friend persuaded me though and so I went.  

For $25, you get AYCE ($23 Sun-Thurs!).  They have soooo much variety!  Lots of different types of broths and fillings.  It's pretty awesome that we ate for 1.5hrs straight.  The meat might not be as good of a quality as Shabu House, but the fact that we could get shrimp, fish, dumplings, wontons, veggies, mussels, noodles etc. more than made up for it since we only ate 3 platters of meat anyway (not very much in comparison since we ordered almost everything on the menu).  Some of my favorites were the egg yolk and taro dumplings.  Save it for last since they're more for dessert.

They've been around for 4 years so I'm surprised that not very many people know about this place, which is much bigger and better ventilated than Shabu House.  Service was fine for us.  They refilled our water/tea without being asked and we got our extra orders in an acceptable amount of time.
author: Jane N.

description: I love The Pot's! This place can get crowded, especially during the weekend, but it's a great place for all you can eat food! They have a great variety of meats, vegetables, dumplings, noodles, etc. It's a bit pricey especially when you go with a bunch of people and get more than one flavor of broth, but this place is definitely worth it if you're feeling hungry and want some hot, hot food! The servers are pretty polite, but it's hard to get their attention especially when it's busy. I highly recommend ordering everything you want in the first go even if you think it's too much. It'll probably be just enough!
author: Grace C.

description: Finally, I got to try this place. Parking is a pain the ass, after circling many times, I parked about 2 blocks away. Entered restaurant a few minutes after 5pm, we were seated promptly, the waitress asked if we've been there before and proceeded to inform us that we have 90 minutes to eat and AYCE.  We happily marked away our selection, then our soup appeared along with plates and plates of food. Food was good, beef was thinly sliced. Pretty good selection of food to choose from. We were checked on a couple of times during our meal. I felt it was enough and if I needed anything, you flag them. Our broth was refilled along with our hot tea.  I don't have any issues with the food or service, the only issue that I had were out table mates next to us.  ....they were loud and obnoxious! Not only were they cussing the entire time, they wasted so many plates of food! 4 stars for food and service. 0 stars for the classless jerks next to us.
author: Alicia A.

description: It was authentic. The soup bases had fruitful flavors. The fish slices were fresh; mushrooms were worth trying. The meat balls were large; Quality of meat was not outstanding.. Overall, good place for hot pot
author: Sherry C.

description:
I went with my two shawty's so we call it "Thot-Pot"

Super authentic hotpot. We got the Super Fire Spicy broth, and it was just right amount of spicy. There was a pretty comprehensive list for selection.

Service was pretty great. We initially ordered the wrong broth and they were very accommodating in switching it. 

Atmosphere is pretty interesting. Gave a very communal family feel - perfect for hotpot. There was no line and practically seated right away.

Great experience.
author: Vi T.

description:
It was very busy when we walked in, and we were asked if we could finish in an hour and a half, because I guess they had a reservation after.

The pork bone soup is amazing. You could just drink it by itself and it would be a meal. The spicy miso is okay.

Their meat selection isn't the biggest, but you can order as much as you want so it's okay. Everything came out quickly despite how busy it was. All the noodles are top notch.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Hot pot is one of my family's traditions, so I always have high expectations when I go. My partner and I were walking by this place after dinner one night and couldn't help but notice the delicious aroma from this place. It smelled so good! We decided that we will have to visit The Pot's soon. So, we did. 

When we went, their credit card was down, so they had signs all over the place that said, "CASH ONLY". Oops, we don't usually carry cash and were about to walk away when someone from the restaurant (not sure what his role is) assured us that credit card will work too. They will take down the credit card number. So, fair enough, let's go. 

We decided to split the broth - the spicy one and the pork bone broth. I'd say the broths were good, but nothing amazing. Then, it's all you can eat.. so you order whatever you want from their menu on a sheet of paper. Hand it to the waiters and they will deliver. Kind of. There were only 2 of them working, so service was kind of slow. While they had lots of items on their menu (all your traditional items - veggies, all sorts of balls - fish, beef, dumpling items, thin slices of meat, etc..), I wasn't particularly impressed with anything - not even their supposedly hand-made dumplings (they were frozen!). It cost each of us $24.99 or something like that, which is kind of expensive. I'd rather go to one of those personal shabu shabu places in So Cal (i.e. Boiling Point) and for a cheaper price.

The night ended with a slightly awkward exchange with the waiter saying, "cash only", but us letting them know that someone (the host) assured us that they can still take down the credit card number. All was fine, but it was weird. 

Hmm.. I guess I may return, but not if I find a better place in SF!
author: Cassy H.

description:
Yummy!!! Came here on a Friday night around 8 and the wait was not bad at all! My boyf and I were seated fairly quickly after waiting maybe 10 min. I really recommend the Kobe beef and the lamb marinated in beer but I'd only stick with one order of the lamb because the broth had an annoying lamb-y beer taste after the second plate of it. Also really loved the enoki mushrooms. They give you such a big bunch! But all the other veggies were also very yummy. 

Service was kinda ehh... A couple waiters had forgotten about what we had asked for a couple times so we had to ask other waiters. 
 
Overall, I highly recommend paying the $26 per for this AYCE spot. It's delish!
author: Kathryn Y.

description: Come here to celebrate friend's birthday,  so we have a room for our private group. The soup base is rich and the beef are fresh and tasty. The menu has a lot of variety to choose. I really love the spicy soup base that they have. We all have a fun time here and the staff here are nice and friendly! This place is good to celebrate party if you have a big group.
author: angel w.

description:
I'll start by saying I LOVE hot pot, shabu and the like.
In a perfect world, I would hit up hot pot with a big group of friends and throw back some beer over good conversation. 
That being said, I can't fathom "all-you-can-eat" hot pot. The broth/meat is consistent  and great but you can only handle the consistency for so long before you're filled with water weight and begging for a change in texture. SOMEONE THROW THIS BOY A BURGER.

That out of the way, The Pots is my favorite hot pot joint in the city. Why? Let's call it "everything-but-the-kitchen-sink" method. 
You're given a choice of a variety of broths, meets, veggies, egg?, shrimp, dumplings, etc.

We ordered spicy miso soup as the broth. Meat we opted for pork meat ball, prime rib slice, lamb slice and pork slice. Veggies were bok choy, Chinese lettuce, spinach, deep fried tofu, and eggplant slice. Dumplings, we went ham, with shrimp wonton, chicken and chives dumpling, shanghai soup dumpling and pork dumpling. Noodle we kept it simple with thin rice noodle and udon. 

Holy. Shit. BOMB.

Not only can you split the broths (which we found out after the fact), you can literally throw ANYTHING you want on the menu in the pot for an out-of-body all-you-can-eat dining experience. The texture was inconsistent which kept you yearning for more (see: food coma/loosening the belt), all the food was fantastic and service was prompt/friendly. Usually Chinese restaurants can be a hit or miss, especially near closing time on a Sunday, but they were on their A-game.

At $25/person, we left full, satisfied with HELLA leftovers (which I'm sure isn't the norm but they were about to close... doesn't hurt to ask) I had leftovers for days so I'm a happy camper.

Bonus points: they're 2 blocks WALKING distance from my house.
Minus a star: they don't serve beer (which would be great for those group outings)

The pots, my hat is off to you. You set the bar for this white boy. My stomach thanks you...I'm just hoping I can find some spandex jeans for my next visit; no judging.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Although this was an all you can eat place for $23, it was clear that by the end of Friday evening, with taxes and the included tip, our group of 9 each needed to pony up $32.

The interior of this place was not particularly upscale but the social experience and the food was the focus, wasn't it? 

$32 included a gigantic amount of food--most of it very fresh. Two hot pots of broth, one panang (kind of a curry flavored) and another vegetarian that I did not sample. 

We had fresh whole shrimp, wafer thin slices of beef, lamb and pork, tripe, enoki mushrooms, green-lipped mussels, fried tofu, fresh bright greens galore, many many good shrimp & fish dim sum dumplings, and we had chicken thigh meat (more on that later). We also had instant noodles, soba noodles and giant pots of tea.

The two propane burners quickly heated up the broths and we were off dumping in dumplings and meat and veggies and letting it cook up.

Long handled mini dipping baskets retrieved your food while ladles provided a means of dipping into the broths so you can fill your small bowls full of the goodies.

On the plus side, the dim sum dumplings and beef pork lamb were all good to very good. The veggies were super fresh and excellent. This was truly a massive amounts of food. 

On the minus side, our waitress would continue to refill the broths (with hot water--not more broth--so the broths got more watered down was the time went on) and supply more meat or whatever we wanted. They do warn you on the menu that there is a surcharge for not finishing what you ordered however. 

The only item that did not impress was the chicken. And the fact many of the raw (non marinated) chicken tasted funky was not consistent with the rest of the meal, nor for a meal of this cost. The chicken was not thin sliced like the other meats, but in chunks off the thigh. This is the only choice that I would not recommend.

Finally, just when we thought we couldn't eat more, the dessert of small sesame balls was a nice touch to the evening.

If I were to rate this just on the taste of meal alone, it might have been 3 stars, but the final price knocked off a star--especially when they simply watered down the existing broth; this is a stingy practice and unnecessary for the charges. 

This is a more-the-merrier kind of place: more people= more choices. So if you're in the mood for a bit of a splurge with good food in a social setting, Pot's is OK but there are better values with better flavors.
author: Glenn H.

description:
To start off, this restaurant could have received 4-5 stars if the service was better. The main lady was rude and not friendly whatsoever. She always had a sarcastic tone and you got the vibe that she did not want to be there. One of the male servers had 1 other table of two and still took 20 minutes and 3 reminders to bring 2 beers. 

Buttttt, on a happy note! The food was amazing, because we got to cook it ourselves! The variety of food is outstanding and the portion sizes are great! Just make sure you can finish what you order because if you don't, you get charged 20%.
author: Nickie F.

description:
My last few visits were all satisfied. The food is always fresh. Some of the ingredients are extraordinary that I cannot find in anywhere else. The broth are creative. I believe that the broth are the most important part of the hot pot. Tasty Broth + Fresh ingredients = Delicious Dinner! 

Below are the ingredients I usually have:
Shrimp Paste, Fish Paste, Fried Taro, Cheese Beef Ball and Shrimp Ball, Chinese Donut, Enoki Mushroom, Watercress, Tripe and More.

Definitely will come back and update my review. :)

P.s. The wait on weekend might up to an hour.
author: Lit K.

description:
Dear The Pots,

With your competition up in flames you are the best AYCE in the area.

Cheers!

-Ed
author: Ed T.

description:
Morning after dinner at The Pot's: I'm sitting here chugging massive amounts of water in a futile attempt to cure this sodium face that is now starting to swallow my eyes.   

This place reaffirms my belief that when things sound too good to be true, it usually is. 

Everything is on the utmost level of saltiness and on the cusp of MSG overdose.  While the selection is quite vast (like everyone marvels at), it all tastes like it came out of the freezer including the meat.  Another major gripe I have with this place is things are not cut for optimal bites/eating.  You are instead dealing with burning your mouth/tongue in a hasty attempt to not stuff an entire napa cabbage leaf into your mouth. 

This place is a testament to the argument quality over quantity.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
This place gets 3 stars from me.  This place is all you can eat.  I came here with my lil sis on a weeknight.  It was really crowded, probably because it was around dinner time.  We waited about twenty to thirty minutes for a table.  The waiting area is an awkward little corner with five, maybe six, chairs.  The inside smells of a combination of sweat, food, and heat.  The windows are particularly nasty looking because of all the moisture that has formed on them.  

We were seated in the middle of the restaurant in a table meant for four.   I was expecting a table with a heating element built into the table.  I was not expecting a portable stove that uses butane gas.  I thought this was rather ghetto.  But hey, if that works for the customers, then by all means, carry on.  We ordered a lot of food for the two of us.  They have your standard hot pot items here.  We ordered the spicy broth, which looked absolutely like a flaming pot of death.  It was pure red, with peppers everywhere in sight.  

Our food came shortly after, and we feasted.  It seems like there are only 3 waiters/waitresses working because it was so hard to get service.  I asked for waters once, then twice, and finally, I acted really irritated, and got it on the last try.  It was equally hard getting more napkins.  Each time I would ask for something, it felt like I was asking them for a kidney.  

When we were almost done eating, the butane canister went out and they had to refill it.  I take it this happens quite often.  

All in all, good food.  Service needs to be re-accessed from a customer standpoint.  I would probably not come back here.
author: Victor L.

description:
Okay, so there is bad/slow service, but that's almost expected when you are at a casual restaurant that is supposed to have good food. What matters is that the food is good.

Okay, the waiter didn't bring out some of the food that you asked for - I guess you almost expect that when it's an all you can eat place and they make more money if people eat less food. But I ordered beef tendon (twice) that they never brought out and yes I'm still a little bitter about that the next day. They could have at least mentioned if they were actually out of it as opposed to just generally unconcerned with getting the food we ordered to our table - but that goes back to the service issue.

The bowls they provide are a bit weird - it is a weird compromise between a saucer and a soup bowl that ends up being mediocre at both. It would have been better to give diners a bowl, a saucer, and a small dipping sauce container. Oh, and they should provide soup spoons without making guests ask for them - my girlfriend kept looking at me funny when I drank the broth from my way too shallow bowl.

But yes, the broth was pretty good while it was there. My long suffering girlfriend wouldn't have had to endure watching me drink it from my bowl if I didn't think it was good. The hong kong style broth was particuarly good while the spicy miso was fine but had too much seawead floating around in it. I like seaweed, but when it got caught on serving spoons it was kind of awkward. When running low on broth, they fill up your pot with either plain broth or sometimes just hot water.

The meat, vegetables, dumplings, etc. were just okay. Nothing was particuarly amazing, nothing was particuarly problematic (My stomach was upset with something, but that's another story). This is something that can be tied back to the restaurant being all you can eat - they are aiming for serviceable food and seem to be mostly hitting their target.

I like hot pot, but next time I'm definitely going to Little Sheep.
author: Jeff L.

description: Just got here n I'm loving the atmosphere! The people the smell of the food and the service is amazing!!!!! Can't wait to eat!
author: Jose L.

description:
Had a great dinner here with some friends to continue our gluttony with some AYCE hot pot.

We had a fairly large group, about 9 of us, so we made a reservation and it was ready for us when we came. Unfortunately they had a power outage or something fairly recently, so their credit card machine was down, so luckily we pooled together enough money for the $30ish per person (tax and tip were included when they rung up our bill for us). Normally, it's around $25 per person and then another dollar extra per person if you want to split the pot to have 2 different broths.

We had the coconut pork bone and one of the curry broths and both were very good. I liked the first one the most at the beginning, but once we had been eating for about an hour and a half everything started tasting the same, so you know... get something tasty. Everyone gets their own bowl of dipping sauce that you get to add your own garlic, cilantro, and green onions to, so that was great to be able to prepare our plates for the meat massacre that was about to happen. We ordered off their paper menu list and checked off over a dozen items for the first round, and the food all came out very quickly and it was all great quality. Hungry for round 2, we ordered again once our table cleared up, and the servers were very quick to refill our ice waters and the soup broths. If you do order an obscene amount of food (or have no more room on your table), they give you some of those stands and leave the whole food tray at your table to cook at your leisure. 

All in all, a great experience that didn't leave me wanting to die but still sufficiently bloated and satisfied. The wait staff is all very, very friendly, and the food was all very good. Don't forget your vegetables or you are going to have a bad time in the bathroom the next day.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I'm sorry, but I have to question the palates of those who say this place is better than Little Sheep.  Did you happen to smoke a sh*tload of the most potent/dankest, munchie inducing weed before coming to eat here or something???

The deciding factor on coming to this place was because I was in the mood for hot pot, but didn't want to make my friend drive all the way to San Mateo after driving to and from Napa all day.  Although my friend insisted that it was no inconvenience, the ratings/reviews on Yelp for this place made it seem promising.

No.  Just no.  Broth was lacking flavor, meats were lower end quality & service was non-existent to those who were seated in one of their smaller separate rooms. One thing I have to give them props for was the little caddy of chopped garlic, cilantro and green onion.  Other than that it was a waste of money even if it was AYCE because we didn't want to eat all we could and would have spent the same amount of money as we would ordering ala carte over at Little Sheep where they know how to serve up legit hot pot.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Used to love this place, until 4/6 of the party had stomach flu after eating here, I think that explains a lot. The grade of the meat was meh, and maybe it was because of the seafood. Probably wouldn't come back here in a long time.
author: Lucy L.

description: The first turn-off: cash only. I had to lose my parking spot and head to my bank. The place could have still received five stars, though. We weren't starving, so we didn't opt for the all-you-can-eat. Then came the per person minimum, which isn't far off from the all-you-can-eat price. We were forced into buying food we didn't want, unless we wanted to be stuck with charges for items we didn't order. I sort of get the reasoning behind the minimum, but it's a huge turn-off. I have no issue meeting it at a classy Japanese place, say, but here!? You're already saving and being annoying by demanding cash only, too. Stop. The service was lacking. My friend asked for spoons for the broth. Simple and understandable. Never provided. Not a friendly vibe. Just whatev. The ambiance doesn't help. The food? Not all that. One item wasn't what we ordered. I was unimpressed with the quality of some of the balls. The lamb was pretty good, and I enjoyed the broth.
author: Paulina F.

description:
A great place to go if you want lots of options and just a huge quantity of hot pot! 2 hours for all you can eat - and they aren't strict about the timing (we were there for a good 2 1/2 hours). 

It was nice that they have side rooms - my friend had a ridiculous birthday party with like 20 people and we got some privacy all together in that room together.

Total was $35 a person including tax/tip (we covered for the birthday boy).

There is literally EVERYTHING on the menu: meat (all cuts, all meats, even blood and liver!), veggies, seaweed, fish balls, tofu, noodles, seafood, even youtiao (fried chinese breadsticks). Try the fried yam and pumpkin slices too. One of my fave finds of the night: egg custard balls and taro balls! These were delicious, a really great sweet option to end the meal on.

Since there is just a crazy amount of options, I would definitely suggest having someone in your hotpot group who really KNOWS hotpot well and can just order s sh*tload of stuff that all goes well together. If I didn't grow up eating hotpot at home, I'd be totally overwhelmed and not know what to get with such a huge listed menu in front of me.

Slight word of caution - service is TERRIBLY slow. The initial orders came out all together (there were always some missing items) fairly readily. Afterwards, it was all downhill. I felt kind of bad because every time a server came into our room, they were accosted by our 5 different hotpot groups with a ton of orders. It seemed to be a 50/50 shot if the order showed up at all. Your chances went up if you reminded them several times.

Also take note that except for the noodles and veggies, pretty much everything came out frozen (all the meat, seafood, balls of any sort). So not exactly the best quality of food.. but you certainly get a good quantity.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
One of my favorite AYCE hot pot places in the Bay!! 

I'm sad the price went up to $25.99/person but OH THE VARIETY! The list of options are extensive and tasty! Everything is pretty good quality. However, I don't like that it's an additional $1/per person for half-half broth. If you're really into hot pot, you must know you NEED to have that Chinese BBQ sauce (idk what its called but in Cantonese its sa-chaa jerng) to dip your meat in. It's not on the list but you can request it!! They have some random choices too that's a nice surprise like Chinese doughnuts! Very crispy and fresh haha. OH AND YOU MUST TRY THE CUSTARD BUNS!! It was recommended from the waiter and it was surprisingly good even though its sweet and the broth is salty. Oh and I wish they wash the vegetables because my bak choy had a lot of dirt on them... I had to rinse them off before throwing it in my boiling broth. 

The waiters are SUPER nice! They don't seem annoyed at all even though we kept adding on more items and needing other things. The main room can get pretty hot/stuffy so they can have better ventilation.
author: Ivana W.

description:
Randomly came for dinner on a Sunday night. No wait at the door, with a "slight" wait for a table.

Pros: Accepts CC, variety of hot pot choices, helpful wait service, all you can eat
Cons: Wait times! (if you are going to order again, make sure to order before all your food has made their way out of the soup), somewhat steep price for all you can eat $25 on weekdays and $26 on weekends [Fri-Sun](but considerably cheaper than most places), every time we reordered from a new menu there would always be something missing when the food arrived at our table, MAJOR BLOAT AFTERWARDS

My family came here for dinner after wanting to try a hot pot place. We decided on trying out The Pot's. As we arrived at the restaurant, I immediately noticed the heavily condensed windows and upon walking in was overwhelmed with a ton of good smelling smells.

We were seated within five minutes of waiting. We were not sure how the menu worked, so we asked one of the waiters and he was easily able to help us and clear our confusion. We gave a waiter our choices, and let the wait begin. I would say that it took at least 10 minutes for a waiter to bring out our spicy fire soup and turn on our stove and another 10-15 for our food to come afterward. The way my family and I decided to order was to get a bunch of different things, and see which items we would be re-ordering. The plates and plates of food came out and looked very good and fresh, very far from that "frozen aisle of Asian supermarkets" appearance. We started cooking everything from the Enoki mushrooms, ramen noodles, Kobe beef slices to the plethora of dumplings that I ordered. The soup was not that spicy but at some times, I definitely felt the heat and sweat building. My absolute favorite things out of all the food choices that we ordered were: the spinach, Enoki mushrooms, 小籠包 (Xiao long bao), Kobe beef, the fried bean curd and the golden fried dumplings! We ordered three times, and I wasn't even at my limit~ Amazing, considering it was basically a buffet and I usually eat to the max at buffets to get my money's worth. 

The wait staff was great. They were friendly and very helpful. Our plates were cleared off in a prompt manner, our tea and my water were filled somewhat slow but not slow enough to ask for a refill. We were checked on twice during our dinner and though I don't like that in other and most restaurantes, it was tolerable at The Pot's for some reason. I mentioned on my cons that there would always be something missing whenever we reordered for more. For example, I ordered Xiao Long Bao three times and only received them on the initial menu we ordered with. I didn't look much into it, but I was a little surprised that I never got another xiao long bao after the four I finished.

Overall, besides the steepish price and the slow food refilling, I would DEFINITELY CONSIDER THIS PLACE the next time I am hunting for hot pot.
author: Alex T.

description:
This place is much better than your typical run of the mill hot pot restaurants.  Quite a little gem for those who like to eat hot pot.

The interior of restaurant is bright and clean, although the chairs can be uncomfortable for those who have back issues.  It looks like they have an area for larger parties.  A flat screen TV on the wall plays the latest shows from Hong Kong.

I experienced very good service there, probably because I went there at 5:30pm on a Tuesday.  I am not sure if they could maintain the same service level in a busy evening.

The AYCE looks like the best deal there.  For about $23 (before T/T and on a weeknight, weekend rate is slightly higher), you can gorge on a large array of hot pot items.  There are at least five or six soup bases to choose from.  I had the pork bone soup base and it was quite good.  All items my friend and I ordered were fresh.

I am definitely going back there for more.  This is as good as you can get for AYCE hot pot.
author: Harvey K.

description: Wow....  didn't came here for 2 years. . But wow they are getting better and better on there hand made dumplings.  I love there fish and shrimp paste. . My heart place .... and the there other locations with yakitori  ...
author: sean c.

description:
When it's cold outside and you're looking for something delicious to eat, you should definitely check out the Pot's.

This is your typical hotpot style place where there's a huge assortment of items to add to your boiling soup such as fish balls, lobster balls, veggies, meats, seafood, etc.  I believe this was pretty standard fare and ran about $24.99 per person for all you can eat.  You should definitely get the split pot (I got spicy + regular) to give you different tastes to your food and even though it may cost extra, it is definitely worth it.

Bottom line: If you're ever in the outer areas of SF and you're craving some taiwan/chinese style hot pot, be sure to check this place out!
author: Andrew C.

description:
I like hot pots. I've only done a few, but I'm a fan of dropping thinly sliced meats and vegetables into a boiling pot of broth. It's great.

As an establishment, it's bare-bones. Gas burners, clean tables, five or so TV's reporting on Harbaugh's recent firing. I even remember the lighting to be somewhat dim. You won't be arguing about merits of the decor or the ambiance.

Instead, you get AYCE for a standard price, that is also open-late. You get some friendly service. You get your sliced raw pork and beef, your enoki mushrooms and bok choy, you drop them into a pot and have at it.

I didn't get seriously sick, and we ate well. Which means I'll probably come back when the urge to hot pot arises again.
author: Louie L.

description:
This is a real time update and will revisit after this meal. 

We have been seated for 30 minutes and we don't even have soup base served. I checked with the waiter and he said there are a lot of other people who also don't have their food served yet. I don't mean to be a btch but most people who came after us have been served already..

- 5 min later -
Soup base came. No food for us to cook when everyone else had their food ready along with the base. 

I wouldn't be complaining if I can get full from the soup base.

The soup is boiling.. I asked if we can at least have something served to start cooking... Don't wanna just sit here and watch the soup boil away
author: Emily W.

description:
I really wanted to like this establishment more, especially because you can't really screw up hotpot granted the food isn't spoiled! I came here on a rainy night with my sister, and luckily beat the crowd! 

AYCE is about $24 i believe. We ordered a broth and listed items. I was a bit confused initially because they took away our menu and didn't bring it back (unless you ask!), which is when I questioned whether it was really AYCE. Then, they brought out either the wrong items, or items were missing. They aren't organized as far as what you order. Unlike the dimsum places, they don't log in your items in an itemized sheet to keep track (yeah i know its AYCE and it doesn't matter!). You end up choosing your battles because the servers are so busy, that when you get the wrong item, you debate whether just to eat it or wait another 10+ minutes for them to fix it.
author: Connie C.

description:
all you can eat HOT POT! i had the spicy miso on one side of the double pot and the other side was tomato.  definitely a fan of the spicy miso. the food concept is a good option for groups because you cook, you talk, you eat, you cook, ....
the only drawback is that there is no beer or wine served here.
seating is definitely a challenge here and the better tables are in the back rooms. not so drafty and more privacy.  service is definitely a small step above self-service too. the staff is not very attentive and we were constantly asking for things like
- more soup, more water, more soda, the check, etc.
but with all these shortcomings it's still a fun and tasty option for dinner on a cold winter's night in the sunset!
JYW says GO Here!
author: Jeff W.

description:
This is my go-to AYCE hotpot place despite the subpar service. The food is usually fresh, they will usually bring 95% of everything you marked, and its overall decent. 

If only the bald male server who wears glasses and the tall female server who looks miserable with an attitude would lighten up and pick up some hospitality skills, I would come here more often.
author: Cray C.

description:
Three strikes and you're out.

Strike 1. Horrible seating arrangement. Did we unknowingly bring shame upon your establishment? Why else would you stuff us in a tiny room having a total of four tables, with the other three tables already reserved for a party. Bad planning much? The other group in the room blew out my eardrums and I wanted to duct tape their mouths every two seconds.

Strike 2. Horrible service. We got little to no attention from the waiters unless we went up to them and asked repeatedly for items. Want a glass of water? Ask three times. Want more napkins? Ask twice. Want more soup? Ask twice. But nooooo, none of that nonsense for the other group in the room. The only thing they were prompt about was bringing the check. Yeah sure, now you want my money after giving me that kinda 'tudeee. We'll just see about your tip. 

Strike 3. The little things add up. 1) Several of the plates we requested never made it to our table. And if this wasnt an ayce I would be throwing a hissy fit had they charged us for the invisible food. 2) I was blissfully stuffing my face with ramen+miso goodness and suddenly something black moves near my napkin. Turns out it was a disgusting bug crawling on the table for who knows how long. 3) I had to keep scooting closer and closer to my friend because the waiter could not get through to the back table. This was definitely out of his control and only happened because the room is teenytiny for twenty people to sit inside. But I could've done without the constant bumping of my elbow tyvm.

And I angrily glared at the 'people love us on yelp' sticker on my way out.
author: Wendy N.

description:
Service ***
Came here on a Friday Night and boy was this place packed. 3 large parties, 2 in the rooms and a party of 12 outside. That means seats are limited. Waited for 5-10 minutes before a waiter acknowledged my party of 3. 

Food and broth took some time to come out 
Waiter gave us the wrong order

Price Average ****
All you can eat for 26 per person. 

Food ****
Spicy Miso and Pork bone Broth

The kobe beef and lamb were fresh, but the beef was not the best I've had. They have a good variety of items.  Ordered fried fish balls, beef tendons ball, lobster ball, scallop shui mai, enoki mushroom, shiitake mushroom, napa cabbage, shrimp dumping, golden fried dumping, udon, taro thread, fried tofu, and stuff tofu. 

I find it odd that they don't cut the stems of the shiitake mushroom.

Love the shui mai and stuffed tofu.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Not a bad hot pot place. Large selection of food & soup bases. We walked in at 5pm so there was no wait. We got the Miso Soup & Fire Hot soup bases and they were both really good. However, it was only me and boyfriend so we only ordered once & it was more than enough. The Kobe Beef was good and their shrimp is yummy :) Their sesame sauce tasted kind of weird to me & their beef was kind of too fat for my liking but other than that, everything was good. $25.99 per person on Sundays, which isn't too bad but we both got a soda so it added up to around $70 total.

They also had a couple TV's around so it was awesome that we got to watch the Oscar's while eating.
author: Queenie L.

description:
It's cold, it's fall, it's rainy... what's going to the be the best culinary intervention to this San Franciscan meteorologically caused depression?

HOT POT!!!

The Pot's menu of all you can eat shabu shabu style hot pot was a pleasant respite from the fall weather for our hero and his friends.  Throwing bok choy, paper thin sliced meats, and fish paste balls into a boiling hot pot of spicy broth was the perfect antidote to a dumpy day.  Their premises are clean, the food is relatively fresh, and the selection is top notch.  Next time you're hankering for pho, ramen, or chicken soup... dig this place instead!

PROS:
- Huge selection of different meats, dumplings, veggies, and more that you can throw into a hot pot.
- Right off the Muni line and with lots of street parking around.
- Clean, well lit, and spacious for large parties.

CONS:
- Surcharge per person of $1 for split flavor pots.
- Service tends to a be a bit slow.
author: Albert W.

description: Amazing hot pot! Fresh delicious food and the staff was very kind and helpful for us hot pot noobs.
author: Nico P.

description:
Excellent hot pots! Broths are seriously yummy! Definitely try the spicy broth, just be careful not to eat the peppercorns. Huge selection of meats, veggies and noodles! 

Only gave 4 stars as the service is a bit inattentive & hard to catch if you need anything.

The restaurant runs hot (and why wouldn't it, they serve hot pots!) so dress accordingly.
author: J R.

description:
My family and I came here on a Saturday night around 9:15 pm and they were able to accommodate us. It was our first time and the waitress (who speaks Cantonese and English) was able to familiarize us with the process. 

Basically it was $25/a person for all you can eat.  You're given a sheet of paper and a pen and you can order whatever you want on there under the all-you-can-eat price. 

We originally ordered the Hot and Spicy broth and when it came out, it was filled with red chili peppers! Once the broth began boiling it was almost unbearably hot so we had to ask them to mix in the original broth to simmer down the taste. (Note: It is $1 extra per person to have half and half broth)

We ordered lamb, beef, tripe, fried fish balls, regular fish balls, wontons, mushrooms, tons and tons of greens and shao long baos. We kept ordering and ordering until the five of us were completely stuffed. 

The waitress was super sweet and kept checking back on us to see if we wanted anything else. The male servers were a bit lacking in service but the waitress made up for it. I will definitely be coming back on a cold SF night! :)
author: Vikki K.

description: Stumbled upon The Pot's after a friend and I discovered that Hot Pot garden was closed due to unforeseen circumstances. So we jumped on Yelp and found this place. We were waiting for AYCE hot pot all week so we had pretty high standards. It was mediocre. Nothing to rave about. I totally understand that restaurants like this get very busy. But do the owners understand that? Hire more employees to serve your customers! I had to ask about 5 times for a glass of water. Sure it filled me up. The food was okay. I enjoyed the taro dumpling thing. And the price wasn't bad for an AYCE restaurant.
author: Dara S.

description:
We made reservations for a party of 10 on a Saturday night, but when we got there, a bunch of people were cluttered outside. I managed to squeeze my way through the crowd to let the staff know our party has arrived. However, there was some misunderstanding and our table was given to another party, so we waited for an additional 45 minutes. The waitress was very apologetic and offered our whole party drinks on the house. So even though we were slightly irritated, the waitress with the superb customer service lessened the frustration. 

The Pot's offers a very electic amount of dumplings, meat, veggies, seafood, carbs, and miscellaneous items. We were informed several of the dumpling selections were already "out of stock" and this happens frequently since they are "popular". Other than that, our party thoroughly enjoyed the unlimited amount of meat plates that circulated around the table. I personally enjoyed the unlimited plates of enoki mushroom and PORK BLOOD. 

The broth was very tasty, I enjoyed the pork and spicy miso combo. (they charge $1 extra per person for the combo broth) It didn't leave me dehydrated, so it's safe to assume that there was limited amount (if any) MSG used. Thoroughly impressed with this hot pot joint.
author: Ada C.

description:
I have been here many, many, times, and this is so far my favorite hot pot place in SF.

Awesomeness about it:
 --- all you can eat! for ~$27/person
 --- two broths in one pot
 --- very wide selection of ingredients; meat has better quality than other places

You should know that:
 --- it get's extremely crowded on nights & weekends. waiting is a bad idea, because hot pot can take 1-2 hours to finish. CALL IN ADVANCE AND RESERVE! Tell them your name, phone number, arrival time, and party size. Then show up at the time, expect there NOT to be a table ready for you yet, but bother the waiters about your reservation, and them being Chinese, will honor the fact that you called, and make it happen soon (my experience is 10 min tops)

 --- water & rice: are the two things I never get until I ask twice. it's puzzling to me, because the pot and the rest of the food comes so fast. I think I've been there 10 times, and only once did the rice arrive with me asking for it again (I always mark it on the order sheet).


Broth recommendations:

 --- pork bone: is the standard hot pot base, can't go wrong with it
 --- spicy miso: is a little spicy and salty 
 --- fire hot: is very spicy, and will likely make everything you put in it spicy

Spicy miso & fire hot should both be vegetarian. But double check with them.

Stay away from the sake broth. It's really sake + water. I couldn't take it...



Ingredient recommendations:
  --- meat-wise:  lamb slice, prime beef slice, beef marinated in wine, bork belly, pork intestine (I'm serious, the intestine is amazing)

  --- leaf-wise: crowndaisy/tong ho, napa cabbage, bok choy

  --- balls-wise: beef ball with cheese, shrimp ball with cheese  (be careful when eating, the balls explode!...with cheese)

  --- shrum-wise: enoki mushrooms, black fungus/woodear

  --- fu-wise: fried tofu skin, iced tofu (sweet-tasting), soft tofu
 
  --- fried yam, fried taro slices (can be eaten immediately or after hot pot-ing)

  --- dessert-wise: dumplings with taro or red bean or sweet egg custard  (NOTE: put these only in clear/pork broth at the end of the meal, take them out immediately after it's done which is confirmed by being able to poke a chopstix through easily otherwise the dumpling might disintegrate)



Do not get:  
  --- beef tongue:  it hardens into a leather-y texture, just yucky
  --- tripe: it may be a good pho companion, but I find it boring in a hotpot


There is no right way to eat hot pot, but here's my general recommendation that ensures a continuous supply of well-cooked food:

1) wait for the broth to boil/bubble before doing anything
2) put large leafy vegetables in first (tong ho, cabbage) that take longer to cook
3) put balls and mushrooms next (wait 2-4min)
4) after the pot reboils with (2)+(3), put in the thin meat slices/seafood/thin veggies (ex: watercress), spread them out with chopstix
5) as soon as all the meat all turn color (should be fast cuz meats are thin), immediately have the whole table launch eating
6) IMPORTANT: don't add in more veggies or balls at this time, add in more meat only if you want more food
7) now the pot should be close to cleaned out, with only broth and some scraps/balls/vegs, now go back to (2) and repeat!

The reason I do it like this is, leafy vegetables take the longest to cook (and taste terrible if still raw), and meat cooks the fastest (and taste terrible if overcooked). You don't want hungry people to eat undercooked and overcooked food. So, gauge the pot so that there's always a time when everything in the pot is done to the same level and should be consumed immediately. It's not rocket science, but I am surprised that a lot of my Chinese friends don't even follow this simple rule and just stare at the pot and try to add in a few veggies every 2 min. You should never have to do the pick-the-cooked-one game when eating!


Happy HotPotting everyone :)
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Delicious!!!  I love the selection for all you can eat.  You can get shellfish, prime rib, pork, lamb, dumplings, veggies, etc, all for $23!  How can you beat that?!  I love the spicy soup and the pork bone soup.  Servers are very attentive.  You don't have to flag anyone down when you're running low on food.  They come by and ask you if you want more.  I crave soup a lot and this is definitely my favorite neighborhood hot pot place!
author: Elena N.

description:
I have never!

I have NEVER seen so many options in my entire life.  The broth list alone is long enough to overwhelm you (in a good way).  By the time you get to your ingredients like meats, veggies, noodles, dumplings, etc...you've already celebrated your next birthday.  

This is a great spot for many reasons:
1.) You're cold and you want something hot
2.) You're hot and you want to cool down - nothing like eating something hotter so your insides make your outside feel not as hot!
3.) Craving comfort food
4.) Can't decide on what you want
5.) Healthy 
6.) Affordable - AYCE for less than $30!
7.) Interactive
8.) You are on a first date and want to seem worldly.  This would also be a good opportunity to see what he/she orders so you can tell if their eating habits are too picky - cut it off right there.  Just end it.
9.) Great family place
10.) Nice staff
11.) You can take MUNI here, it drops off right in front!!!
12.) There's plenty of neighborhood parking
13.) If it's OutsideLands time, you can hear the bands performing from GG Park.
author: Alex T.

description:
This place is great! :) 

I came here on a Thursday night at around 6:45 with my boyfriend, two friends and their baby. It was practically dead when we arrived, there were about 3 other tables eating and by the time we finished two hours later, 3 other tables were filled. 

So, I guess this place is ONLY all you can eat for $22.99 a person (which is worth it if you ask me) and its more Chinese style than Shabu. You get one of those papers with 50 items on it and you just mark down what you want, which has everything from noodles to prime rib to lamb to dumplings to veggies to pork blood and etc. etc. 

For our table we got 1/2 miso and 1/2 spicy miso for our soup base and might I add, the spicy miso is CRAZY! It is overflowed with different herbs and those little dried chili peppers. We took about 50 of them out and there were still about 15 in there and it was HOT, the flavor was great but it was spicy. We also got 2 plates of lamb, 2 plates of prime rib, 3 veggies, 2 tripe, 1 beef ball, 1 fish ball, 1 roll thing?, 1 shu mai, 2 3 bowls of noodles and 5 bowls of rice. After about 2 hours, we were done. 

When the bill came, it equaled out to be $104 without tip. Worth the money to me 

WARNING: They will charge you for all food left on your plate when you decide to call it quits.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Driving 14 hours over two days from Seattle to check out a nearby condo where we decided the landlady was a no-show after waiting 20 minutes in the windy cold is enough to upset a lot of people. But Pot's was only a block away, hot pot sounded amazing at the time, and their tasty AYCE hot pot was good enough to instantly lift my spirits.

With an incredibly extensive menu of options to choose from (5 types of broth, all sorts of meat, seafood, dumplings, and veggies), it's hard to get bored as you're stuffing your face until you've eaten far more than you really should. Items I'd suggest are the pork and shrimp dumplings; beef, lamb, and pork slices; iced/frozen tofu cubes; and the pork bone and Sichuan broths, as these were all tasty, quality ingredients.

And while they advertise a $25 for all-you-can-eat hot pot, there are a few caveats to be aware of - they do charge extra for broth (if you split it, I believe), and they will, supposedly, charge you for any food you do not finish.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I am always a big fan of the The Pot's.

Thank goodness we had a reservation because it was really busy on a Saturday night.
We had a reservation for 4 @7:20pm，we were actually able to be seated at 7:25pm (+1 star)

The taste was great! Different from shabu shabu, but it reminded me of the hot pot experiences in Hong Kong.

Another thing i noticed was that the service here was a lot better compared to the others I've been to.

Anyways I would highly recommend this place
I would definitely come back whenever I am craving hot pot!
author: Wyman L.

description:
Definitely lots of variety here, from the choice of soup base to all the different kind of dumplings.

We came here for our friends's birthday and they were very accomodating to our last minute reservations.  We had a large party so they seated us in a private room. The room was able to seat probably 14-15 people and we had a pot for every 3-4 people.  

They have all of your standard hot pot choices plus dim sum like dumplings.  They also had dumplings that were filled w/ either custard or taro (more for dessert).  Luckily, one of our friends is a vegetarian so his broth was just water and he only cooked veggies in it, so we were able to cook the dessert dumplings in it or else it woulda been salty from our broths.

I think overall, the experience was good but I guess since we had a bigger party, the waiter messed up our orders.  We had 4 pots total and we kinda put in our order at the same time, but 2 of the other pot settings never received their soup or food.  When we finally checked in on it, it turns out the order was never officially put in.
author: Mimi P.

description: expensive and what youre privided are less than other hot pot restaurants. But the tastes are good.
author: Tian H.

description:
The staff were completely inappropriate by letting people who came in and complained to jump the line. 

We were waiting for almost 45 minutes, with our name on the list, and these jokers came in without a reservation complaining that "we called."  They bullied the management into letting them jump the ENTIRE line, people with actual reservations written down on the list.

I'm very disappointed. It seems like a great restaurant but we can't wait a whole 30 minutes more than we were originally told because loud, obnoxious people got our spot while we were patiently and quietly waiting. 

I wish the management would contact us to make it up to us, the food looked delicious!
author: Dina G.

description:
All you can eat hot pot. Fantastic! Decently priced. Ingredients weren't great but at an all you can eat, what can you really expect.

I like it here and can definitely get my fill.

Drawback: UNBELIEVABLY slow service. How long does it take to bring you raw food? If you order a second round, make sure you can finish it. They will make you pay for what you can't finish. We wound up getting full just waiting for the next round to come.

I would come again, but I will avoid the major dinner rush.
author: Eric C.

description: This place is out of control, its so good I tear sometimes since we don't have any in LA. Definite must try if you love dumplings, soup, and Asian food!
author: Tiffany G.

description:
I don't know if the lack of staffing for dinner time is usual here or if it was due to hot pot garden being closed. The two times I've ever been here was during the temporary close of HPG so I guess it's hard to say.

The first time I came here, my fiance and I already noticed that they were slow to bring us food (raw food might I add since it is hot pot) and to refill our waters even after asking several times. The second time around, I came with a friend and it was disasterous! 

We were actually lucky and got in before the 7pm rush but we witnessed tables not getting their food for half an hour or so after their soup was already on the table. EEP! I was embarrassed for the establishment since they were already moving with haste and all staff were on the floor. But for the whole restaurant, I only saw 2 people running around, not including people in the back kitchen. I
later kept trying to flag them down to add more water into my hot pot since all the liquids were boiling away but it took them to near burning the pot before they got to me. 

Yes... it was irritating, but I'm sure if they had extra staff hiding in the back, they would have called them to the floor already. Plus, I already felt bad for them getting chewed out by multiple groups before and after us. Poor things... 

But besides the understaffing, the food is not bad. They have good variety and savory broths. Definitely a nice alternative to HPG, even though that place is still my ultimate fave and I'm salivating just thinking about it.

Oh! and definitely order the hot pot taro dumplings! I thought it would be weird with my soup base, but it was actually surprisingly delicious no matter what base you put it in! YUMMMM!!!
author: amelia g.

description: Always make a reservation when you come here on weekends, it is always pretty packed. As someone who grew up in Taiwan, this place has some pretty authentic ingredients like Pork Liver and duck blood. My only complaint is that once they get pretty busy...they definitely forget to bring you everything that your table ordered. I've been here a few times and it has happened every time. But since they're super busy and seems a little understaffed, I don't blame them that much.
author: Nina H.

description: prime rib to die for! So good, and the food is never ending!
author: Janet B.

description:
Yummy!

This place is a great for AYCE hot pot!! Hot pot means you all are going to be dipping into the same pot, not good for a place for friend with a cold to come along. Anyway, they have a large variety of meats, seafood, meat balls (shrimp, pork, beef) and vegetables.

There's also a couple of soups you can choose from curry to spicy miso. Spicy miso is my favorite so far. No doubt you're going to smell like garlic and armpit when you walk out, but your belly will be full and happy.

It's definitely worth going with a large group of people. It is a busy place so go a little earlier/later than the 5-7 dinner grind.
author: Lauren H.

description: AMAZING FOOD. And totally worth the all-you-can-eat price. They also have all-you-can-drink sake which is rare to find. But be warned: you will be put in a delicious food coma afterwards. As a tip, I recommended making a reservation if you have a party of 6 or more. This place gets PACKED. I recommend going early since there is always a line
author: Kyla R.

description: Definitely one of the best all you can eat hot pots I've been to in the city. I was first introduced to this restaurant by a friend and have been going there since because I love it so much. A huge variety of meat, mushrooms, vegetables, meatballs, noodles, dumplings and other items to choose from. Kobe beef is my favorite meat while all the veggies are delicious. For noodles, I always order taro thread which is just plain amazing. Try adding as much green onions and cilantro into their dipping soy sauce as you can because it makes the sauce thicker and you'll notice the difference that makes. Ekino mushrooms are delicious as usual and really compliment the soup. Service is not as great as it can be but the quality and quantity of food are definitely not disappointing!
author: Vicheth K.

description:
Hmm I must say, my second hot pot experience here and it was actually decent. All I remember was.. it was super crowded, and loud. We had quite a few people so we had the corner table, and it was squishy inside. The chairs and tables take up so much room, and it was just cramped. The ventilation wasn't that great either, it was just hot. I don't think i was hallucinating, but I could've sworn I heard loud thumping music, either in the restaurant or next door. Annoying..
ONTO THE FOOD, we had the all you can eat for dinner and of course, we got our money's worth, and the waiters didn't mind. The food was pretty good, you have your normal hot pot food items such as the thinly sliced meats, fishballs, dumplings, choy, you know the usuals. The soup base was surprisingly good, I love it extra spicy, and I got it extra spicy. 

Despite the horrible ventilation and stuffiness, the service was great in the beginning, and it stayed consistent throughout the night. I'll deal with it. Will come again.
author: Connie Y.

description:
SUNDAY SUPPER CLUB:  The Sunday Supper Club was at it again!  Earlier this month, a few friends and I hit up The Pot's to satisfy our Chinese-cooking and all-you-can-eat cravings.  

We got at The Pot's promptly at 5:30 p.m. and ordered 1/2 mala huo guo and 1/2 pork bone broth.  The broth was good, but I think Hot Pot Garden's broth was more flavorful and clear.

Dumplings and Fish Balls (4/5):  We got the all you can eat and were quite impressed with the homemade fish and shrimp balls and dumplings.  The homemade seafood balls were "fluffy," as my friend described it.  

Sh Cha and Dipping Sauce (3.5/5):  They had fresh sha cha, seasme paste, freshly diced garlic, chives, cilantro and hot sauce, but they only had four of those condiment baskets for the whole restaurant, so we had to hunt them down and wait a while before we could refill our dipping sauces.  The thing I will say is that Hot Pot Garden has a dipping sauce (peanut?) that is like crack.  It made our sha cha jiang insanely delicious, which was good because I felt like I could keep eating forever.

Meat (3/5):  The cuts of meat are a little fatty, but you still got the whole variety-- beef, chicken, fish filets, lamb, etc.  It was great!  I doubt that they slice them fresh like they do over at Hot Pot Garden because I think the slices of meat came out in little frozen rolls.

Extras (4/5):  The variety at The Pot's definitely takes the cake.  There was SO much to choose from-- lots of veggies, mushrooms, meats, dumplings, fish balls, tofu types, noodles, taro, etc.  They also have you tiao!  SO good.  I wish I was never introduced to those little fried doughs of heaven because I ate so many of them.  YUM

For dessert, we ordered little "dumpling"-like balls of red bean, vanilla custard and this salty egg.  

Venue (3/5):  This restaurant doesn't have any frills.  It's not fancy, and it's staffed with about 4-5 waiters.  It's just a regular Chinese restaurant that serves hot pot.  There's a private room to the side where you can entertain a larger party.

Service (3.5/5):  The waiters were nice (not overly friendly), though we had to order fried sweet potato chips several times before the cooks finally processed our order.  They were very prompt and it was easy to wave them down because the restaurant isn't big.

Price:  I think.. Sunday through Thursday, ayce hot pot is $1 cheaper... I think.  Check the prices!
author: Sunny S.

description:
The Pots is delicious & really hits the spot when you're craving some good flavored broth/foods.

-Food: 5/5--they have all the flavoring a and tools for you to make a tasty meal catered to your tastes.
-Service: 
   -Busy: 2.5/5--they do try but they just always seem understaffed. I've experienced missing food, forgetting to bring me things, & no water unless I hunt for someone to bring some.
   -Not Busy: 4/5--huge service improvement.

I LOVE the beef here. And I especially love that they cut each plate of meat FRESH!

Ultimately: I come back here again and again for the huge selections
author: Vanessa M.

description: Was about to make reservations on a Saturday night which was great. Not bad for ayce. Had the basics with some additional items. The curious items for me was the hot pot buns. Never seen that before. Service was good. Would return
author: Suzan K.

description:
a lot has changed in the 3ish years since i last came...

the quality of the food has gone down (especially the seafood and ramen noodles) and service was SUPERRR SLOW. we went on a night where there was no more than 3 tables too.

ive raved about this place back then but my past time here was definitely disappointing.
author: Katherine C.

description: MGS ALERT!!! I been up all night drinking water. It's crazy! Got the miso soup and man.... I don't think I would come back. The quality of the meat is chewy (old age animal). Variety isn't bag but man...... I'm so thirsty :( only thing I like was the sauce that can be customized. Service wasn't bad.
author: Jasmin T.

description:
The food was not bad, but service was HORRIBLE!!! My friend and I went there on a crowded night, and we're placed in this small room with 5 tables. There's this younger grumpy waiter than looked hella pissed. He literally snatched the order paper from my hand, we're too scared to order anything else or ask more tea  from him. We ordered a lot more than what came to our table *sigh* not coming back again.

P.s. The old guy, probably the owner, was pretty nice. I felt bad for him for losing customers because of poorly-trained waiter.
author: Sharie H.

description: This is a great place for hot pot in the Sunset.  The service is always great, the quality is good, and you can get a 3-way pot for more broth variety.  We have actually started coming here more often than Hot Pot Garden.  We've also never had to wait horribly long, unlike HPG.
author: Dylan T.

description:
Not bad. Good collection of food! I will definitely coma back!

But the waiters are not as enthusiastic as they should be.
author: Alex S.

description: The food here is okay.  Nothing special.  There is one standard sauce for dipping, which resembles the taste of a very salty ponzu sauce.  You can ask for sesame sauce, but the one that they carry is not tasty at all.  Overall, it was decent because I was hungry.
author: Jes D.

description:
I love coming here. every I try different soup base and it's all good. 
I especially love the fresh taro dumpling and also the custard dumpling.
these two are sweet taste and you would think it weird to go in a savory soup but it's not.
some plates you can ask them to bring half the order so it's not too big.
author: Rina C.

description: Best hong kong style hot pot to date. All you can eat for ~$26. Kobe beef, pork blood, intestines, veggies galore, lamb, fish, shrimp -- literally everything. Be sure to get the spicy broth that looks insane with the chili's. Tsingtao beer taste better here for some odd reason, but definitely a place to go if you feel like indulging.
author: Andrew T.

description: This one star for their bad service. They answer questions without patient. For the whole meal never come by to ask whether customers had needs. For each time we want to order, check,get water, we had to ask and wait a long time to get response. Never come again, nor recommend.
author: Li L.

description: QUALITY food at an awesome price! $25 all u can eat for dinner. I highly recommend the kobe beef, lamb, tongue, shitake mushrooms, enoki mushrooms, & black fungus were to die for!!! Great service, fast and friendly staff! If this place had an option with the hot pot where we could bbq the food ourself, i would have given 5 stars. But hot pot alone was great on its own! I wanted to come back the very next day it was that damn good!!!
author: Jordan E.

description: The place is small as tables are super small and there are flies everywhere. My friend recommended me this place but it will be my last try.
author: Jagan B.

description:
There's a price difference of $5 going on a Fri/Sat vs Sun-Thu.  I opted for the cheaper alternative of going on a Thursday.  It is highly recommended to make reservations even on the slower days because in the off chance that they have a full house, you're expecting a long wait.  How long?  Well, let's put this into perspective.  For starters, you're cooking your own meat by placing it onto boiling broth.  The broth needs to be refilled every so often since it's evaporating.  They're pretty slow in bringing stuff out to you.  So you're looking at 2 hours.  I'm estimating there's only 1-2 turnovers per table.  This is definitely not McDonalds.

What is The Pots?  Well, it's an all you can eat Hot Pot buffet.  What is Hot Pot?  Think fondue.  So how does it all work?  They give you a sheet of paper where you mark the quantities of items you want along with the broth (I chose half spicy and half pork bone).  You'll want to fill it out immediately since they take forever to bring stuff out to you and they only bring so much at a time.  I remember not receiving all of the items and had to fill out a 2nd sheet only to have missing items.  It gets steamy in there and you definitely don't want to bring your Chanel or Louis Vuitton purse.

Notable items:
* lamb in beer
* beef in wine
* taro chips
* hot pot egg yolk dumpling (dessert)
* hot pot taro dumpling (dessert)

This place could be killer if they speed up the service.
author: Ronald L.

description:
The Pot's = Genius!!

Can I just say All You Can EAT!!! No joke, all you can eat everything on the menu! of course, you'll have to pay $25.99 (I believe) but it's worth the price. Hello?! it's basically a hot pot buffet. Plus it's not like some overpriced shabu place, it's affordable. You choose your broth (my favorite is the spicy one) and then they give you a sheet where you indicate how many meat, veggies, dumplings and etc. Don't over order, be considerate and finish what you can first.

We ordered one of each: beef, lamb, chinese bread, enoki mushrooms, fish balls, shrimp balls, fried tofu, mussels, dumplings. They were all delicious and paired well with the spicy broth. 

Overall, this place is really addicting and I can't stop thinking about coming here again. Just a tip, this place gets pretty packed especially with people celebrating birthdays or what not, so if you're thinking about coming try avoiding the weekends or prime time.
author: Julia K.

description:
Beef quality wasn't very good, as decided upon by both my friend and myself.  Service was non-existent, and everything had to be requested.  Pricey for what we got ($30 a person for ayce hotpot....).  Interior had absolutely no decoration whatsoever.

Food overall was still decent and left full and mostly satisfied.
author: Chinito G.

description:
I've been eating hot pot here for years. Mike is a super nice guy. The long list of menu make them stand out the others. If you're a hot pot and Kobe beef lover, you gotta go here. I recommend go there Tuesday or Wednesday. The All-You-Can-Eat price is lower on weekdays and not as pack as weekends. 

Good thing is they take reservation which most of others don't. There's also one thing set the Pot's stand out from other is that they have a Karaoke room you can reserve for party. I hosted 3 Karaoke party over there for 20 people. The song is not the most up-to-date but it's a perfect place to hang out and eat.
author: Jason L.

description: This is our to go place for hotpot. They have great meat choices and large selections of vegetables. The all you can eat price is also very reasonable. I love their egg custard bum - very creative to make the bum hotpot style! Only thing stop me from going here is the wait and parking... Sometimes parking can be longer than the wait...
author: Coco S.

description:
Went here for Thanksgiving AND they are open!

I made reservation for 3 and it was pretty quick getting our table. The service was still great but couple of times I came here, their credit cards were down so one of my party had to go out to get cash. Other than that, the food is still great.
author: Jade L.

description:
