Really great hot pot place in Sunset! They have a really good selection of broths, noodles and add ins. Our favorite broth was the spicy miso and our favorite noodles were the flat rice noodles. I haven't been to any other hot pot places in the city but the people I ate with told me that the price was really good for all you can eat. 

It was also really good for groups. We had a party of 13 and we were able to make a Friday reservation at 7pm on Monday without a problem. They even seated us early!
author: Alli Q.

description: went last night for dinner - it was awesome! the place is really packed with tons of customers even at around 8 and they are open until 10 pm. it's all you can eat and they bring so much food according to the order! perfect for friends gathering or just a Thursday date:) food was delicious and fresh and clean - meats and seafood especially. will definitely go again!
author: Ailin G.

description: Love love love this hot pot place. I live in the outer sunset and there's not a lot of good food options in the area, but I'm glad The Pots is one of them. They have a relatively large menu selection of broths and veggies and meats. I've tried the spicy miso, pork bone, and the spicy pepper one (forgot what it's called). I like cooking my noodles and veggies in the pork bone broth and my meats in the spicy broths. But my absolute favorite thing to get here is the Chinese donut, it just brings me back to my childhood. I always end up getting at least 2 orders of those. There's usually a wait especially during prime time dinner hours Friday-Sunday. The only thing that's lacking is service. It can take a while for them to bring a new round of food so make sure you put in a new order before you're out of food so there's not downtime of waiting for the servers to bring the food. It's definitely not the best hot pot place but I think it's better than most of the other ones in the city. But regardless, I will definitely go here again and again whenever I'm craving hot pot and don't want to go too far to satisfy my craving!
author: Cindy F.

description: It's an all you can eat hot pot place; at 25 per person it's easily makes 3 stars with no effort! Lots of soup bases to choose from and they are flavorful! There was just two of us so for some stuff we wish portions can be smaller (compared to the big groups there!) and then only two dumplings seem too small...I don't know...portion size was confusing. There was quite a variety on the menu - the egg yolk lava buns were confusing for me since they have a sweet egg custard filling...but the soup was savory. I wish there were different cuts of beef other than the "kobe". Our biggest complaint is that there was no watercrest!!!! Overall I think I'll give the pots 3.5 stars as they have good variety on their menu but maybe not in the right way for us.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
Solid. Shorter wait than Hot Pot Garden and better ventilated. I was a little apprehensive when I saw that they used the portable tabletop burners (the ones powered by cans) but it was fine. As far as splitting broths, you can go up to 4! That's new to me. They have really interesting broth choices that other places don't have, such as pho and a type of curry. 

The veggie choices were fresher and appeared more clean than Hot Pot Garden (but I think Shabu House still wins for freshness/cleanliness). There was also a good variety of meats, including a wine-soaked beef that was really popular at our table. Their menu warns that if you don't finish all the food you ask for, you'll get charged. But we're all Fatty McFatFats and we destroyed the food so not sure if that's an empty threat ;)

Our server was attentive and we got refills of drinks, broth and food as soon as we asked so I have no complaints there. There did seem to be a limited number of staff (3 or 4, maybe?) but since that didn't affect our meal that's fine with me!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
2.5 stars; I gave it 2 star rating because I've experienced better. 

Located by the corner of Judah & 32nd Street. The reason for low stars is really based on the food, service, and space. The service was horrendous - 3 servers/waiters, with a full restaurant; they never paid attention to us & was always normally running around in the back. No moving space as all tables are cramped together, with foldable tables on the side of restaurant tables, for holding a tray of plates (of raw food) for the hot pots. The food quality was okay, but the meats were quite frozen (due to popular demand), and they were never sliced the whole way. At one point, they ran out of big plates and had to resort to small plates, so they stacked our pretty-much-frozen-meats on there. 

I came here NYE with 6 other people for my bf's bday dinner. The place was packed with a full restaurant. The waiting area is small, and everyone is blocking the doorway, AND the area to our seats (maybe because it's cold..but maybe some of you girls shouldn't be wearing a skirt & leggings on a chilly night, or at least bring a spare of clothes between parties & dinner). Note to owners: You should tell the people waiting, not to get passed the glass or not to wait at the glass area. It was disturbing our dinner because they kept moving around, and I had to keep scooting my chair inner than I could, or they would hit my chair. 

Moving along, we originally had 10 people but 3 bailed. Because we thought we had 10, we made reservations for it and they had put 2 [hotpot] tables together. With 7 people, we could fit a maximum of 5 per table (2 by 2 with one on the side). The other 2 people sat in the second table next to us. Each table group made an order separately. We received our hot pot & meat in about 5 mins. By the time we ordered our second plate of meat, the other table still didn't have their hot pot. I would also like to point out that they didn't come to our table to take our orders or to check on us the first 5-10 mins. After 10 mins of the first table getting the hot pot, someone FINALLY came to the second table to take their orders. The staff does not check on you; if you wave their hand, they won't see you. The only way to get their attention is if they're passing by and you try to wave them down or make QUICK eye contact. We made a lot of plate orders (7 people eating here..), and they would always forget some stuff, such as a plate of pork, dumplings, or meatballs. The way the servers kept forgetting our orders, was basically our entire experience throughout the dinner. Also, if you split the hot pot, they charge you an extra $1 by per person, which makes no sense, since you're already paying the AYCE price. It's not like we can choose to get our own personal pots!  

On a positive note, this place has a large selection of broth, veggie, and meats. 

Overall, I did not enjoy my experience, and will not be coming back probably.
author: Mandy G.

description: This place is delicious! This is the cheapest AYCE I know around town. $24.99 per person on mon-thurs. They have great service and food. And when I went, the wait time was only 5 mins. Definitely coming back.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Went with the g/f, we decided to pay for the all you can eat option. Each plate that came out was more than the portion that two people would like to finish. If you go in a small group, I recommend asking for smaller servings per dish, so you can enjoy many varieties without stuffing yourself or wasting food.
author: Anthony W.

description:
All you can eat hot pot! 
Paid $33-34 dollars per person after tax and a 20% tip.
The meat is great---had plates and plates of thinly slices Kobe beef and lamb.
My favorite was the fish fillet.
Not in a hurry to return because I'm not a huge hot potter, but for anyone who loves it, this is a great restaurant.
Conveniently right off the N.
author: Patricia S.

description:
I'm not really an expert on hot pot but I do know I can enjoy a good piece of meat cooked in tasty broth.  And to those ends, The Pot's delivered.

THE GIST: Prime freaking rib beef cuts / Delicious sliced pork cuts / Great Szechuan spicy broth

SERVICE AND SETTING

We went on a Saturday night without a reservation for a late dinner.  The wait was about 15 minutes for a small party.  If you plan to bring a large party you should definitely make a reservation.  However, on the day I went, the reservation line was significantly behind schedule and the last party was seated near the end of their opening hours.  We asked out of curiosity, and it seemed the workers all had to stay after hours to serve that party.

Our servers forgot a couple of our orders, but were attentive at refilling drinks and broth and were definitely friendly and willing to help if you ask them for something.

FOOD AND VALUE

I can only fairly rate the stuff I enjoy, which is pretty much mostly meat:

Prime Rib Beef: Doesn't matter what broth you put this stuff, it's the bomb.  Fatty, delicious, well cut and beautifully organized beef.

Lamb: Not as good as the beef, I ended up not ordering lamb after the first round because it didn't have a lot of the game-y flavor I expect out of lamb.  However, that may have been because we cooked the beef first.

Pork: Thinly sliced pieces of what I believe to be pork belly... which means the pork here is awesome and I wish I had more.

Don't be fooled by my picky-ness.  The menu here is quite large, comparable to that of Hot Pot Garden.  I haven't seen expensive menus at hot pot restaurants like these anywhere else but the bay area, so explore a little.  Price per head was 24.99, which makes it slightly low in SF, but anywhere else you'd be spending at least 5 dollars more for a menu of this size.

CONCLUSION

I want some more prime rib and pork.
author: Brandon W.

description: The pots is the place to be when u want to catch up with old friends over dinner, the meat is very fresh, service was spectacular, loved the pork bone soup and it has 2 private rooms when u want to have a mini gathering or party. I will Def be back! !!
author: Renee Y.

description: A great local Hot Pot place. They have a good selection of stuff on their menu. I really enjoyed the Spicy Miso broth and the Coconut Pork broth. They were both very tasty. Be careful for the occasional bone fragment though. The broths both started out really good, but got a little watery after they added some plain broth or water to both. They seemed to get better as they cooked down a bit so maybe I just needed to be a little more patient. I didn't seem to have this problem at the other great hot pot places I've been to.
author: Scott L.

description:
I've always wanted to come to this "Da Bien Low" (Hot Pot in Chinese) place but never had a chance to until yesterday. After walking into a large establishment with 2 Flat Screen TV's for the NBA Playoffs, I was in Heaven! All you can eat FRESH food for $22.00.  There is quite a large selection of meat, veggies, seafood, and side orders. The four of us ordered up a storm! 

Best of all is the selection of soup base for your Hot Pot. We decided on a clear broth and the spicy which was quite intense. Not for the faint of heart if you are not a spicy eater. 

I definitely recommend this place.  Solid FOUR stars
author: Scott L.

description:
Pots pots pots pots pots potssss!

Perfect place to go to on a cold winter day-- or any day of the year in San Francisco. 

I love this place! The service is generally quick, the place is clean and they have a great variety! My favorite thing there are their exploding shrimp balls! I can't believe I didn't find out about those until my 5th time there! Total fail! 

Be sure to try their crystal lai wong dumplings!

I've been here about 5 times in the past 6 months and I'm planning on coming back for more!
author: Tiffany U.

description:
My co-workers took me out for my first hot pot experience, as I am leaving San Francisco for the Asian food desert that is Portland, OR. 

***A little note of the hot pot experience:
Holy cow. This is the most food I've ever ate in one sitting-- including every Christmas and Thanksgiving of my childhood. That being said- COME HUNGRY. You'll feel like you're done about 30 minutes in, but ask for some water and relax for a bit because you'll get a second wind.

On a Friday night, dinner at The Pot's will set you back about $35 after everything. Make sure to get the split pot to try 2 broths! We got half Sichuan hot & spicy soup and half pork bone soup. Wait to critique the broths- the whole point is that the flavor becomes richer and more complex as you cook your meat and veggies in it. Add green onion, cilantro and garlic to your ponzu sauce and dip absolutely everything in there. Ask for rice and noodles. Crack an egg into the little ladles they have in the pots and take it out after a few mins- perfectly poached! Try all of the meats. Kobe beef, lamb, pork, white fish, shrimp, etc. Some are even marinated in wine. Also, who knew you could cook lettuce? 

Food safety:
Make sure you fully cook your meat and wait to grab from the pot until new items are cooked. Also, keep your chopsticks under the broth long enough before eating off them. This is how we prevent foodborne illness, guys.

We got pitchers of beer for the tables, but I almost want to say skip the beer. You won't have room for it and it won't get you buzzed with all that food! Also, they gave us plastic cups instead of beer glasses. Not the same effect when toasting...

Don't take more than you can eat, or you'll be charged 20% per person. A little tip though: just put (hide) your leftovers in the pot.

Being the Sunset, the nearest bar is 10 blocks away from The Pot's. You'll need all 10 of those blocks afterwards to get yourself a Fernett or whiskey ginger.
author: K M.

description:
First time i went here was 2 years ago. I remember my cousin live near by say it is good and cheap. It was near his house after we visit him. It was a Wed or a weekday. I didnt expect it to be busy at all. The price was not cheap but lit more expensive then others.

The service was a guy and his wife running the front while some dude in the back cutting up some frozen meats silces and a dishwasher or w/e. We have a party of 6 and we order some stuff to start which was not much. The lady say "can you guys finish that, we charge extra if you dont"  I mean wtf we not ordering a whole cow. We are Hungry and can finish all of it ofc. That kinda of rude to me.
Finally the food came and it was very thin cutted and not even enough for us. So we have to order more meats and veggie. We also order some soft drinks which take a long ass time. All the fountain drinks are behide the counters and the nakins too. lmao. 

The soup base was alright nothing special or as good as little sheep in san mateo, There are better place to go, Portable gas stove and when you put the pot on top it is pretty high in the middle of a small cheap unstudy table. I can Imagine an accident can happen in a tight seat resturant. You are elbow to elbow with the next tables and other plp. Barely any room to get out and in of ur seats let alone the server. If you have kids and plp going up and down and around your tables it can get dangerous. All the Co2 fill the resturants. Dont seem to have a good vent here. Come on guys we still screw around with portable gas stove in a resturant like the stone age?

The Staff is so slow and undermanned, They hide all their fountain drink behide the counter and only the server can refill your drinks when you grab and flag them. straws nakins is all behide the counter too. Are you guys stupid. Do we have time to play flag the waiters and waitress all night. There alot of ways to save money and upkeep of a resturant but not like this. Everything have to ask 2-3x and the wait is crazy when it is not even full pack yet.

My Tip: Is to order every items 2-3x each, order your drink and get 2 cup for each person. Come early with a good empty stomach. Let the staff know you are hungry and not going to play game. Dont let their remarks bother you. Of course you can finish everything, it not going to cost an leg and arm if you cant.

Would i come here again? Hell No Epic fail. In China and most place all their resturants have a electric flat stove and special cut center tables to make the hot pot lower and safer. You guys need to learn something from them. I wont come here ever again, I feel light headed from all the Co2 coming from all these butane stove. Does it even pass health code to do that. 

Getto place and tight seating for a AYCE.
author: Amano T.

description:
Hands down, the best Chinese hot pot place I've ever eaten at.  SF hot pot is 2-3 levels higher than that of L.A.  Yep, as you've gathered...  I'm from So Cal...  :D

Here's what makes this place so SPECTACULAR:

--  The hostess seated us quickly...  :)
--  This place offers great, attentive service... 
--  2-3 people would bring items to the table.
--  This is the best non-spicy soup broth I've ever had the pleasure of tasting!  :)
--  I highly recommend the pork bone broth...  d:o)  
--  They add white radish to this broth to make it sweeter!
--  The beef is high-quality, thinly sliced & virtually fat free.
--  Beef comes on a large, generous plate!  1 should suffice!
--  I like the 4 sauce/herb tray that accompanies each meal... :)
--  The atmosphere is casual & not too noisy, like it is at other hot pot places.
--  If you're lucky, you can find a few FREE parking spots around the local streets...

I can only DREAM of eating this SUPERIOR type of hot pot in L.A.  We have the best dim sum, but you most definitely have the BEST HOT POT in the U.S.A!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Content O.

description:
Went there on a Saturday night around 6:45 for dinner. There was already a wait and had to wait about 20-25 minutes for a table of 2. Be sure to put your name down on the list. We tried to call and make reservations for 2 but they didn't accept it. 

We got the all you can eat. The Kobe beef plates have about 5 or 6 pieces of beef on them and they're big pieces of meat. They don't skimp out on the meat so that's a good thing. 

We had mussels, lobster balls, udon, egg noodles, spinach, imitation crab meat, pork balls, shanghai dumpling, some other dumplings, hot sausage links and a few other things. Everything you can get from the freezer, nothing much special. 

Service was surprisingly good for an all you can eat place. We asked for more plates of beef and more refill on the drinks and they were quick to tend to us. Also very quick in taking the empty plates we finished already.

I knocked a star down because after we ate there, my boyfriend had to use the bathroom. I don't know what he ate but it went back out right away. After we ate there we were both really thirsty too. I think the soup had a lot of msg in it.

The place seems a bit small and often times there's big parties so there's limited tables for smaller parties.

Overall, an okay place for hotpot and quick dinner.
author: Jeanne Z.

description:
Came here several times and the food and service is always consistently good! Great selection of everything- meats, veggies, dumplings, seafood, etc. 

Usually I get the pork bone broth and my boyf gets the spicy miso. Recently tried the Hong Kong satay broth (I think that's what it's called?) and its my new fave! Super flavorful. 

All the food is super fresh! My absolute favorite is the salty egg yolk dumplings. MUST TRY! 

Servers are always friendly. The only thing I would say is that they don't notify you when an item you ordered is sold out for the day, but that's no biggie. 

Another plus is that the bathrooms are clean! (When I went at least) I think that's pretty important to have clean restrooms. It really represents the establishment's hygiene. 

All in all, this is my go to hotpot restaurant:) would recommend to anyone who loves hotpot or shabu
author: C W.

description: Oh man, the soup is really great and the service is great too ! The menu options are plentiful and the food is pretty decent. The best part is that the price is all you can eat ! The Aloe Vera drink is pretty good too !
author: Taz T.

description: This is a pretty standard hot pot place. If you like hot pot you won't be disappointed, but you also won't be "wow-ed". The menu has the typical hot pot items in what from my experience are standard portion sizes. I have been here a few times and never had a bad experience - except when I took an uncoordinated elementary aged child here and he dropped something into the broth, splashing spicy burning liquid into his eyes. FYI they are really nice to you when one of your group members starts screaming and crying. So props to The Pot's for being understanding and helpful. PS - probably a good idea not to let children cook their own food. I learned that the hard way.
author: Catherine H.

description: All you can eat, delicious food in a variety of broths. Great hot pot to do with a bunch of friends.
author: Claude M.

description: Don't go to this place!!! It's  a rip off! They charged 2 children full price. They don't explain how the menu works. If I knew They charge $24.99 a person we would've turned our backs and walked away! Definitely Not worth it! The vegetables are served uncut. That's definitely not enticing to eat!!! Meat are nothing special. There were only two people on a Wednesday night and service sucks. Bill was $118 for two adults and two children wtf?!? We could've gone to Kome for that price! Not ever coming back!!! I felt robbed. I agree with the other review below, I couldn't sleep last night my stomach was on fire..I had a really bad stomach problems up until now! I'm sure something's up with the food they serve...
author: Aimee D.

description:
Caveat.  I'm not a huge fan of hot pot.  I'm not too keen on balls of meat.  I'm more of a shabu fan.  All I need are some thin slices of good raw beef to swish so it's barely cooked, some noodles, and enoki mushrooms and I'm good to go!  But, I will say the Pot's has a good selection of other stuff that I don't really care about.  Others in our party seemed to enjoy the selection.

The Problems with The Pot's:
(1) Horrible ventilation.  I smelled like disgusting boiled meat afterwards.  Stinky!
(2) No alcohol!  I don't drink beer, but even I will imbibe a bit of beer with hot pot.  Jeez!
(3) Service was not very attentive.  It took forever and a half to get the things we ordered.  Slow service is horrible at all you can eat places because the longer you wait the sooner your belly tells your head that it's full.

No more The Pot's for me.
author: Christina L.

description:
All you can eat hot pot for $23, you can't beat that! The menu selection is incredible, over 50 kinds of meats, veggies, noodles and seafood. We got the miso broth and the chicken and mushroom. Both were delicious and perfect for dipping. 

The place gets busy so won't wait around making eye contact to get service. Raise your arm to get the waiter's attention. They're very short staffed but super friendly. My friend and I both needed outlets to charge our phones and he went out of the way to charge my phones behind the front desk. 

I'll be coming back the next time I'm in SF!
author: Jane K.

description: Service was kind of slow. All you can eat about 26 per person. They have all sorts of stuff from tendon, pig ear, intestine, and some stuffed taro balls. Food was good. I liked the beef tongue and homemade shrimp paste. Sauce and birth is alright..would prob prefer the non all you can eat hot pot as quality was sub par. Meat looked really tough and they just sliced it. Even though they said its Kobe.
author: Karina H.

description:
Who doesn't love buffets? The Pot's offers a wide variety of hot pot items. My friend and I had the pork bone soup which was so hearty and flavorful. The veggies were fresh, but quite large; we had to rip them in half before putting them into the broth. There's a lot of items and all were pretty tasty. I didn't get to sample the shrimp cheese balls (I heard it's really popular) because it was sold out.

My friend and I really enjoyed the dessert dumplings. One was custard and the other taro. 

The Pot's has a private room with karaoke, if you want to sing and get drunk and eat hot pot. The owner of the place was very attentive and refilled our pot with more broth when it was running low. He also asked if we wanted more meat or other items. Service is very nice

At the end of the meal, instead of traditional fortune cookies it came with delicious bite size sesame balls (jin dui) 

Overall it was a good experience and I would visit again
author: Connie M.

description:
Despite NOT going to Bay 2 Breakers, I still got my "run" on...

Unlike other Yelpers, sadly my friends and I did NOT have a positive experience at The Pots, nor did we have very pleasant aftereffects. We came here tonight for dinner at around 7:45 PM and was promptly seated.

After thoroughly enjoying Little Sheep 2 weeks ago, I was super excited to try TP b/c it seemed to have a similar concept based on the  pictures online. However, TP and LS are not the same caliber.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/little-sheep-mongolian-hot-pot-san-mateo#hrid:iPv31uVSn4pECBViB7Q5zw

CONCEPT:
All you can eat for $22.95 for Mon-Thurs and $24.95 for the Weekend which I think is overpriced considering the poor food quality.

You get to choose from the original broth, spicy, pork bones, vegetarian, and one other I can't recall. If you want half/half, it's $1 extra per a person which makes NO sense esp when you're paying an all-you-can-eat base price. 

The waiters give you a list, so you can check off the food items you want. They also have Chef Specialties like Sea Cucumber, Duck Feet, Fresh Chicken for an additional fee.

They bring you your items within 5 minutes, so you can start cooking. You have a 2-hour limit to eat and any items you don't finish, they charge a 20% fee per a person, so don't get too carried away.

FOOD:
*Spicy Broth: ECK! All heat and NO flavor. Essentially, it was water with chili peppers, peppercorns, fennel and star anise seeds. The broth tasted like I was drinking cayenne pepper water as there was no depth of flavor to it, much less any flavor at all. There was so much peppercorn that when you cook your meat or veggies, the peppercorn sticks to your food item and you end up having to spit out the peppercorns, chewing on it, or getting it stuck btw your teeth.

If you're sensitive to MSG, be very careful. My heart started to race almost towards the end of the meal from the broth. And, I ended up waking up to a dry throat the next morning. 

*Prime-rib: It was ok. B/c the beef was so thin, it kept on falling apart when you pick it up and ended up breaking apart when you soak it in the broth. It didn't taste like "prime" quality as the marbling was just at the tip of the beef so it wasn't as tender as I expected it to be.

*Lamb: Uhhhh, why was the lamb brown?

*Spam: The only flavorful item...it's spam after all and who doesn't love spam?

*Hotlink: It was good as it was store bought; spicy and fatty.

*Meat and Seafood balls: Bleh! Menu claims it was "homemade" and the pics on YELP seemed like they were homemade, but the ones we got, looked and tasted like balls from the freezer section.

*Pork and shrimp dumplings: It was good! The pork was moist and flavorful and there was bits of sweet shrimp.

*Mussels: Bleh! Another item from the freezer section. The mussels were chewy and hard.

*Imitation Crab Meat: Ehh, the sticks were served as a frozen clump.

*Ho Fun: Gross! They looked and tasted like pieces of flimsy plastic sticks b/c they were frozen.

*Tofu: It was ok and was one of the only things not  served frozen.

*Deep fried taro: Burnt outside on some pieces while still raw in the inside.

*Spinach: Ummm, at least it was fresh?

*Sauce: They give you a sweet soy which you can add minced garlic, chili sauce, cilantro, and scallions to. I used SO much of the sauce b/c the broth did NOTHING to the meat and veggies. 

In short, almost everything was frozen except for the some of the meat, spam, hotlinks, and veggies which is NOT a good sign. 

AFTEREFFECTS:
I'm very skeptical about the TP's cleanliness b/c they had a piece of paper pinned on top of the Health Inspection Score Card, so you couldn't read it. But, really makes me wonder about their food safety practices and freshness of their food, is the "aftereffects" my friends and I had. One of my friends, started getting stomach cramps and started to itch before leaving TP. Within 5 minutes of coming home, I went running to the porcelain throne. I BBMed my other friends and apparently they had the SAME experience which is more than coincidental. My friend, John had stated, "I'm in my fortress of solitude thanks to this place."

SERVICE:
Since it's an "all-you-can-eat" establishment, they might as well just make it a buffet type set-up b/c the servers are rude and inattentive. After your first order, they just throw down the plates, they never come to check on you, and don't take your empty plates away.

We had to ask several times for our Sprite which by the way managed to taste warm even though there was ice in it.

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR:
It seems TP use to be an old sushi restaurant and it still had the old décor from a sushi bar. The dining room can accommodate about 30 people while there's 2 private dining rooms that can accommodate about 10 people each.

I like to spend my Sundays relaxing and NOT "running" to the toilet, so I can say, TP was a once in a lifetime experience...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: This place is great for comfort food with friends, wait staff is attentive and the most important the kobe beef is so fresh, live their pork bone soup base,  the place to be for birthdays, celebrations, game day ..love it !!!
author: Autumn C.

description: This is an all you can eat authentic hotpot place - the best I've experienced in the bay area! Their menu selection is wide, and the food is very fresh. I'd always come back for their specialty dishes which include the hot pot salty egg yolk bun, hot pot taro bun, and the hot pot egg yolk bun, and their meat and seafood is also very fresh (can't go wrong with any of it). I also love their soup base, full of flavors with highly fragrant herbs, delish! So far I've tried the Fire Spicy, pork bone, miso soup, cilantro & preserved egg (my fav.) and I love them all. I personally like spicy food but most of my friends does not eat spice so we normally order two different soup base. I highly recommend this place because of the quality, they never disappoint me when I return. The seating here is also very spacious and comfortable, and there are two rooms for large parties. I've been to other Asian restaurants where they try to maximize every square footage but this place is not like that at all. Additionally, regardless of how busy this place is I find the waiters very nice, attentive, and knowledgeable. The price here is also very reasonable for all you can eat. Whenever I crave for hotpot this is my spot!
author: Tiff H.

description: I've been here a couple of times. The unlimited option is too much, but the a la carte is just the right amount. The broth is good, and the meat is sliced to perfection. Good for those cold foggy nights in the Outer Sunset.
author: Michelle S.

description: DELICIOUS. So damn delicious! The pots combines mouth watering all you can eat dumplings, Kobe beef and more, with a fun way to socialize and cook your ingredients of choice right at your table. The service is super slow, but when you get everything you order you largely don't need to bother hailing down a waiter. Great date spot or outing for a group of friends!
author: Claire C.

description: Over an hour waiting time, just because they accept phone reservation. All the groups that have reserved get in first.
author: Jason H.

description:
I didn't find out about this place until my lil broski told me there was an all you can eat hot pot place in San Francisco that is pretty decent and such a good deal.

Pricing is about around $24 a person during the weekday and close to $30 during the weekend for all you can eat.  They have a great variety of meats, vegetables, dumplings. noodles and soup base.  My favorite is the spicy soup base, because it is SPICY! I love how you can ask them to cut the meat thinner if it comes out to thick.  Once your plate of meat is empty, they will be quick to refill.  The other favorite item I love ordering is the stuffed bean curd?! Sooo goood!

This is my second favorite hot pot place and will be back when I am craving HOT POT!
author: Chanel L.

description: Me and James, best broth ever! I went here tonight with my friend James and we got the all you can eat deal. It was amazing! Not only do you get a lot of high-quality me at the broth is ready to go with amazing flavor. Filled with chili peppers, seasonings, and all kinds of other good stuff, you already have a delicious soup to work with. $13 all you can drink he really can't be bad plus quite a selection. If you have never had Chinese donut then you could honestly come here just for that, it's accurate. We had a bok choy lamb pork beef spicy broth pigs blood shrimp dumplings Ramen noodles which are handmade by the way and everything was really good. There was not a bad part of it at all. The best and very decently priced!
author: Timothy C.

description:
MSG  ATTACK!!!

My head is pounding as I type.  Never coming here again (even if someone else picks up the bill).  Im usually not sensitive to MSG, but if my head is (still) pounding.......

Took 600mg of ibuprofen and drank 2 large glasses of water about 2.5hrs ago...my head is still POUNDING. I rather be hungover, ( because atleast I can say, I had a good time).

ughh. not cool
author: Angelica C.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times. It's all you can eat for $22.95 from Monday through Thursdays. Weekend price is $24.95.
The portions are still small. A group of 3 or 4 will go through a plate of beef instantly so order in batches. 

Although I come here, I would prefer not to. Their service sucks because they're not too attentive. Actually, they're not attentive AT ALL.
author: Susy C.

description:
This place has a similar vibe to most cheap restaurants I've been to in rural mainland China.

Thoughtless decor. Clueless staff. Mediocre food.

AYCE hot pot is typically an easy favorite among, well, humans. In theory, you get a lot of food. But that depends on the waiters caring to serve you. The staff at The Pot's will not attend your table unless you aggressively flag them over and then repeatedly tell them what you want to eat. I also hate to pull a White Guy card, but it feels like the printed menu offers much less than what I could get if I spoke Cantonese or Mandarin.
author: David S.

description:
The Hong Kong style broth is AMAZING. 
I would pass on the Spicy Miso. 

Very fresh vegetables and lots of selection. Almost too much, very overwhelming. 
The meat is still not as good as the kobe beef from shabu shabu places, but if you're craving Chinese hot pot, this is a very good option. 

Way better than Little Sheep Mongolian Hot Pot AND this is in the city!
author: Lily S.

description:
today, our service was terrible because we came during the dinner rush at 7pm. i believe this place has gotten a bit busier since its rival, Hot Pot Garden decided to burn itself to the ground. 

it took about 5 minutes for us to be seated, 3 minutes to order food, but 45 minutes to get any other ingredients to eat with. it really sucked. what can i say, it's the only AYCE hot pot restaurant in the area and perfect on a cold night.

food was great actually. most times we end up at HPG but honestly, The Pots has amazing dumplings and won tons, much better fried tofu, they offer both fish and shrimp paste, beef tongue, and my favorite of the night: lamb soaked in beer. it was fantastic. we kept it simple and ordered pork bone broth - often times much healthier than all else that is spicy and full of oil.
author: Thao T.

description:
The Pot's is an all-you-can-eat hot pot establishment that offers everything from the basics like: beef, lamb, tofu, and enoki mushrooms- to the more deluxe ingredients like: pork blood, tripe, tong ho veggies, dumplings, and shrimp paste. Excellent way to enjoy a large variety of hot pot goodies at one set price ($25pp, soup base charge extra), without shelling out too much money ordering a la carte.

If you are going with a group on a weekend, I would recommend calling in for a reservation. Otherwise, expect to wait hungrily near the doorway whilst staring like zombies at already-seated patrons. Creepy.

Insider Info: The Pot's does not serve alcohol, but the owners- unofficially- may or may not allow "BYOB". Our group brought like 30 beers in a paper Trader Joe's bag, which in retrospect could have been disastrous in last week's rainy downpour. Whatever, we made it, and we left with full bellies. Classing it up in the Outer Sunset.
author: Elaine T.

description:
Came here to celebrate my cousin's white jacket ceremony with some family and I was pretty impressed. Normally I go to Hot Pot Garden for hot pot, but they don't take reservations, and so we took our business to The Pot's. I'd honestly say they are just as good as Hot Pot Garden,maybe even better in some aspects. 

SERVICE: Very accommodating. Very patient. Friendly. Helpful. Attentive. They refilled water glasses several times without having to be asked, which is always a PLUS for me, especially when I drank 4-5 glasses.

FOOD: 
Soup: Spicy Miso and Pork Bone. Bother very good, very delicious. 
Delicious selection of meat and veggies. They beat HPG in serveral aspects:
1. They have a larger selection of dumplings. I'm not talking 1-3 choices like at HPG, but they have a whole section for dumplings here.
2. HPG has fish collars, but the amount of meat on the fish is hit or miss depending on the pieces. The Pot's has lovely fresh fillets of fish. Much better.

AMBIANCE: Modern. Clean. It has several flat screens playing sports. Thank you for having CLEAN bathrooms. Thumbs up.

You must try The Pot's at least once! The selection will surprise you, even if you're a HPG fan. However, HPG definitely has the edge on alcoholic beverage.

Defintely will return!

-------
EDIT: Sadly i realized their dumplings ARE frozen. I guess the first time around they were thawed/defrosted properly that I didn't realize it, til the second time around. Oh well, still good, and I'd order them again, but now I know they are frozen just like HPG.

Other things I've tried:
Their miso soup base was pretty good, with nice big chunks of tofu, so you can skip on ordering a plate of soft tofu. They have seaweed in it too, which seemed to get in the way of the scooper though. Oh well. I can live
author: Jenna H.

description:
Usually, *usually* when it comes to asian grub, I prefer Japanese food.  Meaning if I had to choose between Japanese food vs. other asian foods (Thai, Chinese, Indian), I'd usually choose Japanese.  It tends to have cleaner flavors and feel healthier.

That is not the case with Shabu vs. Hot Pot.  Hot Pot clearly wins this time around.  I was a self proclaimed fan of 'all-you-can-eat' shabu deals since I had my first shabu house.  But, my hot pot cherry was recently popped earlier this year and I've been semi-fanatical since.  

I was amazed at all the additional items that you get at a hot-pot vs a shabu house.  Yes, you get the thin sliced 'kobe' beef (or so they say 'kobe'!)  But, hot pot also come with fish balls, lobster balls, dumplings (like 10+ different kinds), prawns, calamari, veggies (all kinds) noodles, etc.  The list could go for days, granted I didn't recognize half the items on their list of ingredients, but 50% ingredient recognition at a Chinese restaurant isn't that bad.

This place tends to get crowded, especially on rainy SF nights.  The wait could be 1+ hours, thankfully we were able to call ahead and get our name on the wait list (they don't take reservations).  

At a whooping $24.99 per person, it's a great, filling meal that doesn't break the bank.  Words of advice: come for an early dinner, BYOB (they don't serve alcohol!), wear loose fitting clothes, and don't make any plans for the rest of the night (you'll most likely have hot pot coma).
author: Clarissa P.

description:
I went there as a group of four. It was kinda packed with medium-sized groups and it was not a hassle to get a table. Our gas stove was not giving enough heat to give our soups a boil, but they gladly changed it with a new gas can. Their service was okay and i'm pretty sure it would get worse if it was packed. 

pros:
- clean
- 5 TVs
- all you can eat

cons:
- no ventilation so it gets pretty hot in there

Overall, I loved my first hot pot experience and I would gladly go back only for special occasions. It's well worth it for the price so i recommend it.
author: Anne Jolene C.

description: Great selection of meats and seafood. Broth is just right not bland or salty like other places I've been to. Easily the best hot pot spots in san francisco. Mike ( owner ) is the best!! Thank you for a great hot pot experience.
author: Evan T.

description:
This establishment is located deep inside the sunset district. It's strategically placed in a neighborhood where brutally cold nights are common in that area, so it would only make sense to "hot pot" during those cold nights. 
 
The all you can eat buffet is a pretty good deal. The service is always pleasant when i go there. There are a variety of broth for you to choose from, personally i like the pork bone broth but like i was saying there are a variety of flavors, the waiter that was serving my party gave us a sample of the broth before we confirmed what we wanted. 

it's no little sheep, but it is close enough in my books !
author: Jeff C.

description: Best Hot Pot in the city -- as witnessed by the fact that I'm usually the only white person in there and the line is out the door.
author: Felix B.

description:
HOTTTT POTTTTT! unlimited meats you say? well then, yes, I'll be there.

Crowded as hell, but whatever, you wait a little people will get full. And you DO get full.

The spicy broth is delicious. You get the non-spicy ones for respite, but at the end of the day the spicy one is the most delicious.

The meats all taste fresh, and the dumplings are nice.  The sauces are a fun way to cool down the insanely hot things you just cooked.
author: Shanee B.

description: Came here for Thanksgiving dinner two years ago and still remember the experience well. Food and staff are great. I have been dying to come again, but have not found time. The Pot's is a bit far from my home. It's a perfect place to dine at during the winter season.
author: Fanny T.

description:
Expensive BUT it hits the spot. I think it's better than the taraval one. They have EVERYTHINg on the menu unlike the taraval one. 

I just think 26 dollar for all you can eat hotpot is a little much but you know, if it's with friends, I guess it's justified. 

Overall, food is good but meat is better at taraval and a good variety of food.
author: Hei Ming C.

description:
Absolutely delicious. Really, a lot of the shabu places taste similar. The only things that set it apart are the in the quality of meat, the veggie/side selection, the price, and last but not least, the SOUP BASE!!!! There were more options for soup bases than other restaurants, but even though I'm a spicy broth type of gal, my favorite was the oxtail soup base, hands down. There was also the spicy (Mongolian spices style) broth but then we kept biting into the mouth-numbing spices, so we had the other side with spicy miso.

I can't remember off the top of my head what I ordered but really, it's less than $30 for all you can eat....It's great for large parties, but FYI they don't serve alcohol.
author: Betty W.

description:
Got the all you can eat here. I love the variety of choices. My bf and I couldn't decide what to get so we got way too much. We were stuffed to our throats by the time we were finished. 

The shrimp, pork, beef, lamb were all fresh and tasty. The broth was slightly bland, but after it evaporated a bit, the flavors concentrated to create a passably good broth. I would come back here for the variety, even if the broth is just so-so, and that's saying a lot since, in my opinion, shabu shabu places live and die by the flavor of their broth.
author: Le T.

description:
I'll keep it short and I won't beat a 224th review of a dead horse too much here. 

After MONTHS and YEARS of Mike. W shouting from the tops of his lungs of his affection for The Pot's, I finally went and it was just as great as he screamed it would be. I love being able to have the duo pot of 2 soup flavors so we picked the pork bone and the spicy. I started drinking the pork soup before our hot pot ingredients came and it was absolutely delicious especially after adding the cilantro and green onion.. Anyways, we picked the sliced lamb, beef, tong ho, napa cabbage, taro dumplings, wontons, cuttlefish, enoki mushrooms, meatballs, etc. - all was lovely. On cold San Francisco nights, hot pot is probably the one thing that hits anyone's spot. I'm thinking SF should be known for hot pot joints seeing how cold it is year-round - particularly in outer sunset.

I'm never one to run asap to an AYCE place, especially a hot pot place, but this place is perfectly sound for quality of ingredients, ambiance, service and taste. If possible, continue keeping it under the radar...just a bit.
author: Jessica C.

description: Not sure why the ratings are so high for this place. We walked in with no line but most tables were full. After being seated at a pretty small table with 2 portable catering style burners (most places have the burners built into the table) for the 4 of us it took 30 minutes to get drinks in our hands. Another 30 minutes goes by until the server actually took our order sheet then you will wait 10-15 for the order to make it to your table. All of the items were fairly quality but the menu doesn't come close to the options at Hot Pot Garden on Taraval, unfortunately Hot Pot is remodeling after a fire and this is the only reason we visited here.  Costumer service is definitely not priority, the crummy interior and burners on the tables are not inviting, I don't believe we will be returning.
author: Kyle S.

description: Best hot pot in San Fran
author: Cynthia F.

description:
We called ahead and made a reservation. They did not have a table set up. They also did not tell us that their credit card machine was down so when we arrived a bit after some of us had to go to the atm. They did set up the table reasonably quickly and then after some of us left to the atm they did accept the number for our card to charge later. 
They did not have music which the setting seemed like it should.
They did not have any dessert at the end.
They did not offer us drinks at any point.
Service was mediocre but food was good and fresh for the most part.
Dumplings were disappointing. They were frozen and tasted packaged.
They did not have the scallion and chicken dumplings.
author: Josh V.

description: This is my go-to place for a AYCE hot pot every time I'm in the city on a cold day... and that's usually most of the time in SF. Come during off-peak hours and you'll get decent service. There were only 2 waiters for the entire place during weekday dinners... so service is a bit on the slower side but they are efficient enough. Other than that, the meat and veggies are fresh. You have an option of  2 choice of broths (I love the pork bone and spicy broths) which will cost you more... or just stick to one. The lamb is delicious. The beef is good. They claim it's "Kobe" but seriously... who are they kidding? Overall it is as good of a place as any other hot pot places. Parking can be challenging as it is tucked in the middle of a neighborhood but you can always find a spot.
author: Mims S.

description:
Craving hot pot, I decided to do a hot pot night with friends. I made a reservation for 11 during the week, and we all came on Saturday night. The Pot's is out there, in the Outer Sunset, which took forever to get to! But that's alright, nice to get away from downtown sometimes. Funny thing was, you would think parking would be easy here, but it actually wasn't. 

The decor here is very simple, restaurant is packed to the max with tables and seats.  Our party of 11 sat at one large table in one of the separate rooms from the main dining area. A plus was that once we arrived, our table was already set and ready for us.

I really wanted to LOVE the Pot's, but it was just average to me. I did enjoy having hot pot with a bunch of friends and getting lots of food, but here were the negatives:

- Sauce selection is not only small, but poor. I did like that their soy sauce is home made, but the sad basket selection of cilantro, green onions, garlic, and hot sauce all seemed to be the cheapest quality of condiments.

- Broths were okay - I would expect it to be better if they're charging you extra to have two different broths at your table.

- Aside from the meats, everything was pretty much frozen foods. Meh, this made for less quality and very bland items. 

- They do have a large selection of items, more than other places. However, we noticed throughout our meal that they don't bring you a lot of the items you mark down. ech..

- They don't serve any kind of alcohol, but on the flip-side they do allow BYOB.

Aside from all of that, service was friendly and attentive for us. Although the food wasn't necessarily that great in quality, I still had a great time with my group of friends. Like I always say, hot pot is such a fun and yummy socializing meal.

Not sure if I will return though - I just keep getting reminded that when it comes to hot pot, you just gotta do it at home. I wanted to do that this time around, but was lazy when it came to do the food shopping and setting up for a large group, and I also had been wanting to try this place out.

But next time, hot pot at home it is!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Allow me to preface my comments by explaining that I was in the mood for dim sum, and had never experienced hot pot dining, so I was disappointed.  This restaurant is miscategorized and some of the reviews made me think it would be a buffet with some dim sum items in addition to the hot pot, but that's not the case.  So this review will be detailed for the others who, like me, didn't know what to expect.

Upon arriving, you're seated at a table that has a portable butane burner on it and given a pot of tea and a menu so that you may indicate which type of broth and various ingredients you would like.  It is all-you-can-eat as others have mentioned, but it's not a buffet line where you pick out everything--they bring stuff to you.  After a few minutes, they bring out a pot of broth, which they set on the burner for you.  Following this, come plates and baskets with all your meat, veggies, and dumpling choices.  They also give you some dishes of garlic, cilantro, green onion, and chili sauce to flavor your broth.  You then proceed by cooking your own dinner by adding the ingredients to the soup.

I would be ok with this concept except for a few things.  One, the staff doesn't really give you any guidance about method (to be fair, I didn't ask).  I'm a good cook, but this was outside my area of expertise, so I was frustrated by having to guess and figure this out.  Second, it's $25 per person for you to cook your own soup!  I could make my own soup at home for much less.  Third, because the butane burner is set on top of the table, and the pot on top of that, it is a very awkward angle from which to be dealing with hot splashing liquid.  I'm short--I literally had to stretch and strain to see everything in the pot.  I've been told that other hot pot restaurants have tables with the soup pot built in so that you're ladling from table level, which would have made the experience much more enjoyable and less dangerous.

On the plus side, the food was tasty and the staff was friendly and the place was clean.  If they charged $10 or $15 per person, I would have considered going back now that I know what to expect.   The way things stand, I won't be paying another visit.  Sorry.
author: Areena M.

description:
This place has the largest variety of food to select from. They have an abundant amount of vegetables to choose from also. 

I usually get the preserved egg/cilantro hot pot broth. If you are into hot pots and fondues, this place is a must!
author: Philip K.

description:
Holy gorganzo beans! This place is like the king of hot pots and shabu shabus! After getting seated, you are presented with a sheet of paper where you must mark which items you would like including the choice of your soup base. We chose the spicy miso which had plenty of flavor and was mildly spicy. All you can eat for $23! 
 
Ranging from seafood, different arrays of meat, dessert dumplings, pigs blood, pork intestines, noodles, vegetables, mushrooms, and many other items. You name it, they probably have it. Except ice cream for dessert which is complimentary at most hot pot or shabu shabu restaurants. 
 
We went on a sunday night and the place was packed. Not sure if its just that night, but there is not enough servers to truly assist the customers. I felt bad for them, but we had to wave them down several times in order to make new request. 
  
Nonetheless, too much food, not enough room to put it.
author: Becky Q.

description:
ITS A- OKAY!

The place is cute just not my cup of tea because it can get cramped in here even with big groups of people, i cant help but think they fill up as much as they can. they use the little portable gas stove which is great but problem is with those stoves, hot pot is best standing up, not sitting.

Food was great, experience was so-so, just i really like to have a lot of room to just move around instead of feeling like i might accidentally smack someone from turning or that ill bump my elbow at my friend on accident from trying to eat.
author: Jay K.

description:
Here comes my first Yelp review and it's to my favorite hot pot place in the city! 
I am impressive with the choices here from soup base to all the fresh food items! I felt very satisfied whenever I had a meal here.. Everything is excellent and my all time favorite is the egg custard bum, which you can't find it anywhere else, but here. It's a hot pot dessert after a great meal! Hmm... Yum...
author: Joyce K.

description:
I'm an Angeleno. Though my heart is in Los Angeles, I DEFINTELY left my tummy in San Francisco! Or more specifically, the Pots. 

When I heard about this delish AYCE Hot pot place.. I just HAD to try it out. So even though we were staying in Nob Hill, we cabbed it out to the outskirts of town to try this place out. It was SO worth it! This was definitely my favorite place to eat on the trip. In fact, I loved it so much that I had to go twice in the one trip to SF.

The soups are SO good. My favorite is the spicy miso. The soup base was very flavorful. The premium beef was also really good -- very well marbled for AYCE. And I loved the assortments of vegetables, fried tofu, mussels. I'm even a fan of the 'sweet' egg yolk bun. 

The first night we were here, there was no wait. The second night we came back, we regretted not making a reservation because there was an hour wait -- basically, we had bad luck because the line did not move one person since we sat down since all the seats probably sat just right before we arrived. We had to wait until all the diners finished eating! But it was definitely worth the wait.

Now that I'm back in Los Angeles, I'm constantly craving this place. I miss it so much already. San Franciscans, you are so lucky!!
author: Nancy Y.

description: So we came here a few weeks ago for a friends birthday and I sort of had some expectations but not too high.. we were put in this room that had two long tables.. the other table was occupied by a family and it didn't seem to be a bother at all. They originally only gave us two pots... and we had like 10 girls... so we were wondering how the heck that would work.. so we asked for another pot. The service was extremely slow... it took forever to get the next plate of food... and we were constantly ordering more because it wasn't enough. We weren't given a sheet of paper to order what we wanted.. as I see on other reviews... but we were given complimentary soda which was awesome.. thanks to our friend who had connections haha. Also we got the half half soup base and the spicy is numbing spicy!! so if you can't handle spicy food.. I'd strongly suggest the regular base. The food quality was pretty good... I just wish we could have gotten more... the service speed was really the only downside to this restaurant.
author: Tiff C.

description: The food was fantastic!  A great place to bring friends and family.  The closest thing to China this side of the Pacific.  The beer could be colder.
author: Nat W.

description:
All you can eat for around $30? I'm in. 

I felt like I drove halfway to Hawaii to get here. I totally forget the outer sunset exists until someone mentions Kingdom of Dumpling or now, Pot's. Parking wasn't THAT easy. 
Vicky L. made reservations for Sunday night hot pot since we had a larger group. It wasn't very crowded on Sunday.
I enjoyed the spicy sichuan base although I didn't get much help from the others in the group. We probably ordered one of everything on the menu to dip. The tripe was good! 

Apparently there's no alcohol here? The best thing with sichuan spice is a cold brew.
author: Sara P.

description:
Mhmm went here two weekends ago because I was craving it for awhile since it's been rainy and somewhat cold here in SF. Came back here after not having been for a few years and it didn't disappoint! We didn't have to wait at all because we came early. 

My husband and I ordered the Miso broth, we couldn't remember what we ordered last time. I like how they have seaweed and tofu floating in the soup base already. It was yummy. But does get a bit salty on your food, I didn't even feel like I needed to dip my food into the soy sauce mixture because it was already salted from the soup base. 

Everything is so fresh and yummy, I'm sure it's frozen but who cares, as long as they defrost it it tastes good, it's fine by me. The lamb meat is my favorite, my husband likes the Prime Rib meat. And we love our noodles, udon and rice noodle. I love it because we can both eat and order what we like specifically and choose to eat what we want. 

But we did end up ordered too much because our eyes were hungry, so we did end up with a lot leftover and couldn't eat anymore. Can you ask for a box to go? My husband said no otherwise everyone would just order a bunch, cook it and take it to go, that makes sense. But I hate wasting the food!! Sorry! But they didn't charge us for it, even though they used to have that policy (not sure if they still do), but it was nice of them not to. 

Mhmmm hot pot.
author: Grace L.

description:
First thing to say about this place: it is humid! I wear glasses, and right when I walked inside they instantly fogged up. And I quickly found myself stumbling around trying to find a table. However, once I came to my senses I immediately noticed how many people were at the restaurant and how happy they were. It was as if I had just stepped into a tropical rainforest, opening my eyes to see blue frogs and scarlet macaws.

Important fact #2. This place is all you can eat! heck yeah! You're given a menu and you can literally order anything. (it might help to bring a Chinese-literate friend, some of the menu items in English are pretty nondescript, i.e black fungus).

Do yourself a favor and eat a diverse dinner. Nothing but prime rib and spicy miso is of course good, but so are cabbage, spinach, taro (soaks up all of the juice) and enogi mushrooms. Highly recommend the bean curd sheets. In fact, sincerely everything here is hot pot good. Eat here and eat like a king. A very fat king.

PS: If you made me disrecommend one thing, it'd be the iced tofu. It tastes like ice. Literally you will be cooking it longer than your meat.
author: Marty H.

description: This is the real deal. I've been looking for a great hot pot place for some time. The Kobe beef is best, lamb a close second. We did a spicy miso broth and a mild pork. Prepare yourself to make a mess and have fun dunking in your ingredients. Remember not to put too many at once, because it will slow the rolling boil. Great for group parties!
author: Michelle B.

description:
Cold, rainy night in SF, we were in the area, so we figured we'd try this place instead of our regular Shabu House.

We arrived at 7pm, we were not seated till 8:45pm. This part of Judah is kind of dead so there aren't any other restaurants we could go to. Otherwise, we would have left when we weren't seated by 7:30. By 8, we were committed.  

Took about another 10 minutes after we were seated before our pot arrived. By then, we were famished. 

We tried the spicy miso soup, which was nothing special. The dipping sauce was so salty, we didn't bother using it. Actually, everything was very salty. We drank cups and cups of water throughout the night. 

We ordered lambs and beef plus lots of veggies. They were all pretty good quality, so no complaint there.  On weekends, it's $25 something/person. Considering the long wait and the price, honestly, we were expecting better food. There's nothing special about it. Service was slow, took forever to get our water refilled. 

This one is not a keeper or us. We would rather wait at Shabu House.
author: Angie L.

description: The food was decent, but the service was lacking, they keep bringing us the wrong items and the meat isn't very fresh IMO.
author: Bai Z.

description:
I would honestly never go out of my way to eat here but was in the area, and its been so cold lately that I wanted something warm so hot pot it is!

We arrived right at 5pm on a Monday evening and by six, the place was packed with a line out the door. The two servers were running around like chickens with their heads cut off that eventually two workers from the back had to come out and help serve the broths and trays from the kitchen. 

I ordered by circling and then marking what I wanted. My friend did the same but for some reason only my food came out. So it took a while for her to eat due to the initial wait until we figured it out and by the time we put in a second order, the place was already getting busy.  I had to ask for drinks three times before I received it but I made sure to keep asking the same guy and after the third time it clicked and he was super apologetic. He came by a second time to apologize again and took the drinks off the check which was nice. I totally understand what it's liked to be slammed and understaffed and they did the best they could. 

The miso broth was nice. So was the udon noodles, soft tofu, and the Chinese donuts. The beef marinated in wine will get super bitter with alcohol the longer you let it sit so eat that first.  The beef tendon was chewy and never got soft. I loved the variety of vegetables, my favorite is the Napa cabbage and the enoki mushroom. The shrimp is firm and comes with the head and we also had squid and beef tendon balls.  It was $23 for each person for two hours worth of all you can eat. 

I am a big fan of Shabu  on Geary. But the variety of broths, meats, and vegetables here is nice. Like I said in the beginning I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but it sure hit the spot.
author: Walerz B.

description:
I love The Pot's. Normally I'm not a big fan of buffet since I tend to overeat. 

Lots of options for meat, soup, dumplings, meatballs, noodles, veggies, etc. I love the lamb here (I don't eat beef). The killer of the night is "hot pot egg yolk bun." They have two kinds of egg yolk buns. One is more yolk-based (similar to Lau Sa Bao filling) and the other is more custard based (similar to Nai Wong Bao filling). Make sure you tried both!

It can be a long wait on the weekend, but it's so worth it especially on a cold, rainy day in San Francisco.
author: Saran R.

description:
Get over the lackadaisical service and you'll easily see why this joint deserves its many Yelp accolades. One question though... Why is the business name in the possessive form?

Anyway, on recommendation from one of my dearest friends took myself, my brother, Bonofide, Baby Brian and BB's lovely lady out here to the Sunset. Totally random, but worth it -- since it's ALWAYS cold out here, hot pot is just the way to go.

A very short wait and no explanations later, we were seated. No booze :(

Get half spicy miso and half regular. Thank me (via my chum Huy) later.

AYCE comes out to roughly about $25 or so per person including tip. You can pretty much select anything on that sheet -- just be sure to point it out to your aloof server because they may miss some markings. Especially toward the end of the night when I'm sure all they want is for you and your fatty foodie friends to get the F out.

Great deal, awesome company, wonderfully full. I can see how the wait could get out of hand, so come late on a weeknight or at some other opportune off-peak time and you should be alright.

Ooh, ETA: must-haves include the prime rib, all dumplings, all veggies, and enoki mushrooms. Mmm. Steer clear of the rice noodles and any meat ball with cheese inside... That's just weird.
author: Monica D.

description: Amazing all you can eat for $25. Incredible quality of meats, seafood, veggies, and homemade dumplings.  One of my fav Chinese restaurants in the city!
author: David Z.

description:
They disappointed me a bit when I came here with a group of friends. Everything was fine and good, until the vegetables came. Some were kind yellow and old looking. Some looked eaten by bugs... would have been nice if they sliced that part off or just thrown it away. The worse thing was when we saw a bug that was still alive in the vegetables... after that we kind of stopped eating the vegetables. I was told that I can't expect restaurants to clean my vegetables like home, but I would hope they rinsed it well enough where bugs aren't still in there.

Food is still good here... I would just probably inspect my vegetables more before eating it... lol.
author: Johnson S.

description:
this is the best hotpot in the US - and I would even say in the world. Yes. ANd this is hotpot buffet - buffet usually means that quality us compromised - but no in this case. the equality is enhanced with the increased amount of available hot pot tools and foodage.

The owner, Michael, is SUPER LOVELY - I came here with my brother when they first opened and he was so awesome to us. 

I am a world acclaimed triple gold crowned hot pot professional eater - so I speak from a position of authority and as the US representative of the International Hot Pot Eating Association.

I eat hotpot all the time in China - while its' SUPER yummy you just never know what you're eating in China. 
I think The Pots is even better than hotpots in China because you know the stuff here is fresh and free of polluted pesticides. 

GET the taro balls!  and they also have the best red bean rice balls.

Michael if you are reading this I have one big tip for you - PLEASE PLEASE increase the # of sauce trays and hire more servers - your stuff is so good that everyone's always fighting for the sauce trays - you need to provide a tray for EACH table. yes. I know. and please more cilantro generousness from the servers - they always skimp on cilantro and garlic - and to me those are the CRITICAL ingredients of making super magic hot pot sauce. 

here are some photos!  http://www.flickr.com/photos/triciawang/sets/72157622694742561/
author: tricia w.

description: More like 3.5 stars. I came here for a friend's birthday and really enjoyed it! This is the perfect place to go to on a cold night. My favorite broth was the spicy miso! It was very flavorful and not too spicy. They also have a large selection of items to choose from on the menu. However, my only complaint is the refill of the broth. Instead of refilling with more spicy miso, they filled it with just the regular clear broth. Of course when you do that, it begins to dilute the flavor of the broth. Not sure why they do this. Unfortunately, this is why I can't give this place 4 stars. Overall, it's really good, but they need to fix this problem.
author: Christine B.

description:
Pretty sure that owners of AYCE places hate me.  I wouldn't be surprised to see a picture of my face plastered all around the city: "BEWARE.  FATTY."

Luckily I got in to The Pot's before they saw my picture.  A few rounds of mediocre broth and mediocre-quality meat (and trust me, when it comes to raw meat, the last thing you want is for something to look just mediocre) later, our bill came out to $46.. and they came and told us that their credit card machine was broken.  AWESOME.

Fortunately, my dining partner had some cash that he'd grabbed as an afterthought, otherwise it wouldn't have turned out well for any of us.

Eh, I've had better hot pot in a slightly more central location, but at least parking is a breeze here.
author: Tori S.

description:
We went for the all you can eat hot pot dinner. We were there early and got a spot but it started filling up.

I think what separates The Pot's from the other hot pot places is the base broth is super good. It even got a thumbs up from my very particular Chinese parents. Another plus was the extremely competent woman working there. The ceilings are pretty high and the ventilation was okay. My mother sometimes feels like she has a hard time breathing in some of these places but she was okay at this restaurant.
author: Dian X.

description: This place is horrible. Once you walk in here, your glasses will be fogged up and will eat unpleasantly. There is bad ventilation in here, when you come sit down and eat, sweat drips down from the ceiling. Wait time is far too long for both getting a table and getting served. Menu's aren't constant and the price is way too high. I suggest going somewhere else. There are much better hot pot places that charge less and have better waiters. This place is overrated and I am not coming here ever again.
author: Samuel W.

description: This place is good. All of the ingredients are fresh and it's really cool that you basically cook your own food. Around $25 per person for all you can eat, so come here on an empty stomach haha. Been here a few times now, and it never disappoints
author: Allen K.

description:
Yesss!! after a long day of biking around sf and across the golden gate in thick fog and super cold weather....all I wanted was some hot pot. Found this place on Yelp (even though I was debating between several with good reviews). Made a reservation, which was a good thing because they were super busy when we went (around 6:30pm?). Everything here was pretty good. My only complaint is that their spicy miso soup base was sooo salty. I had to dilute it with the other soup just because it was hard to drink the soup. All the ingredients was of decent quality and the taste was good. For AYCE, I think this was standard pricing or maybe a little more pricey? I'm not sure. But despite how busy they were, service was pretty good. 

Got to try some other AYCE hot pot places in SF now!
author: Isabella L.

description:
I admit I'm a hot pot virgin...I was a hot pot virgin! The choices were vast and varied. We started with lamb, pork, white fungus, pak choy, shrimp dumplings, flat rice noodles, tofu, enoki mushrooms in a pork broth. OMG, this should say it all. The meats were plentiful but what makes a great hot pot is the freshest vegetables and sides! This is like a Shabu shabu style on a larger scale. Second round we got sliced prime rib, taro dumplings, sweet egg dumplings (imagine sweet custard in shumai wrap), more vegetables. Ugh, had to undo top button on jeans to stuff anymore into me.
Service was ok, had to ask for waters and more tea but they were busy.
The best part of all this was $25 per person for 2 hrs of nonstop noshing on great healthy food (except for the quantity we consumed)!
DEFINITE must eat!
author: Lana H.

description:
We came here in a group of 12 last night as middle school reunion. The service was excellent, the owner was so nice and generous to us. He offered free drinks to us :)

The menu offered a lot of choices too! My favorite one was the "nai huang jiao" I don't know it in English, but its made of egg. Kinda of like custard maybe? The lamb and beef were fresh too. I will definitely come back next time whenever there is a big party of friends. The price varies depending on the day you are going. If I remembered correctly, sunday-thursday $22.29 & friday & sat $24.99.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Happy Birthday Justin!!!!

8 of us altogether, so 4 people at each pot.

I learned a new acronym yesterday, it's AYCE. I had to look it up on Yahoo, it means All You Can Eat.

AYCE hot pot dinner: Sun-Thu $22.99 & $24.99 for Fri + Sat
They have other items too, not just AYCE. You can order individual items, but I'm sure if you're eating a full meal or a big eater like me, you'd go for the AYCE. I think it's much cheaper.

I suggested this place because a friend suggested another hot pot place which was more expensive. I am a starving college student or just a poor one, so searched for a place that's cheaper & more affordable for me. I chose this place because it is relatively close to me, it's one of the cheaper AYCE hotpot places (I think), & I've been here before. Good thing they all liked it, because oh mannn it would have been my fault for this restaurant choice. They liked how there is seafood and not just meat & veggies.

I was so excited when I found out yesterday that we were going to hot pot. I guess anytime you hot pot, it's fun & worth getting excited for.

The last time I came here, I gave them 4 stars. This time, I must admit, they deserve a 5. Why a higher rating this time? I felt jipped when I ordered more than $23 worth of hot pot stuff per person, I tried to not exceed it but we did.

I would suggest installing more restrooms. Most hot pot places only have 1 for female & 1 for male or just 1 restroom altogether. I mean you're drinking ALL THAT SOUP & there are other people in the restaurant that are drinking that delish custom made communal soup. I would imagine a line forming out the door just for the restroom. Maybe restaurants don't see the need for it, maybe I'm just crazy. I guess it would cost more to install & for the water bill, if more people had to use the restroom there, therefore jacking up the prices on food. Maybe if there's only 1 restroom, the restaurant thinks that some people wont use it and will just wait to pee. I guess there really isn't a need for it. Usually only 1 person in line.

Well...onto the food.
We picked the pork bone broth, since that & the spicy are the 2 most popular. Me and another friend can't eat spicy, so just pork bone broth.
We didn't stop, we're eating machines. 

We ate beef balls, all sorts of noodles, various meats, assorted choy, mussels, deep fried taro, tofu & all that...so much food, I probably can't sleep tonight. It was so good but towards the end, the bottom started to burn and everything tasted like it. If you're done with your 1st sheet and want more food, just ask for another & they'll give it to you.

The burner thing burned out, so we told them & they changed it right away. The water started to boil much faster.

A friend and I were the food champs, I must say he ate a lot more than me though. Have to finish it if you order it.

For 8 people it was $240.07, the restaurant included tip already, I guess because we had more than 6 people. It was nice coming with this crew, they'll eat the real Chinese kind of stuff, like pig intestines, willingness to eat anything on that list. If you're all going to add it to the same pot, you should have similar palate. Whatever anyone else adds, you're going to taste it in your soup. 

Good service.
Variety of food.
Clean.
Attentive.
Full house, that's when you know it's good. I hate going to empty places, makes you wonder why it's empty.
author: Kylie L.

description:
First of all, its an all you can eat place, which makes it a bomb! 

Second they serve good quality meat, other fantastic goodies such as an assortment of dumplings & meatballs, a good variety of noodles and fresh veggies. 

The best way to enjoy your hotpot experience in The Pots is to have your hotpot with the spicy broth. Yes, the one with floating chilies and spices!
author: Gordon O.

description: Best hot pot spot in my opinion! Wide range of foods to choose from and waiters and waitresses are on point.
author: Tina D.

description:
Lately I have been bitten by the Hot Pot bug, so I decided to check out The Pots after reading the reviews on Yelp. This place had a lot of pros, but also had some cons.

The menu had an extensive soup base and dumpling/meat/shrimp ball selection. We chose the pork bone and spicy miso broths; they were both well seasoned and flavorful. The meats, dumplings, meat/shrimp balls, etc. we cooked in the broth were tasty and well seasoned as well. The dumplings were very good. Also, I thought the price was pretty good for an AYCE establishment. Lastly, the servers were cool and asked us how we were doing a few times. Our soup was refilled a couple times; overall, a nice experience.

Although some items on the menu were pretty extensive, the meat and veggie selection were a bit underwhelming. The meats were good, but I was expecting a little more. Also, the sliced beef - while tasty - was a bit large and unwieldy. I would have preferred smaller cuts. The veggies were quite disappointing...they actually looked like they had seen better days and were in need of a washing. I prefer a larger selection of fresh veggies that have been properly washed and cut for hot potting.

When we were making our own sauce, I happened to notice the chopped cilantro looked a bit discolored in some areas...upon further digging, I realized the entire bottom half of the cilantro was dark green and some parts looked liquified. Basically, the cilanatro was rotting away in the dish...that was really gross. 

Soup bases were definitely tasty, but loaded with salt/msg. When we first started, I was raving about the soups, but after a while, the salt/msg became a little much. Even with additional soup being added, it was still quite salty. I drank a lot of tea to counteract the saltiness, which helped. If you find it a bit salty at times, water/tea/soda might help.

I think this place is pretty good...but I still think Hot Pot Garden is my fave for now. But I'm excited to try some other Hot Pot places or try to create the perfect home Hot Pot. If you have a good Hot Pot soup base recipe, please share!!!

Try this place out and see if you like it
author: MishEddie G.

description:
This is good hot pot.

Been here twice and left very happy both times. 

Got the spicy broth and always the prime rib cuts -delicious. All the vegetables seem fresh and the staff are really nice. 

Tip: If you don't get the all you can eat you get to take home your leftovers and unless you are crazy hungry you will not be able to finish it all.
