Two of us spent $30 total, ate as much as we could and got two more meals. Just be careful when you order, circle the english words of what you want because the check box doesn't always line up.

Definitely will be coming back :)
author: Devin B.

description:
This place is alright--I like Hot Pot Garden better. They like to charge $1 per person if you want a split pot and I believe it was $24.99 per person for AYCE--$1 less than weekend prices. Be prepared to pay with cash only. Based on reviews from November, I figured they would have fixed their credit car machine but I guess not...

Came here on a Tuesday night with my parents and unfortunately service was a little slow and it wasn't even busy. Staff didn't do a great job of making sure our broths were refilled and it was hard to flag them down for more food because they were too busy standing around the TV. In the end, I definitely at my money's worth; my mom and dad gave up and just stared at me chowing down different meats. I do have to say that the lamb was hard and chewy... but everything else I had was good. 

Although the food was not bad, I don't think I would come back here...
author: Hwan L.

description:
Waited for an hour for a 4 persons table on Sat night. 

The soup base is flavorful and the ingredients are fine. However, there's one thing I really dislike. They simply didn't hire enough staff. You can see the 3 staff running here and there. I'm pity for them.
author: Mag L.

description:
The AYCE is a pretty great deal for the amount of food you get! The quality is pretty decent and I was so full by the end of the meal that I could barely move. 

I don't quite remember what we ordered (because we ordered SO much), but I can attest that all of it was delicious and our servers were very accomodating.

Score! I'll be back again so next time, I'll definitely remember the specifics of our orders.
author: Kristina K.

description:
$23 all u can eat sun-thurs
$25 all u can eat fri-sat

Beef tongue, stuffed fried tofu, hot pot egg yolk bun,
author: Andrew H.

description: Went there w/ a friend who loves hotpot.  Ordered the spicy hot & regular as soup base.  Added a varieties of vegetables & tofu, meat (slices beef, pork, meatballs),seafood (shrimp balls, fishballs, shrimps, etc.).  Overall, food and place looks clean and fresh.  Service is a litle slow, but overall experience is good.  We both enjoy the outing.
author: Denis Y.

description: There is a huge selection of various items to put in your broth! This place is great!
author: Michael L.

description:
My favorite hot pot place !

I love everything about this place, the atmosphere is nice and it's a convenient location for parking. The food is very very tasty and they have a wide variety of food for you to enjoy. I always get the all you can eat it's well worth it =).
author: Lisa Y.

description:
I want to go here every week! 

The Pot's is the best Shabu Shabu restaurant that I've been to in the city. It's clean with good service and amazing food. The Spicy Miso broth was to die for! The noodles were also very good! Dont forget to try the shrimp wontons and dumplings. 

The servers kept us busy with a seemingly never ending supply of meats and what was even more amazing was that there was a table of 30 or more people next to us. Despite that fact my group never felt neglected and I had a really great experience.  5 stars out of 5...would try again. I just gotta build up my appetite.
author: Sueann W.

description:
Oh my is this hot pot AMAZING! I was visiting a friend over Thanksgiving and this is how we started our week.  Although it is $25, it's all you can eat and there are a variety of authentic Asian ingredients.  We got the REALLY spicy broth and boy was it spicy! It was super flavorful.  However, if you don't like peppercorn this might not be the broth for you. 

This place is extremely authentic as everyone there was either speaking Chinese, Korean or Japanese. Not sure if there was one non-Asain there except my friend and I.  Next time I plan on getting a different broth just to try some variety.  

The only downfall is that although their are separate room the waitresses tend to forget about you.
author: Akta N.

description:
Definitely a better spot then most hot pot places in the city. I been here twice already and for $23 per person, it's pretty reasonable. This place use to be xbar I believe and I'm glad it's a hot pot place now instead of the waste of space xbar since it was pretty lame in there when I went. Very spacious inside and plenty of seating. They also have a room where you can have a private dinner with a group of friends.

So, for $23 you can eat ALL YOU WANT. Order as much as you want, whenever you want. Just make sure you finish you're food so you won't get charged for not wasting it. You sit down, pick a soup base and check off anything you want on that sheet of paper. I've tried the pork base one and the chili one with lots of peppercorns in it. The pork one was super bland. I couldn't taste anything but broth. But if you decide to order that, make sure you ask for some satay on the side and mix it in with your dipping soy sauce looking thing and that makes it much more better to eat. 

There's so much items to choose from that I can't remember all or everything I had. I probably tasted all the balls there is, prime rib slice and lamb slices, tofu, spinach, Chinese lettuce (romaine lettuce), taro thread, udon, pork blood, shrimp, dumplings, and definitely the custard crystal dumpling ball. Everything was pretty standard. All the balls were probably purchased in bulks by those big companies but I believe they make their own dumplings or something? That's what they said. But what IS good was the custard balls. The only thing was that I wish they would boil it in PLAIN water and bring it to the table instead of having us do it in whatever broth we have. I don't think custard dumplings in pork broth or chili broth is very appetizing but when I did eat it with the pork broth, I poured tea over it and that help take out any pork flavor. Very gooddd..

Service can be very slow and you will feel very rushed when it gets busy. The owner literally wanted to kick us girls out when we literally sat down for 30mins, didn't even finish our first round of food, and still had food in our mouth before he asked if we were done. Ummmmm does it looook like I'm done eating? Does it loooook like I'm the type of girl that eats only ONE round of food when it's all you can eat? HELL NO! BUT I would come back anytime because I don't like Coriya hot pot or that River Hotpot place on Clement.

**Oh, and this is where Patra B and I first met! What a coincidence!!**
author: Juliane N.

description:
Waited about 20mins for a seat in sat night. It was well worth it!

It was my first hot pot experience. Or those of you who do not know, you cook your own food in a hot broth. It's kind of like Japanese fondu.  The beef was excellent and they had plenty of fresh veggie options for my friend who is cutting back on red meat. Overall the experience was a lot of fun.
author: Sarah L.

description: Quite a busy place during dinnertime. The meat was fresh and sliced well. I was a big fan of the beef tongue. I wanted more from the sauces though. And procedurally they take away the cilantro, onion, garlic which means you have to ask for more when you need it. Slightly inconvenient.
author: Wilson W.

description:
Fellow yelpers, I'm guilty of culinary infidelity.  As much as I love going to Sichuan Spring in Highland Park NJ, I've given my heart to The Pot's in SF.  

During our latest trip to SF, and it happened to be on a cold rainy evening, we decided to go have hot pot.   We ended up at the pot's and were glad we did.

We had the broth with the clear/spicy soup and the broth was absolutely delicious.  The things we really enjoyed were the yams, the lotus roots, the rice noodles and the vege. dumplings.  Service was extremely friendly, and the place seemed very clean.

One point worth noting.  The other people with me were vegetarians, and when the waitress replenished the broth, we asked her if it was vegetarian.  Turns out it wasn't.  SHE ADMITTED THAT, AND GAVE US A FRESH POT OF SOUP.  Absolutely remarkable.  I guess it would have been easy to lie to us, but the fact that she changed it out really scored mega points with us.
author: SG D.

description:
This place is solid. I love how it's all you can eat all the time. Of course, that means, it's chaotic, so you gotta be patient. Order a lot up front so you don't have to keep bugging them to bring more.

I thought the quality was pretty good considering it's all you can eat. We split our pot with spicy sichuan and pork bone broth. The sichuan is pretty spicy, it has tons of red chilis floating in it. The dumplings are a must, as is the winter melon.
author: Kenny J.

description: Wow, what a great deal!  $25 for all you can eat with a ton of options, including Xiao Long Bao.  The spicy miso broth was great, and the quality of the various meats and veggies were good as well.  If this place served beer I'd make it 5 stars.  Easy to get to as well on the N-Judah.  We'll be back for sure.
author: Joshua W.

description: Really nice hotpot place, the staff made you feel very welcome. The all you can eat menu has so many options and all are decent Chinese hotpot food. Definitely I will come back a lot.
author: Maggie W.

description:
I came here for a friends bday dinner and His friends HIGHLY recommended this place.

Spacious seating restaurant, cantonese style (I should say Hong Kong style) and friendly staff.

All-you-can-eat Hot Pot for $23 (sunday thru thur) not including drinks and special meats

Meat was ok, seafood was decent, and veggies were ok fresh, I just like the varieties they had that other places doesn't offer.  The only thing I didn't like is the selection of sauces (didn't have much to mix it).  

Filling, but with that amount of money ($30 per person) I can get a nice American dinner.
author: Helena H.

description:
I've never had hot pot at a restaurant before - I've always gone to a friend's home. This was for a friend's birthday dinner, so we had a lot of people. I arrived late because my bus ran late, so I can't quite rate the full restaurant experience. It seemed like they accomodated our whole party in a little side room which comfortably fit everyone there. I liked the spicy miso base. Like I said, I arrived late, so they gave me a pair of chopsticks, but no one gave me any water or refilled on water so I was stuck drinking my friends' water glasses. 

I think it was a bit pricey for what it is - I'd rather pay for AYCE shabu shabu than hot pot. 

Overall, the food and atmosphere seemed very average, 3 stars, minus 1 for the lack of service (people who arrive late deserve water too!) and price.
author: Lena Y.

description:
Clean, fast service w/a smile and great hot pot - minus the rice, the white rice sucked to be honest...
 Nevertheless, the spicy broth was just that - spicy! Fish, shrimp balls, dumplings, different kinds of shrooms and vegetables made for a great night of all you can eat hot pot.
author: Mike S.

description:
I came here on Christmas Eve for dinner with my family and best friend.  When I went in it was pack and many were waiting.  I had a reservation for 6:30 pm and we were seated pretty promptly.   Other than that the service was pretty bad afterwards.  My friend went to the restroom and they overheard employees talking about being overbooked.  Since the employees rarely go check up on us I figure we should just order 3 beef after our 1st one so we don't have to ask over and over, but the brought one.  The whole evening we only had 2 plates of beef.  We order a second round and waited for 20 mins and no food came.  We weren't full but screw it, so we asked for our check which came pretty quick.  

There was 3 adults and 1 toddler.  They charged us four adults and we told them 3 adults and a toddler.  They changed it to 3 adults and 1 child.  PARENTS BEWARE:  THEY CHARGE 3 YEAR OLD TODDLER  $13.99.  I mean seriously even when they go to buffet like Kome they only charge like $5.99.  $13.99 is like a teen price.  How much can they eat?  All my son ate was maybe like 1 or 2 udons. My husband left a tip, and he thought about it after, we should haven't tip any since they tipped themselves.  Where on the menu do you put kids price and their price range??

I come here a few times a year, and sometimes I go to Hot Pot Garden.  If Hot Pot Garden took reservation I would have went there and wouldn't have come here.  Now with this experience I think you lost a customer.
author: AB H.

description:
There are different broths to choose from, if you can't decide on one, they offer a half and half pot for an additional fee.

So you get your paper menu and you check whatever you want. I use numbers to indicate how many portions I want. They have a wide selections of meat.. From meats to vegetables, they have it! The portions can be small so, when you're ready for more just ask for another menu or tell the server exactly what you want. 

Each table has a condiments caddy to dress up the bowl of soy sauce each person gets. Parsley, green onion, garlic and chili flakes. As the soup can be bland at times, this is the only flavoring you have.

It's all you can eat, so bring your stretchy pants and enjoy your time!
author: Serinda O.

description:
In China, it would be 3-stars. But the hot pot craze hasn't fully hit on this side of the pacific. So this is the best we've got in SF.
Get the traditional split hotpot with sichuan spice on one side and savory on the other. The sichuan spice side was not nearly spicy enough and contained too few hua jiao peppers.
Both the white fungus and black (wood ear) fungus are not to be missed. The thinly sliced tender beef and lamb are perfect. Add some greens, potato, fish balls, lotus and mushrooms, and you're set. They did run out of Tsingtao (Qingdao) Shame on you. And as other Yelpers point out, hey chefs, whip up some more sauces, especially a sesame-based sauce and a house sauce.
Will definitely return, just wish the actual hot pot was a tad bigger. Service was wonderful btw, and on a busy Sat night.
author: Brian J.

description:
OK OK OK.... here are my opinions

Likes - L 
Dislikes - D 

L- all you can eat 
D - only if you can get the food that you want 
L - great broth 
D - only the pork broth, the spicy one is not good... no Anthony bourdain style for you 
L - Next to N Judah 
D - no parking 
L - eat right away 
D- only if you get your food on time 
L - Best dumplings because they are homemade 
D - which dumplings were good again? shit shit shit.. 
L - the owner is super nice, and very eager to change whatever we needed to feel comfortable 
D - How do we hotpot at this place, and how the hell do we get a re order 
L - The fresh garnish rack was to my likings 
D - They didn't have enough garnish trays for everyone.. :( 
L - The SHRIMP WAS SO FRESH AND DELICIOUS 
D - I wish I spoke Chinese so I could get someone's attention for some more shrimp 

All in all.. I wish they had a system where they had a flag that you would put up so we could get our server's attention so we can get a refill of our food, or beer, or drinks, or even more napkins.. NOT ENOUGH NAPKINS..... 

let's just say.. make a laminated how to hotpot at the pot's and you'll get more people in and out faster, and not so darn discouraged on how to hot pot there... but I liked the flavors, and how fresh everything was that I will come here again.. :) btw they have these red bean desserts that were delicious when I was there.. ask if they have it :)
author: Nina M.

description:
Just to say at first Grassland is my first and favorite ever so this review will be a comparison between the 2. 

Even I say Grassland is my favorite, the hot pot here definitely has a better quality. The soup here is more tasty (We ordered AYCE - half half, spicy and bones, I believe) My soup was spicy  and it was delicious! The meat was fresh and tasted fresh. You definitely should try the cheese beef balls. They were good. However, they don't have as many choices as Grassland and you will be charged if you didn't finish your dish.
The place is quite small, which made a long line when we were there. We had to wait for more than 1 hour and we were exhausted. Still, the food was good and we chose AYCE so it was not too bad for us haha

So overall, since I'm a big eater lol I still prefer Grassland but if you prefer quality than quantity, The Pot's is definitely for you.
author: Tran N.

description:
Cold days = perfect for hotpot. They are located in sunset on Judah. They are one of the few restaurants in that area. A great local spot. Prices are very reasonable, soup base is good and consistent. Weekends they get fairly busy, so plan ahead! 

-SFCG
author: Mike H.

description:
All you can eat hot pot for $23???  I'm game!  

This place is my friend's friend's friend's restaurant, and its really close to my house, so I finally made my way over with Lester W. to try it out.  We got there pretty early...5:45...so we got seated right away since there was only one other table eating dinner.  

This is not your typical all you can eat hot pot where you just get meat and veggies.  You get to pick from about 5 different types of broth, and then you get to choose from a wide variety of items to cook.  They give you a piece of paper with different categories, and you just mark down how many orders of each item you want.

We went with the spicy broth( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/96Wv2KhAEWpdiWmWH241Fw/l ) which ended up being a little bit too spicy for us, but still pretty tasty.  It had ALOT of dried chilies and peppercorns which kept getting caught in all our food.  The beef was nice and fatty and cut thinly so you only had to briefly swish it in the broth to cook it( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/4bGYrBo5kVsjKd0zR5J_pQ/l ).  I highly recommend the handmade fish/shrimp/meat balls( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/9i_x5SvIDubqm7OHETydBQ/l ).  They're much tastier than the regular ones( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/RLl57Omv32ncSMGmlr0foA/l ).  We ended up ordering alot of food and were quite full by the end of the meal.  

The restaurant is very....."Asian".  There is a plasma tv showing HK pop stars singing and dancing.  Quite entertaining, but I have no idea what they're saying.  The service was really good.  They were quite attentive and kept coming by to clear our empty plates.  They even give you sesame balls for dessert...yum!
author: Patra I.

description: Been coming here with my friends for the past 4 years. Love this place! The soup is always yummy. The selection of meat, dumplings, and veggies are plenty. Everything is always fresh.  My favorite part off the meal is ordering the sweet egg yolk bun for dessert. It's pretty unique because you have to dump it into your boiling soup to cook it. Staffs are very quick and friendly.  Our soup and water/tea gets refilled pretty quickly which is a plus. Will definitely continue being a regular here!
author: Sandy F.

description: Best hot pot I've had outside of Hong Kong!! Highly recommend this place!
author: Cathrine A.

description: Neither Szechuan nor Northern China style. However I really love it here! Fresh meat and vegetables, tasty soup base (we ordered both spicy and non-spicy), wonderful dipping (soy sauce+garlic+green onion+cilantro)! It's so close to my home that it has become my must-bring-friends-here restaurant.
author: Shia L.

description: What can I say about this place. It is amazing! I love the options for all you can eat hot pot. Yesterday is the day of only getting prime rib and udon noodles with a few measly veggies, This place does it right giving you a rediculous selection of items to choose from. Dumplings, enoki mushrooms, tofu skin rolls, daikon, fried pumpkin, prime rib, lamb, fish fillet, ect and the list goes on. If you have a large party make reservations because seats fill up fast and you could be stuck with an hour wait if your not careful. I absolutely think this place is one of my favorite places in SF.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Love the dumplings there.  Great assortment.

We tried the spicy schichuan, spicy miso, and HK satay.  All were very tasty broths.

Beef and lamb slices are slightly above average quality.  

Service on the slower side, but staff is always very nice.
author: Sam T.

description: I have to say that this place is not that astonishing but they surely have a great menu in here. The food is unquestionably fresh and the broth that they have is as warm as anything out there.
author: Steve Y.

description: This place is beyond amazing as if u can't tell by the incredible line that starts from 6pm. If u love Hot pot beyond the simple and vapid basics, this is the place for u.
author: Ti C.

description:
Went to The Pot's on a weekday to get their awesome special.  $16.95 for the first person and $1 for the second person.

There are a lot of reviews for this place for all-you-can-eat, so I thought i'd shed a little insight on the weekday deal.  Couple of notes regarding the deal...only available on Monday to Thursday(?) and not all you can eat.

The server had explained to me that it's not THAT much food, and if you're hungry, you shouldn't order it.  I was pretty hungry but decided to order it anyway.

What you do get in the deal is rice noodles, napa cabbage, two shrimps, two mussels, tofu, two beef balls, two fish balls, one meatball, one dumpling, and three slices of thinly sliced meat (either beef or lamb, you get to choose one).  You don't get a choice of broth, so you'll get the chicken broth.  Each person gets what I listed above...which isn't bad.  It ended up being a lot of food and I got really full.  We we're going to order some rice, but it was $1.50 per bowl, and they were still cooking it. Probably would've complemented the meal a bit more.

Based on the ingredients we got, the food was only alright.  I've definitely had better hot pot at home before.  The dumpling was probably the best, next would be the thin sliced beef.  Comparing this deal to a place like shabu house...shabu house is much better.  However, my opinion would probably change if I had the all you can eat.

The deal itself isn't bad.  My friend and I walked out paying $23 total including tax and tip.  Not bad to get full for two people IMO. Probably won't go back for the deal...maybe for the all you can eat.
author: Jason M.

description:
So far the best hotpot I have ever had in SF.
I love choices, so the variety of soup base was an attraction for me.
The coconut pork bone soup base is yummmm, make sure you have some before it gets greasy (after putting all the meat and fried pumpkin in it, there is a layer of grease floating on top of the soup).

Veggies and tofu are fresh, I do not know the meat part.
My favorite is mushroom, flat rice noodles and fried tofu skin.

It is hot pot, you pick whatever you like, the key is to have a variety of food.
And it is all you can eat for under $25, not totally cheap but if you have a stretchable tummy like me, it is a good deal.

Servers are friendly and very attentive, adding soup, bringing napkins and water.

Great for family and friends getting together and kinda of romantic, in a way.
author: Yi Z.

description: My friend took me here for the first time and I was a little confused on how to order. The service there was not the greatest but we definitely got what we paid for. It was about $25 per person for all-you-can-eat. I really liked it! I would definitely come back again.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Wow, all you can binge eat for ~$30 including tip?  I'm not really sure it's possible to go wrong here.

I think their ingredients are pretty good quality - the beef and lamb were both good, but the fish was my favorite.  Their dumplings were all delicious as well.  They also have a pretty big selections of vegetables, noodle, tofu, etc.

What really surprised me was how good their dessert...um...balls were.  It may seem weird to put these sweet dumpling (filled with either taro, custard, or salty egg custard) things into these savory broths, but really, it doesn't taste too weird.  It doesn't get too savory just boiling in the broth.  Besides, salty + sweet is all the rage now, no?  That said, don't put it in the spicy broth...that's just perverse.

Only semi-minus is the service, as the others have pointed out.  It can be a bit slow and they sometimes miss things that you have ordered.
author: jon y.

description:
tip: make reservations or suffer long wait times.  also if come in large group using 2 portable stoves, they give you things that are not what you order, they hand you crappy items first to fill you up like shrimp dumplings and siu mai; when that's gone, they actually give you the stuff you order on the 2nd try (via 2nd paper order)

portable stoves suck because they are elevated, hard to see what's in the pot and need to change the portable gas canister (went out on both of our stoves); a table with a lowered center portion would help (carve hole in middle); fairly large restaurant in a crap location (dark, residential, out of the way); $25 (18% tips if 6 or more i believe) acye hot pot with various broth such as tomato potato, pork bone, satay, and spicy; fresh veggies, excellent fat beef and lamb, homemade meatballs very good (though not as good as little fat sheep), tasty taro pieces, cool desserts with the crystal egg yolk dumpling; only gripe is no fried fish skin, this is huge for hk style hot pot and they lack big time.
author: Jacky K C.

description: First time going to this place got recommended by a friend. Got to say the food was amazing i can not complain, their kobe beef slices were so juicy and delecious probably better then most places i have to say., The only reason i did not make it a full 5 star is it took them 15 min each time to get the raw food out and i had to find my server every time when i wanted to put some more food in the pot other then that great place deff recommend
author: Alex S.

description:
This place replaced my weekly craving for Little Fat Lamb and Shabu House. The spicy sichuan soup base is what I always get, and it's also what I always pay for the next day. The food is great, the quality of the meet and others are... okay. For the price though, it beats hot pot city.

The only complaint I have about this place is that sometimes when things are ordered, it's never received. Even when we ask for it a few times, and eventually we just forget or move on from it.
author: Alan L.

description:
great place to grab hot pot. There are a bunch of restaurants doing hot pot now, but this place makes all their cuttle fish balls, meat balls, by hand. Most of their stuff is made in house which is why I keep coming back and their ingredients are very fresh as well. 

You definitely have to try their custard filled dumplings. Sounds really odd, but SO good! When i'm here I order at least 2-3 orders of them so my friends could try it and they usually run out quick. It tastes like a custard bun but instead of a bun it's mochi skin. Something everyone should try. 

If you have friends that can really eat, definitely should come here. Parking can be a b***** on the weekends, so go early to beat the crowd.
author: Jessica L.

description: They gave us 3 pretty damn banging soup bases off AYCE for 2 people. The meat was really good and I was generally a really happy camper. Nothing to gripe about; I had a shit eating grin throughout most of the meal.
author: Donald C.

description: My best friend and I come here a lot every time he comes back from college. It is definitely one of the more AFFORDABLE hot pot places in the city. I would definitely recommend this place if you cannot afford to pay like $25+ for hot pot. The stuff here is really good, it is rarely ever crowded. I recommend the porkbone for the soup. and their menu is actually quite extensive. Prime rib beef, lamb, beef marinated in wine, and a wide assortment of other foods available that are not at other places.
author: Wells Y.

description: The Pot's is one of the best hot pot place in the sunset...Great selections and friendly staffs.
author: Jim T.

description:
FINALLY. Came here again with a few friends after craving this place for weeks!

We arrived at 8:30pm on a Thursday night. It was a bit crowded, but we were seated pretty quickly.

We got half pork bone broth and half spicy miso. OH my goodness, both broths were so good and flavorful. We ordered lots of meat, enoki mushrooms, udon and another type of noodle... and a bunch of other things I can't really recall. But geez, that broth makes the food taste SO good. 

Service was better than usual. They actually came and took care of us without us having to call them over, which was never the case so many times during past visits, so it was a nice surprise.

Overall, I love this place and if I have money to spend and friends to bring, I'll be here!
author: Krissel A.

description:
The Pots is a new restaurant in our 'hood, The Sunset. If you're looking for a neat dining experience come on out our way, and if you live here take a stroll over to The Pots. 

As the name suggests you cook your food in pots of boiling broth at your table (shabu shabu).  My usual complaint about shabu shabu style dining will remain, and that is if you are vegetarian you end up paying a lot of money to boil tofu and veggies in a broth - but it is still fun. 

This restaurant is new, and family run. The owner was our waiter.  He was extraordinarily friendly and helpful. You can tell he is excited about opening his own restaurant, and perhaps a bit nervous.  He poured water into my glass which had soda in it before which meant I enjoyed some 7up flavored water.  Also, several of our items were forgotten or mismatched. I'm sure he'll improve as he gains experience. Both he and the other staff were attentive and answered all of our questions. 

The food was fantastic if you like this sort of thing. The dishes come out looking kind of funny but when you cook them in your hot pot.. yummy. Fresh varieties of tofu and a variety of vegetables and vegetarian broths will make vegetarians happy here. And you can get two kinds of broth if you want to keep meat separate. The homemade shrimp ball with cheese inside was surprisingly tasty.  We also had taro root, cabbage, dumplings, two kinds of mushrooms, and my partner had beef and some other meaty things.

We had a very spicy broth,  and a tomato, potato broth. Both were satisfying on a chilly evening in the Sunset. 

It's fun to cook your own food at the table and experiment with different cooking times and textures!  It would be perfect for a unique first date. It's worth a trip to the Sunset for The Pots. When you're done, walk down to Irving street and have a bubble tea or sing Karaoke at Blue Moon.
author: Mark S.

description:
Great service.  Great broth.  Great home-made dumplings.  Great meat.  Great sauce.  What else????  Awesome!!!!!! 

This is the only hot pot place I'll ever go to as long as I live here in San Francisco.  

Make sure you come with a big appetite!!!!
author: W C.

description: Really good, but i kinda feel like a sucker paying $30 for a bowl of soup :)
author: Michael E.

description: The food is great - awesome selection of hotpot components, comes with tea, and you can take your time.  They also take reservations, which is great for groups.  I do kind wish they had a better description or pictures of all the ingredients so you get a better idea of what you're ordering - might lead to less wasted food too.  But the main reason I dock the stars are: 1. extremely understaffed - I had to get up a couple times to communicate with the waiters, even before the dinner rush.  2. So warm inside! A place that relies on serving big pots of boiling food might want to consider turning up the AC for a less...sweaty...dining experience ;)
author: Yushan K.

description:
I went kayaking in Sausalito on my birthday, and after spending a few hours in the moonlit evening sloshing around in the water, I knew what I wanted to eat. Hot flippin' pot! It took us some time to get seated, even though we arrived at like 8:45 PM on a Saturday night and had made a reservation. The placed was PACKED.

But omg O. M. G. I was having a great day, but hot pot made it even better. My friends are the bestest and did all of the ordering, but the few dishes stood out in my mind. The grilled pumpkin, which was recommended to me by my friend, is awesome - doesn't need to be cooked too much, because then it disintegrates into a million pieces. My other friend went crazy ordering the dumplings, almost all of which were good, though the shrimp cheese balls were divisive, I was like shrimp cheese ball you cray, would think twice before ordering that one again. Being pros at gorging ourselves, we largely avoided ordering noodles and drinking water. The waiters, while not the most friendly in the world, provided us with attentive service, especially as the crowd at the restaurant thinned out - they even helped us out with plates and utensils for a German chocolate cake that another friend made for me.
author: Sidney L.

description:
The slow service and uncleanliness of the overall restaurant made this a very unpleasant dining experience.  Since everyone comes here for the all you can eat deal, expect a very tiresome wait.  The lighting is jarring and the dining area was very uncomfortably crampt.

Though the broth was tasty, selection of ingredients fresh, and the deal a nice draw, I truly can not believe how slow service is.  You want a fast turnover in this type of restaurant.  And I wasn't pleased with the leftover food and wet spots that wasn't wiped off the floor.
author: Chris T.

description:
All you can eat hotpot during cold SF days are the best!

They were a bit backed up the night that we visited, but the owner was nice enough to come to our table and apologize for the delay. He also provided us with free drinks which I thought was pretty nice!

The soup base was pretty good, not super oily, and I enjoyed the dumplings the best! There was some delay with the soup base coming to our table, but the food came out pretty quick after.
author: M W.

description:
Finally, made the journey out here for hot pot.  Remember?  That chinese version of the latest Shabu craze?  I suppose this is one of the last hot pot places standing up against shabu.  

In any case, if there was a difference between the two (I don't think there is) then shabu is definitely winning.  For hot pot, at least theres a pork broth vs all spicy miso or what not.  And where shabu houses usually house sports bar vibes, The Pot's incorporates karaoke into the mix (very nice).

But to get those karoake rooms, you'd have to reserve about 10+ people and give about 45 mins of your time to learn the devilish machine which plays with your emotions and spits out chinese opera at the most unwanted time.  But how can you complain.  It's karaoke, and once you get that darn thing moving, you can sing to your heart's desire all the songs you want from Love Story, to How do I live, and so on (don't judge)

As for the food, it was ok.  Not great, but not terrible.  The variety is definitely there-from watercrest, to bok choy, to ong choy, and so on.  Tofu, tofu skin, dumplings, beef balls, fish balls.  Most of the ingredients are there.  The meat is rather thinly sliced and not to my liking, but hey, its the way it is.  They've got shrimp, calamari, pig intestine, pork liver, and more.  So with that, I guess I can prefer it over shabu sometimes.  Plus, for $23/person during the week, its not too bad.  

Alcohol: none.  And with 10 people celebrating, and a karaoke machine in the back, how can you noT?  But luckily the staff are really cool about hooking you up and letting you drink whatever it is to bring out those vocal chords.
author: Vincent K.

description: I love Chinese/Taiwanese hot pot so i was excited to be coming here. First, the customer service is HORRIBLE. Walked in, no one greeted us, we just stood there waiting, i made eye contact with literally 3 workers and no one said "hi" or "one min" or "how many people" nothing was said. It wasn't even that busy. they had like 5 workers on duty. Finally, we got seated i asked a couple questions and the guys attitude was just so rude. we got some ball things and other stuff. the ball things are so gross. We got beef, shrimp, and something else but they all tasted so rubbery and nasty.  and they didn't even bring us everything we asked for but whatever. I asked for some more water and literally saw the lady fill her pitcher in the sink and she came over poured it in our cups (NO ICE). maybe bc i'm from LA i refuse to drink from the sink but she could've at least hid it from us. honestly 25$ each person for all u can eat is not worth it because half of the menu is not worth eating. I wouldn't even pay $1 for half of the things they were selling AND the horrible customer service is just not my style.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I've been here a couple of times with friends and find it overall "ok." It's a bit of a drive for me to get here and so I doubt I'll go back given there are other Hot Pot style restaurant's I've been to that's just as good if not better.

The service is super friendly and pretty attentive given how busy it usually is here. The price is average for what you get given that it's all you can eat. 

Parking is a total BITCH here so be prepared!
author: Soozie H.

description:
While browsing for a restaurant to try out, my cousin saw that The Pot's was 4 stars and not very far from where we were.  We were hungry too, so all you can eat didn't sound bad at all.

We decided to go half clear soup half Szechuan.  I've been building up my tolerance in the last couple of years, but it's definitely not very high.  The assortment of peppers were really strong, and I found myself regularly coughing from inhaling the spicy aroma.  But it's not as bad as it sounds!  I stuck with the spicy broth the whole way, and felt extremely satisfied by the end of the meal.  Plus, the waiters fill it with clear soup as you eat, which helps to alleviate the heat.

We ordered spinach, lettuce, tofu, dumplings, udon, and order of chicken and fish, 3 plates of beef and 3 plates of lamb.  Of course, split into multiple orders as we saw fit.  I'd say the meat was all very good quality, and the servers didn't try to skimp on the meat as we ordered more.  In fact, it looked as if the plates got bigger (probably to try and deter us from ordering extra).  

The servers were all very nice and responsive, and never forgot a request.  The restaurant itself was very clean, unlike other hot pot places that can get very dirty.  I think it would be a great hangout spot for larger groups as well.

All in all, I really enjoyed my experience at The Pot's.  $24.99 is a little pricey compared to other all you can eat hot pots (like Coriya) but I'd say you get what you pay for.
author: Andrew T.

description: when you first walk in you, you get slammed by the hot steam. JESUS TURN THE VENT ON!
author: Jen C.

description: So good! So many choices! Great price for fantastic food! I'm very excited to be living around the corner from this place. I'll be returning soon!
author: Lorianna B.

description:
This is a review specifically for the all-you-can-eat.

So I'm not much of a hot pot person, but I thought the food here was AMAZING. I came with a fairly large party and we all had the all-you-can-eat. We tried a little of everything, and also ordered about 3 different broths. I thought the flavors were great and the service was decent. The only thing I didn't like was the price - about $33 after tax and tip. Was I full? Yes. Was the food great? Yes. But $33 is enough to get me full three times over. A fair price would've been around $25, tops. I will definitely go again, but I will probably order a la carte.
author: Gun-Ik P.

description: This is by far one of my favorite hot pot places in the city.  Their broth selections is plentiful with many menu items on their all-u-can eat package.  I usually get the cilantro preserved egg soup base.  Their meats and veggies are always fresh.  This place is way better then Hot Pot Garden...I don't understand why people pack that place and not this...though they do get a small line during busy dinner hours sometimes.  Parking sucks here...
author: Patrick C.

description:
I love this place. Chinese Hotpot and you can choose what ingredients you want. Very Similar to Little Sheep Hotpot and the food is fresh. This place is just closer since it is in the sunset district. 
You can have all you can eat for the price of $25 or if you go out with your girlfriends... Cheaper if you just order from the menu.
The portions are just right. You can choose spicy broth or non-spicy or both. 
Great for big parties, family, and couples. Very relaxing place... You can stay here and talk until your plate is empty. The waiters are very nice and attentive to what you need. 
Best to come here on cold/rainy days!!! I just can't wait to come here again!!!
author: Valerie A.

description:
This is my favorite hot pot place, because it reminds me of having hot pot at home :) 

The 4 of us came here, and it was busy so we waited for like 5 minutes while they cleaned up the table for us.

We ordered the Satay flavored soup, and they give you a piece of paper to tally down all the different food you want :D 

The Satay soup base was super good, not too spicy and just the right amount of flavor!! 

I loved their cuttlefish balls, and also their lobster balls alot. Their kobe beef & lamb was really fresh :). I also got a side order of fish filet and those were really fresh tasting too!! 

In the beginning when I first say down, their door was opened so it felt 
really cold from the breeze but eventually after you start eating then you will warm up!

I will be back there soon of course!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I traveled all the way from San Jose to the City on the day that made national news for the stormiest day of the year. And by "storm" I mean, thunder, lightning and seemingly all hell breaking loose. And after all that I of course deserved one, awesome dinner... 

First of all, it had been awhile since I had Chinese hot pot and I was craving an experience that would catch my taste buds. Leave it to the Sunset district on Judah to give me just that. 

When I got there it seemed like everyone had the same idea as me because there was about 10 parties of people before us on the waiting list - probably due to both the cold weather and it being around peak dinner time. I think my major issue of this place was that the wait was really long - around 1 hour and a half for my party of 2. The Pot is pretty small and of course at hot pot you would expect entire families and big groups of friends. A couple time during that wait I wanted to give up but the smell that this place gives was a deal breaker. Was the wait worth it?

When we finally got a table it was almost their closing at 10. On this particular night they kept the place open for much longer to accommodate people who were waiting for so long. The service was quick - which I can imagine is difficult for a staff so small on such a busy night. The waitresses and waiters were good about checking on us and were all very friendly to me a first-timer.

So to our POT filled with mild broth and endless possibilities. The thing about hot pot is that your pot definitely is a personalized pot between you and your party, filled with goodies and anything you desire. Since this place is AYCE with a great amount of choices, it definitely expands your creativity. 

My personal favorite items from the menu included: 
- Prime Rib Slice: Excellently sliced and a great quality of meat. :) It was easy for me to finish a whole plate by myself.
- White Mushrooms: I loved how these mushrooms soaked the broth and gave it a great texture to work with. 
- Rice Noodle: Any noodles are really hard to eat with hot pot due to the difficulty of getting it out of the pot without getting it all over the place - but definitely try an udon or rice noodle to add more substance to your meal.
- Hot Pot Egg Yolk Bun: This was the PERFECT way to end the meal. It was sweet and after you cook in the broth it just gives it an extra something. I wish I had room to eat about 5 more. 
- Cheese stuffed dumpling: I really can't remember what it was called on the menu but this dumpling was a great little cheese pick me up in between all the fish and shrimp balls we ate that night.

OVERALL, service was great and the food and overall experience you will get at this place is worth the wait. Even after a really long wait, I still gave this place 5 stars for it's value and its ability to bring both warmth and happiness to my stomach - definitely a special place for my 100th review :)
author: Tracy Joy K.

description: Enjoyable all you can eat hot pot place for a slightly expensive price compared to home preparation, but worth it for their soup stock and not having to clean the dishes afterwards. Came here with a big appetite and ate many plates of food. They have a good selection of vegetables, tofu, fungus, but lack a little in the meat and fish. I didn't have any room for dumplings, but they're not pre-made... Or steamed. Rather they're thrown into the pot which is weird for Xiao long bao. Came on a weekday, so it was pretty empty. Service was prompt. Although the dishes weren't the cleanest. Overall, this place offers standard fare hot pot with some good choices of soup, offering convenience and guaranteed fullness  at the expense of price point and meat selection
author: Lars B.

description: Been to the others in the city (eg Hot Pot Garden) but, I always come back to this one...
author: Jen H.

description:
I will always have great memories here I saw the Lakers lose Game 3 here on their flat screen (cue evil laughter).

Perfectly placed in the Sunset, as it's always cold there.

$25 gets you all you can eat (in two hours). Every meat item we picked was tasty, which included the sliced prime rib, the lamb, the pork, and the white fish.
author: Huey K.

description:
It's Friday night, it's raining, and the stomach is hungry, what to do! So I did what any hungry person would do, call up the homies and headed to hot pot at the Pot's!

I had reservations made for this place (which I strongly recommend, since it gets extremely busy during popular hours), so the wait was not relevant for this review. The waiter seated us in a private room as we had a large party. We must have ordered 2-5 of each item on their menu and then some more for seconds and thirds. The spicy broth and pork miso broth were both really good (I personally prefer the spicy broth). What stuck out in particular was the beef slices, wonton, and watercress plates - I can eat these all day here. Our party spend about 3 hours total here until we were totally stuffed and decided it was time to go, though there's a sign stating 2 hours of time limit (they didnt enforce this thankfully). Overall, it was a great experience and fills you up at a cost of about $32 dollars per person, including tip!
author: Ming S.

description:
Problem: COLD IN SF
Solution: Hot Pot

It's thanksgiving, it's cold, we didn't want turkey, so we went hot pot and we are warm and our guts are full.

Our night was interrupted by an elderly white guy complaining about the cold......drink some hot tea and eat your hot pot to stay warm, it's not rocket science......he didn't notice me drinking ice water because it was hot.....so the dude stormed out before he ate anything.
Interesting enough, 2 white dudes with their chinese girlfriends also came in, took off their jackets and had a jolly ol' time.

Verdict, Hot Pot good for winter cold
author: Bernard W.

description:
Good deal for all-you-can-eat. The beef & lamb quality is excellent. Everything else was fresh and there were a lot of choices to choose from. There is a separate sheet to order certain seafood items for an additional price between $4-$8. You are given a sheet to mark your orders and the waiters bring it out to you. The hot&spicy soup was very peppery, good and strong. The clear broth includes some spices as well. Also, they use standard hot-pot portable stoves which butane canisters need to be changed when it runs out. If your pot is not boiling enough, you should ask for it to be changed.

One star off for service. I don't blame the waiters because they were doing their best catching up to everyone's needs & also taking care of the money. Perhaps they need a few more helpers to help the service side because it was hard to catch their attention. Sometimes they forget items and need to be reminded a couple times. Some of the items marked never arrived. 

Other than that- a very satisfying meal. The wait was not too bad since it was a weekday.
author: Allyson L.

description:
We came here on a day that wasn't busy, so we got seated right away.  I have to say the guy that was working gave very good customer service!  Either he's really nice, or he's terribly strapped for cash and wants good tips!  Haha, but yeah, I think he's just a really nice person.

Everything is ALL U CAN EAT, NO a la carte.  It's 20 something dollars, I forgot how much, and there is a huge selection on the menu.  I absolutely LOVED their taro balls/yellow bun ball (or whatever it is.  I forgot what it's called).  I tried to search for this item at Ranch 99, to see if I can relive the moment I tasted these balls, but.. no luck!  Haha, looks like I'll have to pay 20 something dollars just to come here just to eat it!
author: Tina L.

description: Large collection of food. Good soup base. Not expensive for all you can eat hotpot.
author: Helen L.

description:
As my friends and I went to Little Sheep a couple of weeks ago, my friend said we should try The Pots because the concept was the same.  Late last week, we planned to come to The Pots for our weekly Sunday night dinner.  I was quite excited leading up the night.  The Pots...FAIL!

Two friends and I arrived at about 7:45pm last night.  To my surprise, only about half the restaurant was filled.  That should have been the first red flag as hot pot/shabu places usually have a wait, even on a Sunday night.

PRICING:
$22.95 Sun-Thurs all you can eat (2 hour time limit)
$24.95 Fri-Sat all you can eat (2 hour time limit)
$1 per person if you want the half/half soup base
Additional items available for additional cost - i.e. scallops, boneless chicken feet
Soft drinks, bottle drinks, and beer available for an additional cost
**There is a charge for wasted food**

FOOD:
The only thing "fresh" is the vegetables!
*Hot & Spicy Broth - ugh -spicy but lacks any kind of flavor!  It was filled with peppercorns, chili peppers, and (oddly) fennel seeds that got in EVERYTHING! Imagine cooking the thinly cut beef slices and chewing on peppercorns and fennel seeds that somehow found its way into your meat.  No bueno! 
*Beef and Cuttlefish balls - the type you buy from the market's freezer section
*Prime Rib Slices - the slices were cut uneven and the thinner cuts fell apart when placed in the broth to cook
*Lamb Slices - they were okay, but didn't taste quiet fresh
*Spam - it's out of a can, you can't mess up on spam
*Hotlinks - it's store bought, you can't mess up on slicing it
*Imitation Crab Meat - it should have been thawed out before giving it to us as a clump of frozen meat, all stuck together!
*Pork & Shrimp Dumplings - not bad and pretty flavorful
*Scallop Shumai - flavorful but something probably bought out of the freezer section
*Bean curd wraps - although it came out frozen, it was the most flavorful dish I had
*Flat Noodles - YUCK!  The noodles looked as if they were cooked, frozen, and then served to us...and they tasted even worse!
*Tofu - at least this was "freshly" cut from the package
*Spinach - the ONLY thing that was fresh

SERVICE:
What service?  Every time we needed something, we had to flag down one of the three guys working there.  I should use the term "working" loosely because it seemed as if only one guy was working and the other two were lost without his direction.  We had to ask for plates twice.  Apparently they don't come around to fill your hot pot with additional water/broth unless you ask.  Empty plates weren't taken away and continued to pile on the stand next to us as we continued to clear off our table for additional room.

PARKING:
Street.  Because The Pots is located in Richmond, expect to circle around the block a couple of times.

In the end, we were not satisfied and left with stomach cramps and aches.  The Pots - Never again!
author: Nicole S.

description:
I've bookmarked this place for over 8 months and I finally get to see what it's all about.  

I'm a hardcore fan of hot pots and I love it when there's just meat, veggies, and yes more meat. So far, The POT is the SPOT. For $25 it's an all you can eat HK style hot pot (not shabu shabu where you have limited varieties).  Some can say it's expensive, some say fair or some say cheap, it really depends on your appetite that day.  I was browsing through the menu and HOLY MOLY (a heavenly glow to the menu) there's a lotta food choices here, almost as many as Little Fat Sheep.  My friend went into maniac starving mode and started marking almost half of the menu. [FYI: They will charge you if you waste food.  Simply eat what you can first, but this hasn't happen to me yet.  Just because it's a buffet, it's not nice to let food go to waste, as my mother would say, "Think of the children in China!!!"]

I love their pork bone and clear soup broth, it's so refreshing I could just drink the whole pot.  Good meat, seafood and variety of veggies. They seriously brought the Hong Kong style over here, it's just good to have variety.  Great service, the waiters/waitress were all pretty nice and they didn't give me that "You're a freaking pig" look just because I ordered 4 plates of meat. =P  

I had to bring down one star because their price charge on the broths were a little misleading.  I ordered a Ying Yang pot which means you get to choose 2 broths and on the side of the menu it says $1.00 extra for additional ying yang broth.  So I chose Pork Bone and Clear Soup, when the bill came they charged $3.00 instead (not much but $$ is $$).  Apparently it's $1.00extra per person.  So if you have 10 ppl going prepare to pay an additional $10 for that extra broth.  I'm not complaining, it's still good, so they're on my good side for now =P  Definitely will return again w/ a larger group who can chow. And to quote Schwarzenegger, "I'll be back baby~" *wink*
author: Willis L.

description:
No reservations on the weekends, so peak wait times can be kind of long, but you can put your name on the list and come back. Each table has a 2 hour limit, too.

They have like 8 different kinds of broths. The spicy is probably too intense, but satay is good. You can also do a 1/2 and 1/2 pot to try different flavors.

Meats include beef, lamb, pork, mussels, chicken thigh, shrimp, a ton of different dumplings and balls.  There are lots of fresh vegetables, too (mmm enoki.)  Tip: tear up your leafy vegetables before you throw them in the pot.

It ends up being about $30 a person after tax/tip and sodas.
 
All you can eat hot pot definitely keeps you warm in the chilly, outer Sunset fog.
author: Marilyn H.

description: The lamb is good! For pork, chicken and fish are so-so.  The worst is the pork: thin, chewy. :(. And the food takes a while to come out from the kitchen.
author: D F.

description:
so much food.... thought i was gonna explodeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee. lol
so i found this place on yelp... and was really excited for it.
i came here with my bf... both of us were starving. and we ate so much. lol
i kept ordering tripe. lol my ultimate favorite!! we had pretty much everything on the menu... as for the meat we only got beef and lamb... but it was all pretty good.. true... i hate the fact that they charge us a dollar a person for split soup... its like. dude i get the exact same amount. what the eff. but whatever i guess.. lol

the balls with the taro and egg yolk custard... hmmm. i still cant decide how i feel about it... hahaha. it was interesting. but i guess good interesting....

it was certainly msg overload tho. i drank so muchhh water when i went home lol. but then again. it is hot pot.... hahaha

its not exactly like china's hot pot... i remember going there when i was a kid.. but its good enough.

plus its ALL YOU CAN EAT. i mean come on! and i thought the waiters were nice and attentive enough. u just gotta get their attention... like an asian resturant. they probably wont come and check up on u. but thats fine with me. let me grub!!!


all in all... lots of food. good enough price... too much msg. haha =]
author: Judy W.

description:
My friends took me here for my birthday, I loved the idea of hot pot! It was a cold day and it was all you can eat. So of course my Asian friends loved it, but at the end we all needed to take walks because we ate too much.

They had a wide selection of meat, seafood, noodles, and vegetables that we could choose from. I loved almost everything we chose! We could also split the "hot pot", so we got one side spicy and one side with pork bone. Pork bone is delicious (my choice) and my friends thought the spicy was delicious at first, but then it got too spicy so my friends couldn't handle it. 

I also liked how we got a private room. Yay for The Pots!
author: Tina F.

description:
So this is the second time the Hubs and I ate there.  The first time was great, no issue.  Just got home tonight and we are pretty pissed.  We ordered alacarte items - we did not want the all-you-can-eat.  We had 1 meat, 1 dumpling and 5 vegetables with the spicy miso soup.  

Service was semi-slow, lots of dirty tables, people in the smaller rooms had to keep walking out of the room to get service.  They took our tea pot becasue it was empty to refill it and I had to ask for it 20 minutes later becasue they were too busy to notice.  Also asked for cups of cold water, the first one they brought out had something dried on the inside of the cup - ewwww. the replacement cup had a layer of oil on top.  (double ewwwww)

Anyways, we get the bill and they charged us for 2 all-you-can-eat.  WE called the waiter over and told hom that we wanted alacarte and to pay that way (there is NOOOOOO way, either of us ate $22.99 worth of food).  The waiter goes back to the counter and comes back a few minutes later and tells us he can't find our order sheet and he won't take our word about what we ordered. (WTF!?!?!?!)

We paid the bill and figured the tip was included becasue they totally cheated us.  Too bad - we liked this place but won't be going back anytime soon unless management figures the crap out!
author: Cindy F.

description:
I'd only been to two other places for hot pot before coming to The Pot's. This is conveniently located in my neighborhood, so I went here last night with loved ones and celebrated my brother's birthday here.

The atmosphere is low-key yet the place is clean; there's a whole separate room for big groups. Hot pot is definitely more fun in a large group! We were only a group of five, but we had a lot of fun stuffing the hot pot with meat, vegetables, dumplings, etc.

All-you-can-eat; I believe on weeknights the price is $22.99 per person and then on weekends the price goes up $2 per person. $22.99 might seem a bit much, but if you are able to eat a lot here, then why not? 

I don't recall how many plates of meat we went through, but we went through a lot....we probably ate $22.99 worth of food (and then some) per person.

There was one thing that seemed a little off to me; offering some sweet buns on the hot pot menu? We put the taro buns into the hot pot and the taste was definitely a little off (we had pork bone and spicy soup bases). 

At the end of dinner, we got complimentary red-bean sesame balls (so petite!) Also to note, there's an extra charge to the bill if people don't finish all the add-ins in the hot pot. Oy! Well, we succeeded in cleaning the hot pot up...

Service was nice and patient; the first server explained to us how the hot-pot system worked since we were a little clueless at first. We got plenty of water and tea refills (to wash down the spiciness). Great!

I wouldn't really say I'd become a regular here, but it is a good place for group gatherings. But, some people come alone here, too; whatever floats their boat.
author: Helene K.

description:
My friend took me here for my birthday and I loved it~~ The broth (we got mala and pork bone broth) were SO flavorful and delicious! And the servers came by and refilled our pot often.
We sat and had a nice relaxing Friday night dinner; they didn't rush us at all even though some people were waiting.
When we ordered (and reordered) our food came quickly and they didn't have to ask again what we had wanted.
author: Lucinda P.

description:
Came here on the weekend and had wanted their family style special, $16.99 for 1st person and $1 for each additional. Found out later it wasn't available over the weekends, but they are too lazy to take down the sign. 

So we did the $24 all you can eat Hot Pot special, which later turned out to be $30+ with tax, tip and stuff like soup base. Unless the order is written down on the menu, the waiters will forget. Had to ask several times for them to replace the butane on the stoves and refills for the soda. 

After we started eating the place was like a sauna. Looking at the reviews this place has been opened for awhile now.  This place didn't think they would need an air conditioner unit recently when on a cold night the place is already 80+ inside.
author: M C.

description:
Hmm... I had never tried a hot pot place before, so I don't have much reference but I did notice some things that might be helpful.

Almost no one there speaks understandable English.

Order A LOT in the beginning, because it takes a long time to arrive and then it takes a long time to cook (for some things).

Make sure you can actually eat $25 worth of food.

The environment is pretty hectic in my opinion.

This review is really a 3.5 - I'm going to go back and contrast my experience. It could be a 4.0 restaurant if I went when it wasn't so busy and on a day when I needed some cozy comfort food.
author: Chris I.

description: the spicy miso broth taste so so good; lots of different selections
author: Emily G.

description:
First time here...

Food: not bad...nothing I havent had before
Price:  not too expensive...all you can eat...but I would have had more at a buffett
Service:  alright...but they did lose our first ordering sheet...we sat wondering where the rest of the food we order was...
author: James L.

description:
ALL YOU CAN EAT HOT POT? I'm so there!

I just came back from eating here, and I have to say that this place was pretty good! I was with two friends, and we had 5 plates prime rib, 3 plates of lamb, udon noodles, tripe, spinach, and chicken dumplings. I love lamb so I probably ate 2 plates to myself. =P The chicken dumplings were pretty good too, and we got a very very nice plate of prime rib! The prime rib was really marbled; you know when the meat has a lot of marbling it means that it's good! Oh, and for dessert we had custard dumplings, about 2 plates of that, and it was really good! =)

The owner was really nice to us, very polite! The place was pretty empty when we got there, thank God, because I didn't want people to see me eat like a beast! =X Parking was an ease, I found parking right in front! Maybe I was lucky? This is has for sure made it's way to my top lists of hot pot restaurants! Our bill came out to $78 for 3 people, totally worth it, because it was all you can eat, and we ate all we could eat!
author: Heather C.

description:
It is not expensive and it taste really good! I have long time not to taste the Northern Chinese Hot Pot.

At the end they have a nice waitress :)
author: Kan W.

description: im not picky about hot pot places. to me you cant go wrong if you supply good quality ingredients and wait staff is relatively attentive. this place is average: average quality ingredients, choices not exactly that extensive, and ok wait service. good place to go if you want a decent hot pot dinner.
author: p f.

description:
Hotpot is one of the greatest loves of my life...

Okay, no, but it's close!

This place is super awesome, kind of pricey (24.99 per person for all you can eat) but that's alright as long as you eat a lot to make it worth it.

They have this taro and uhm...nai wong bao? I don't know the English name, that you can cook and it tastes wonderful!

Everything is really fresh and the taro chip thing is great!

My friends and I got the satay soup base along with the pork soup base the last time we came here...

The satay soup base honestly was weird cause it tasted nothing like it and it had tomatoes. I never had tomatoes in my satay soup bases but alright...The sad thing though was that it wasn't spicy at all. That was sad.

Otherwise though, the staff members here are pretty friendly and nice.

I love The Pot's! It is my second most favorite place to hot pot!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Great for groups, and the food tasted super authentic.  The spicy broth wasn't as spicy as I'm used to (I'm a glutton for pain), but they were happy to add more chili and spices when we asked.

Also, we got there at 9:30p and the place closes at 10p.  They let us stay there till 11:30p to finish our meal (we ordered a lot) while they had dinner, which was very nice of them.

I would definitely go back.
author: Nic M.

description:
This is seriously the best restaurant in the Sunset. All-you-care-to-eat for $25 a person (including tax).  I was a newbie to the "hot pot" process...how to order...what the cooking protocol is, etc. All my insecurities were laid to rest when our sweet waiter asked if we'd been before, and after our sheepish admission that we hadn't, he gave us a little crash course in Hot Pot dining.

My piece of advice...order way, way less than you think you want because the portions are family style & generous at that. Starting with 2 protiens, 1 starch & 3 veggies is what we have been doing...since we go at least 2 times a month now.  If you are a fatty like me, and still want more, they are super attentive & ready to bring it! After all, it's all you can eat, so you can always ask for more...and more...and more.
author: Eryn S.

description:
My boyfriend and I kept driving past this place, and finally went in on a random Monday night. 

This was our first time trying out a hot pot place, and we were totally clueless. We got their dinner special, which was a seafood combo plate (the first one is $17.95, and the second one is only $1!), so we got a LOT of food for very little money. I didn't think the quality of the food was mindblowing, but it was edible and we had fun being silly and trying to figure out what we were supposed to do.

However, it was kind of creepy that we were the only people in there. We were there for over an hour, and not a single soul walked in. Does that mean we picked the wrong place? Where are all the people?

Also, even with just us, it was overwhelmingly hot. I knew it could get stuffy from reading the reviews, but we were sweating it out pretty badly. I can't imagine what it'd be like with more than just two people in there.

I'd like to try other Hot Pot places and go with people who know what they are doing before I give a final judgment but for now I don't think I'd go back.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I love coming here. every soup bases are good. 
They have unique fresh custard dumpling, definitely got to try it after you're done with your food as dessert!
author: Jason H.

description:
To be fair, the food itself may be worth 3 stars for the price. However, the service wasn't attentive at all, and they were very slow with orders and half of our orders were MIA! 

There were two kinds of beef (the fatty one and the regular one), and the second time we ordered we asked for the fatty beef only, but the server told us that there was only one kind of beef!? Everybody of our group was very surprised hearing that. Fortunately people in the next table just got a plate of fatty beef so we could pointed out which kind of beef we wanted. So why did the server tell us there's only one kind of beef? Hmm...

The broth wasn't tasty at all comparing to the Little Sheep in San Mateo. They don't have satay sauce and any kind of alcohol. $22.95 per person for all-you-can-eat, and each of us paid $30 after tax/tips. Little Sheep is just way better in terms of everything.
author: Will N.

description: We are new to the neighborhood and excited to find The Pots on our first evening. We hadn't done Hot Pot before and ended up loving the whole experience. The food was delicious. The service was good, but could have been more attentive refilling drinks and answering questions. Looking forward to our next visit.
author: Adam M.

description: these stars is only only for the food. Right here. The services earned zero star.  Slow and they were just stand at the counter and chill....
author: Jerrfty A.

description:
I am a fan of Shabu and hot pot so when I was told that this place offers a very spicy broth, I was all for it! If you've ever eaten with me, you'll know that I LOVE spicy food. Hot sauce and spicy peppers may be a condiment for some but it is the star of the dish to me. I will find something to eat with my jalapeno. 

I've eaten at Coriya hot pot and I like this place better but it is more pricey. You are given a piece of paper and pencil to mark off the items you'd like to order. They have a pretty good selection. We stuck with the basics. I saw others order pork blood cubes and intestines but I wasn't particularly in the mood for it at the time. 

We ordered the spicy broth, pork, beef, won ton, fried fish balls, noodles and veggies. When our pot of soup was brought out, I saw a sea of red with dried chili peppers floating on the surface. It even stung my eye a little and I got excited. 

The broth definitely tastes better about halfway into dinner - like any stew or soup, it gets better over time because the flavors are more concentrated especially with the flavors  of all the things you are adding to the soup. The broth was spicy but not mouth numbingly spicy.  At one point, I scooped from the bottom of the pot and grabbed a spoonful of pepper seeds- jackpot! 

I really enjoyed the pork. It was fatty but that's what made it so yummy. They were thinly sliced and when cooked in the spicy broth it reminded me of a spicy korean pork dish that I really like. 

At the end of the meal, they bring out mini sesame balls with your check. What a nice treat. If you like spicy hot pot, you should try this place.

Thanks, LT!
author: Cyndi G.

description:
Pretty good deal for all-you-can-eat hot pot.  More affordable than Little Sheep if you're going in with a big appetite.

They have lots of broth choices.  We went with pork bone since I can't handle too much spicy stuff, but they can also give you a split pot with 2 broths for an added charge of $1 per person.

I liked the prime rib slice, lamb slice, hand-made fish ball, pork dumpling, deep-fried tofu, bean vermicelli.

For meatballs, order from the hand-made section rather than just the plain [store-bought+frozen] meatball section-- the difference in quality is pretty obvious.  If I go back with a larger group I'd also try more types of dumplings.

The only change I'd request is that they chop up their veggies more.  I get that most veggies shrink when you cook them, but some of the raw watercress and bok choy pieces that they gave us barely fit in the pot.
author: S L.

description:
This is an absolutely amazing place if you like chinese style hot pot. Chinese style hot pot differs from the Japanese kind in that the emphasis is on a more flavorful broth and varied ingredients as opposed to a select types of high quality cuts of meat. 

I really like the selection here for the all you can eat. You're given  sheet and they have everything from beef prime rib to taro custard desert balls. Ask for the satay sauce and a raw egg to make the dipping sauce.

The sichuan spicy broth was really amazing. It was reasonably spicy and very flavorful which made it perfect for adding some kick to the the ingredients we threw into the hot put.
author: Andrew H.

description:
we had a reservation for 8 and got seated at 8:30.  i would compare this pace to little sheep but i think its less clean and service is less attentive.  the food is pretty good though and i think almost better than little sheep.  im a bit allergic to MSG and i think little sheep soups have it but this place didnt!

this place is all you can eat but no alcohol is served.  we ordered certain amounts of food but we are pretty sure they only gave us a portion of that.  we tried to order more but had to tell them like 3 times that we wanted more food.  so we filled out the sheet again.  and waited quite a while before we got the food that we ordered three times.

oh and there was some huge party going on in the side room and people were getting trashed and singing karaoke really loud.
author: claudia y.

description:
I came here for my girlfriend's birthday so the service naturally was good because we had a party of 15 or so.  The food is surprisingly good for a AYCE.  Most hot pot places use crappy quality meat that has tons of fat and is probably a day from getting moldy, but The Pot's keeps it real by using high quality cuts of meat, piles of fresh veggies, and lots of unique ingredients such as crystal buns (filled with sweet goodies such as red bean paste/custard etc) and many more.  At the price of $22.95 it was pretty decent for the price.

I saw the Asian folks getting better service than some non-Asian folks, but it could just be me.

Try it out, it's great!
author: Jesse W.

description:
I don't have much to complain about an AYCE hotpot place! Food, good. Service, good.

Honestly, I can't really tell the difference between all the hotpot places in SF, they're all pretty much the same to me in terms of quality and names. There was another hotpot place that I liked a little more than this place, but I can't remember what it's called. Also, I do think this place is a bit expensive, especially since I can't eat that much so I always feel I'm not eating my money's worth lol.

Anyways, this time we got the pork bone broth and spicy miso broth. Pork was good, but the spicy miso wasn't my favorite. Last time, we had the spicy szechuan, and that was gooood. Service is pretty fast, so we got our meats and veggies pretty quickly. I always get the wintermelon, which alot of other hotpot places don't offer, egg, shiitake mushrooms, beef, beef soaked in wine, lamb, etc. This place also has almost every type of dumpling ever created, along with some other weird things. Don't get the beef with cheese ball! I don't know why I even ordered it.

Also, this place can get pretty crowded since there aren't that many tables and people usually sit and eat for 2 hours. I suggest coming on a weekday, or after 8:30 on a weekend!
author: Kate Y.

description:
Theres nothing better than having hot pot on a cold winter day.

This place has plenty of choices and considering its all you can eat, you can basically eat here almost the whole night! we had a table of 8 so we got plenty of items but there are so many choices, i dont think we were even able to touch every item before everyone was stuffed!

The service was also pretty good even though the place was filled.

Each table gets only one pot which is actually the traditional chinese hot pot way as opposed to some japanese shabu places where each person gets their own pot. they use butane gas stoves and they tended to take awhile before the pots boil. If they switched to the newer electric stoves that boiled faster, that would be great.
author: Alex H.

description: At least 4, with the possibility for 5 on return visits. i'd have to say, the only downside is that it's lit like an interrogation room, and it's hard to pry beer out of them. it's the first time i've ever asked, "do you serve beer?" and had someone say, "let me check" - it's usually pretty binary. but the answered tured out to be, "we DO have some tonight" (??) so that was good. and the food was quite good and a screaming bargain. would be fun to go back with more people to gorge myself even more fully on all the options.
author: Erica W.

description: Poultry wasn't fresh. Soup base (pork) was way too salty!! :(
author: Nancy W.

description: Worst customer service ever! Expect to repeat yourself multiple times if you want water or spoons! It takes a lot for me to not tip a waiter, but it happened here. The food is not worth the awful service and wait staff. Stick with shabu house.
author: Elle S.

description:
Love the dumplings there.  Great assortment.

We tried the spicy schichuan, spicy miso, and HK satay.  All were very tasty broths.

Beef and lamb slices are slightly above average quality.  

Service on the slower side, but staff is always very nice.
author: Sam T.

description: authentic Chinese hot pot.  A large variety of materials. The service is just ok, seems they only have two waiters/waitress.
author: Kevin L.

description:
went here for my friend's birthday celebration last night.

we had a whole mess of people.. and so they placed us in our own private room - which was AWESOME ! wished they had karaoke tho!

so the service was quite good! they gave us unlimited refills on Coke and Sprite... ( : 

the weekend Buffet Style dinner is $24.95 + our 18% tax n tip came out to be close to $32. Quite pricey.. but hey.. free soda + a private room = happy camper.

on the weekdays its only $16.95. The only beers they have are Bud lite, Corona, and Heineken. side note : I LOVEEEEEEE eating mussels with heineken. 

they give you a 2 hour limit, but they're pretty lenient. they're conveniently located next to Crepe Temptation. which is awesome!

the only con is that the room was steaming hot like a suana, and there was no ventilation except the open door!! they have this tiny dinky fan but my friend's butt was hogging it up. we were pretty uncomfortably hot in there.. w/ all the steam from the hot pots and the body heat and trapped air =[
author: Jenna L.

description:
It was my second or third visit. I think the price dropped a lot. Did anyone feel so? I am not so sure but it certainty felt like so to me. It was pretty expensive back then as I remember. 

They were slow with the orders and missed quite a bunch of the ones we checked on the all you can eat list. They were already trying their very best though. Although they were very busy, they were still very nice. It was a Sunday night and it was pretty full. I guess they were a bit understaffed on a busy night.
author: RB B.

description: This is my favorite spot to eat HOT POT in SF. It is all you can eat, and you order as many items at a time. The choices are excellent. The meat is pretty good. The staff is friendly. I do not like how they charge each person extra if you want to split the soup base.
author: Chatree T.

description:
$22 all you can eat on a weekday ($25 weekend).  You order what you want just like at dim sum :P
