We ordered the spicy miso broth (not as good as Shabu House's), but it was ok.  (Shabu House's is not as good as it use to be either)  Spicy on the first sip, but it eventually became too salty.  They have a variety of broths you can choose from; there were at least 6-7.

The lamb was very fatty.  I like fat, so it was fine with me.  I'm sure other people would have liked it a little leaner ^__^.  The slices of meat are paper thin!  Pretty smart actually because it was hard to tell the quality fo the meat (haha!).

I would definately come back to really make use of their all you can eat! I went with a gf that didn't eat a lot and didn't want to be a piggy eating by myself.  

**I didn't see any other options of ordering here (as mentioned on other reviews).  It was only All-You-Can eat**
author: Theary K.

description: I never liked hot pot until I've tried The Pot's.  It's definitely the best hot pot ever.  The quality of the meat is way better than other places.  On top of the great quality,  the price is only $27 for all you can eat.  I pick this place over Little Sheep or ZabuZabu anytime. My favorite soup base is the spicy mala and pork bone.   They also have a great variety of food you can get.  I'd definitely recommend this place!
author: Little M.

description:
Finally decided to try this place after driving by it a few times.

So, they basically serve you hot pot on a propane burner, which is very convenient to them vs the hot pot/shabu places that have it built-in the table. Anyways, they have a large main dining room and two smaller, more private rooms. We were seated in the smaller one with three tables. Found our menu sitting on top of the burner with many selections. 

The waiter was great and explained the whole ordering process to us as it is an all you can eat experience, but they bring you the food. Dinner cost $24.99 pp and you could pick between a regular broth or spicy broth. We opted for the spicy which was a little too spicy for our taste and had the waiter add some regular broth to our pot. We ordered a ton of things before we realized the bottom of the menu read "if you do not finish what you order, there will be a surcharge" or something along the lines of what you waste, you pay for. 

Oh boy. We had about four different types of noodles, four different veggies, three types of dumplings, four meats, fish, two types of tofu, and tripe. All served in very good portions too. We sort of finished it all (I had to "put away" two bowls of our noodles) and it was all very good. 

My favorites: fillets of fish, lamb, beef, pork, taro bun (omg, tastes more like dessert!)

Next time we won't order some of the things we ordered this time; we were just anxious to try everything. Overall, a great dinner with great service (considering we were in a small room and it was busy) and I will definitely be back for more. Especially those taro buns...
author: Kimberly H.

description:
MMMMMM I love The Pots. It's right up my block, which makes it so hard to resist! The smell of the broth & the knowledge of it's yumminess is a will power work out.

After tax & tip, it's basically $30/person each time. It's all you can eat hot pot, supposedly for 2 hours, although I've sat there for around 2 hours & haven't ever been kicked out. 

The meat, veggies, and other goodies are super fresh, and abundant, as it's all you can eat. But cmon people, let's not waste! There's been countless times I've come here when I see people order a whole bunch of food & not even touch it! The dumplings are handmade and DELISH.. chicken & chive, wontons, you name it. Yum. The rib eye is tender & to die for when dipped in their sauce. I make sure to load up on the rib eye, dumplings, & noodles when I go to The Pots. 

It can get a little warm inside, as with any hot pot. The only thing I'd wish for in improvements at The Pots is the service. The way the ordering works is with a paper menu that you mark off your choices on. The waiters/waitresses aren't very attentive & sometimes, you're caught waiting, paper in hand, for them to see that you've hit the bottom of the pot. They're inconsistent when offering water, napkins, etc., and also, it's a free-for-all. Servers don't man a certain section of tables, it's basically "whoever's in the area, helps that table" sort of situation. I find that it's frustrating to get help with more sauce, or our next order of food. 

Other than that, the ingredients are fresh & tasty, and at a great price to feel super stuffed! :0)
author: Stephanie J.

description:
This probably is the best hot pot restaurant in the sunset district next to the Old Mandarin Islamic restaurant.  This place is cleaner and they have a bigger selection.  22 dollars on weekdays and 24.99 during the weekends for all you can eat.  There are a few other specialty items for a nominal fee.  A very solid 4 star restaurant. Honestly,  they probably deserve a 5 star based on freshness, variety, price, and location.  The service was a little lacking but they were genuinely very nice and we overlooked it.  They didn't rush us and we were actually there for 2 hours.

Compared to Little Sheep Mongolian?  Very comparable but cheaper.  In terms of value, I would choose this over Little Sheep.  Yes..........I like it that much.

You know why this place works here?  Because the sunset is always so cold and hot pot is the perfect combination to counteract the cold.  Eat a little and go out for a breather is very refreshing.  

Pros
broth (spicy......it's very spicy/ pork broth)
sauce
Prime rib beef slices
dumplings
shrimp balls
tofu
bean curd roll
shrimp

Cons
beef ball
fish ball

4 ppl for 117.00  Well worth it.
author: jason g.

description:
The problem I have with these places is their pricing policy for kids.  If your kid is taller than the counter then they pay full price as an adult if they are shorter they still have to pay price regardless of how old they are.  

This is ridiculous my daughter's only 4 years old and she gets charged 12 bucks???   Does that sound fair to you?  

As quality and selection its not as good as Hot Pot Garden.  Price is the same, so given the choice I would rather go to Hot Pot Garden on Taraval.  

Actually, I'd rather not go to any of these places any more because of their horrible pricing policy.  Instead I'd make the drive to Fremont to have AYCE Korean BBQ at Bob Sang's for 18 bucks and where my 4 year old child doesn't get charged 12 bucks for nothing!
author: Ethan C.

description:
Ok, so I've been to this place a few times when  I lived in the neighborhood and the food is always great. Plus, Sunset is always cold and foggy so nothing is more perfect than a hotpot. Love the spicy soup base. Meat is fresh and love the kobe beef, but their dumplings are usually cold (frozen) so leave them in the soup for a bit longer than the meat.
Yes it's a bit pricey ($25 per person) but it's all you can eat, so make sure you come hungry! The place is small and get busy pretty fast especially during the weekend, so make sure to come early (they only open for dinner at 5pm). Parking is easy as it's in the Sunset. 
Service is not the best one, but after all it's a Chinese restaurant, so please people, stop complaining about it. Just go there to enjoy the food.
author: Tia P.

description:
Nothing really special about this place.  It's just an average hot pot joint.  The price was around $30 per person, so it's kind of pricey.

Pros: fresh ingredients.

Cons: pricey.
author: Amy C.

description:
i swore that i composed a review of this place, but it's fallen into the yelp black hole of reviews.

$24.99 all you can eat on the weekends.

me and my friend came here on friday night and closed this place down. ingredients are fresh, portions are plentiful, and you will have to roll your fat self out of this place after your meal.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Excellent Canto take on Taiwanese hot pot concept with Sichuan-style "mala" hot pot base split pot accompanied by a Chinese medicinal soup base complete with white bark, goji berries and others.

Both broths were really good. 

The raw ingredients were plentiful and fresh, with lots of different types of meat, seafood and vegetables to make anyone happy. The meatballs and fishballs were really tasty and QQ and the soup at the end was super savory.

This is the perfect place for cold, foggy summer evenings out in the Sunset district. Just beware of the Canto-pop karaoke that drifts out into the main dining room once 8pm rolls through. 

The service is WAY friendly for a Chinese restaurant so it was nice to hear my people being helpful and smiley for once, and not slamming plates down on tables or giving bitchface when you ask for your water to be refilled. 

$24.99 per person. I'm definitely going back.
author: May T.

description: Came here with my parents for dinner.  It was expensive but really worth the money.  Had several servings of the prime rib and lamb, both of which were extremely fresh and well sliced for hot pot.  Only complaint was that the tofu was too soft for the soup and the bean threads were cut way too short.  Other than that, we had a great meal and everyone left more than satisfied.  I would definitely return.
author: Ren C.

description: This is a wonderful place.  The food is fresh and lots of good sauces.  The restaurant is very plain, but clean.  The service was good but the staff is really stressed.  They really should have one or two more people. We will definitely make it a regular spot.
author: v n.

description: Wow this place was awesome -- definitely worth the trip on the N all the way from downtown to the sunset. If you're from Asia or grew up in an Asian household then hot pot might not be that novel to you, but if you've never done hot pot you should drop what you're doing right now and go. The beef and lamb were especially excellent.
author: David B.

description: Word of caution: don't come around 7, or you'll wait an hour, that's how popular this place is. Simply the closest thing approaching authentic Sichuanese hotpot in the entire Bay Area (though I think it's Taiwanese-influenced). I come here once a week because it's still the only place -- out of dozens sampled -- that recalls blissful memories of my favorite hotpot dives in Shanghai. Advice: if you like it real, ask them to do their best to spice up the "Fire" soup base. Only then will it begin to approach the genuine article.
author: Edwin C.

description:
I'd probably give this place a 3.5 with room for improvement.  I'm not a huge fan of hot pot places because in my opinion, if you're going to a restaurant, you should just go there to eat, not cook it yourself.  But that's just because I'm super lazy and I hate cooking in general.  However, this is all-you-can-eat with a two-hour time limit and I am a huge fan of massive amounts of food.  

We ordered the spicy broth (really spicy with about 35 red peppers thrown in) and the pork broth.  After burning my tongue on the spicy broth immediately and then having to wait a really really long time for the waiter to bring water, I ended up eating most of my food out of the pork broth.  The food was decent although I'd stick to meats and avoid the seafood (squid tasted really old or more fishy than it should taste).  The dumplings were good although when they brought them out they were frozen so you need to cook them a little bit longer.  Some of the things we asked for never came out either.

The only major thing lacking here is the service.  They are really nice but understaffed and the waiter actually asked that we give him some time.  They were serving several large parties and people have to be patient if they want their money's worth.  I would suggest thinking ahead and asking for extra napkins, spoons, bowls, forks, water all at once, otherwise you'll just be waiting a LONG time to get everything, which is what we did.  Hopefully their service will improve so I can give them more stars.
author: Stacey C.

description:
this is by far my favorite hot pot place, besides my home. (hehe) It is very clean here. They have a large section of food to choose from. Did i mention that it is ALL YOU CAN EAT?! you just order from a sheet of paper and they will bring it out for you. Love the pork bone broth and the spicy broth base. 

The owner Michael is very nice and friendly. His staff is very attentive. There are street parking around the shop. It's prefect for a cold, chilly night, or when you are super hungry. Just eat, chat, and drink!
author: Sabrina K.

description:
Decided to try this place since i drive past it now and then.

Quick summary:

Fresh food.

Excellent service.

The owner was extremely nice to me and made sure my mom's bday was handled with great care.

Different flavored soups makes my face and heart happy.

Coming back?  Only if i get hungry. =P
author: Simon S.

description:
came here to eat with some friends and didn't have to wait very long since we had called ahead for a reservation. parking is easy here. the food itself is alright. most of the items come straight from the freezer. the meat selection is decent. service is really slow. i think we had to wait ~20 minutes for the pot to even arrive at the table. come on guys this is hot pot. we're not asking you to cook anything ahead of time. the price is a little steep considering all the factors
oh yeah and make sure to get the desert balls at the end
author: Brian C.

description: First time - last time! Waited forever to be seated.  Service was very slow. Did not receive many of the items we ordered and meat plates came at the very end AND we had to ask for them. No wine/beer.  Make sure you have cash, "credit card machine not working" or they don't want to pay the service fees.
author: pat b.

description: Amazing place to have hot pot. If you come at the wrong time in the evening youll end up waiting for a while but its only because the foods great and theyre in no rush to kick you out. They just keep coming by and bringing more food from a very expansive and thorough menu. All types of meat, vegetables, noodles, broths, dumplings, and even a bunch of sweet dessert type dumplings that taste so good you can still have a few after filling yourself up to the point of not breathing. Its especially a great place to go with a large group so you can order a lot of different foods and be able to try them all without getting too stuffed on the same things. Definitely my favorite hot pot place.
author: Henry W.

description:
As if All You Can Eat hot pot isn't good enough already, The Pot's gets extra points for closely resembling the tastes of Hong Kong's hot pot.

They have many soup bases to choose from and the most you can have per pot is 2, which is pretty much the standard for all hot pot places. I remember the original soup base being a little on the bland side - not enough herbs/herbal flavor. All the other soups we had were good.

They offer many food items, including some dim sum items like milk-custard bun and cha-siu bun. In fact, the milk-custard and cha-siu buns were comparable with the ones you find in Hong Kong's hot point joints. Their beef was pretty tasty - we ordered A LOT of plates. They had a good veggies to meat ratio and you can keep ordering as long as you'd like.

Honestly, they give you pretty good quality with the price they charge you.

Is it better than Little Sheep? 
Food-wise, it's more or less the same since it's just a matter of freshness. 
Soup-base-wise, no. Little Sheep's soup is richer and tastier - that means the flavor can actually soak into your food. 
$$$-wise, well...one's AYCE and one's not...
Service-wise, the staff at The Pot's were definitely friendly and efficient. Little Sheep's staff had been slightly snobby and were always very busy, thus kind of inattentive.
author: Grace C.

description:
Each year I look forward to Thanksgiving. Not because of turkey, cranberries, pumpkin pie or any of the other usual suspects. For me, Thanksgiving marks the start of huo guo  (hot pot) season at my mother-in-law's house. We are usually able to get at least three or four hot pot parties out of her a season and each one is a treat in itself.  Lately I have been fretting about this coming winter because my in-laws are going to be in Taiwan from October through February. We're going to be left out in the cold during hot pot season. What's a girl to do? 

I am happy to say that I have found a suitable alternative to my mother-in-law's house. After trying a handful of other wannabe hot pot places in the city, I have to admit, The Pots is a close second to my mother-in-law's. 

A group of colleagues and I caravanned out to the Sunset on a recent unusually sweltering Friday evening. Probably not the best day to slurp hot pot, but we had been planning and talking about it for four days and there was no backing out. We were committed. 

I walked in expecting a hole-in-the-wall joint and instead was greeted with a bright, cheery space with lots of tables and an army of servers waiting to meet our every hot pot need. 

For you hot pot novices, The Pots is just for you. It's a set price per person ($25) for all you can eat. You have two hours to enjoy your hot pot, which by the way is plenty of time. If you're hungry at the end of your time, then you're not human. You will be given a sheet of paper and pen (much like a sushi place) which enables you to make your very own personalized hot pot. Ready, set, go! 

Choose your broth: choices include pork bone, cilantro and preserved egg, mala (spicy), beef bone or split pot where you can enjoy two different styles simultaneously. If you are like me and want it all, go for the split pot. 

Choose your food: thinly sliced raw meat, shrimp, fish balls, beef balls, vegetables, noodles, tofu, handmade dumplings are all choices. My suggestion is to check off every ingredient on the list. But hey, I'm a glutton. 

Make your dipping sauce: While you're waiting for your broth and accouterments to arrive, start concocting your personal sauce. The Pots offers soy sauce, chili paste, garlic, cilantro, vinegar and green onions. Mix to your own personal taste, but watch out for the garlic. That will stay with you for days! 

Do-it-yourself cooking: place everything in the broth pot and wait until they are cooked. Tip for the novice: put in the dumplings, lotus root and other things that take awhile to cook first. Things like spinach, meat and tofu are fast-cooking and won't take long. One of my colleagues (who will remain nameless) is what I call a "Hot Pot Nazi" and likes to clear out all the meat before cooking the vegetables, clear out the vegetables prior to the dumplings and so on and so on. Me? I'm a "dumper" and like to throw everything in at once and then nosh on the bounty of delectables. The choice is yours.  

Extracting food: when your food is cooked to your taste, remove from the broth. Take the food with your chopsticks, drag it through your dipping sauce and chow down.

What makes The Pots special? The quality and amount of traditional options is amazing. Things like tofu skin, whole shrimp, wood ear mushrooms, dumplings, gai lan, winter melon are all choices and that's only a small handful. 

The thing that tipped me over the edge was the sweet dumplings. There was sweet taro and egg custard dumplings that seems a bit strange, but provided just a hint of sweetness at the end of the meal. 

It's not as comfortable as my mother-in-law's dining room, but I have a feeling The Pots will get me through the winter months when I'm craving hot pot.
author: Lee H.

description: This place is garbage.....seriously. First, out soup came and when my party and I looked at it, it had flies in it, so we exchanged our soup. The fly wasn't too bad, but once we start to get our food, there was a hair on the food. first time trying it and it will definitely be my last. The meat is crap and everything else. The only good thing was the spinach.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Solid. Through and through. There are no complaints about the food at all-- save the fried items (fried tofu, fried skin) isn't freshly fried. Not a big deal. AYCE 22.95/person. $1 extra per person if you have a split broth. Excellent veggie options as well, since it matters for my gf.

Biggest issue is what everyone else mentioned, service and the nasty sauna-like conditions (due to boiling hotpots everywhere). Not a big deal as this is an authentic-ish chinese restaurant and bad service, conditions are part of the charm.... :^)
author: Sumeet S.

description:
Came here for my birthday and had dinner with some friends and family. I had no idea it was an "All-you-can-eat" type of hot pot place. The meats and veggies were fresh but I didn't like biting into tiny pepper balls after I scooped my food up from the broth.

The bill was expensive, food was not really worth that price, and some people wound up having really bad stomach aches afterward. The wait staff were nice and friendly though...and they didn't sing, "happy birthday," to me so that was a HUGE plus! =)

I don't think I'd come back here anytime soon. I'd check out other hot pot places where it's cheaper and the food was better.
author: V M.

description: i normally get disappointed by hot pots and shabu places but this place is actually good. AND it's all you can eat?! the dipping sauce is good but of course being a garlic lover i load it with minced garlic. they have different broths and you like spicy but your significant other doesnt? no worries, they can split ur pot in half for both broths for your table! the spicy broth isnt that spicy although it looks mighty spicy however the spices they put in it are kind of annoying when you bite into it. I felt like i was biting a rock :/ but they have a wide variety of veggies, meats, seafood and udon to choose from. definitely a place worth checking out! service is ok, we had to requests mutiple times for everything, even our drinks...but they do get busy. they only take reservations for parties of 5+ so if you don't plan to wait a little for a table. people tend to take along time to eat here, it is all you can eat in 2 hours :) also there is no parking lot, street parking only- good luck!
author: Linda L.

description:
If this were MTV's Next, this one would have been the one girl that I gave a shot to (looked good on the outside, heard good things) but gave the NEXT card to after spending time with her.

Continuing on my quest to try each and every hot pot/shabu place in the SF area until I OD on beef, veggies, tofu, and various dipping sauces ... I ended up here @ The Pot's.  Just a few blocks from where I stay .. woohoo!

PLUS: The all you can eat (your only option here) menu is huge. You can pick from many different types of protein, seafood, dumplings, noodles, veggies, etc.  The cost for such a menu isn't so high either so its really a pretty good deal

MINUS: Beef, dumplings, and many of the other items just weren't very good.  The beef in particular was very disappointing as it wasn't tasty at all, even cooked in the spicy broth.  The texture of the beef wasn't very appealing either.  If you're a lamb fan, the lamb is decent I suppose.  *shrug* maybe I've gotten spoiled by all the kobe, angus type marbled high quality beefs I get elsewhere.

The broth itself wasn't very good either. I would say the The Pot's is meant to be similar to Little Sheep out in San Mateo, and by that meter .. this place falls WAY short.  The broth is pretty boring and just doesn't do much like I would hope it would.

Service: So so.  They were responsive and walked around alot. But they often forget what you order.  We ordered rice as soon as we sat down, but 2 hours later, we never got it.  They said they had to make it .. ok? Simple item like rice isn't ready during primetime dinner hours?   I can forgive that I guess but they never did bring the rice and we just ended up annihilating double digit plates of meat instead.  Their loss! hahah

So I've definitely had better ( Shabu House, Little Sheep ), but this one falls below all others and sadly will be the one I won't be going back to.  Too bad though because I really wanted to like it. 

NEXT!
author: David B.

description: Stuffed to the max!!  This is why i dont go to all you can eat too often.  This place have crazy amount of options.  Think we over ordered on the balls.  Tried the spicy miso soup and pork bone.  The broth was ok , not as good as i expected.  Maybe i'll try a different broth next time.  The prime rib was really tasty though.  Service was friendly and pretty fast when we got seated but it took a while to get seated as it was crowded on a friday night.
author: Hugh L.

description:
Just recently I'm becoming more of a fan of hot pot dining, and the more I go to The Pot's, the more my palate and tummy like it!  I often come here with a large group of friends and we always get a private room.

The AYCE menu consists of a piece of paper which lists the numerous items you can add to your broth, and you just check off and indicate the quantity that you want.  They have a good selection of spicy and non-spicy broths to choose from.  Since I'm not one for spicy foods but like to truly enjoy the full flavor of all the ingredients, my favorite is the miso broth.  Once you add all the meat, dumplings, meatballs, seafood, noodles, and veggies, you have one darn good tasting broth!  The thin slices of prime rib and lamb are presented perfectly with the right amount of marble, and are very fresh.  The various dumplings, meatballs, and seafood are all tasty.  The even have the black and white fungus, as well as enoki mushrooms!  For the noodles, they have the thin egg noodles, the thin bean thread vermicelli, and the thicker udon noodles.  The texture of all are perfect.  The various greens are very fresh and, when simmered in your broth, very satisfying.  

My favorite dish, which should be enjoyed at the end of the meal, are the taro balls, a ground piece of light purple taro wrapped in a thin, slightly chewy noodle wrap.  After being heated in the broth for a few minutes, you have a perfectly sweetened ball of DELICIOUSNESS that just melts in your mouth!  An excellent dessert dumpling!

The prices for this AYCE hot pot are very reasonable:  $23 per person Sunday - Thursday and $25 on Friday and Saturday.  Be sure to only order what you can eat or you will be charged for any wastage.  For entertainment, they even have karaoke for those of you who want to show off your singing talents.

Overall, The Pot's is a great value and with a group a friends, you will not only have an enjoyable, delicious meal but also a lot of fun!  I will definitely be back!
author: Karen L.

description: I don't even like hot pot, Well I didn't , Possibly because when people do it at home they bring crappy ingredients, This place has a wide range of tasty, and some not so tasty items. The stuff I don't like I just don't order simple as that. Im not a big fan of protein in a ball form and even less so with cheese whiz oozing out of it, but the prime rib after it has been boiling in its own delicious fat and garlic and anything else you threw in there... YUM.
author: Bruce W.

description:
Came here for the BF's bday party. We had a party of 25. They did a great job of serving us. The service wasn't as quick as we would like, but they were very nice and shuffled as fast as they could. I love the variety and freshness of the food. Would definitely come back on a chilly SF night. 

The sate broth was oh so yum. And the Sichuan broth was as spicy as it sounds. YUM!!!
author: Mai H.

description: Great quality food.. i am absolutely a hotpot expert haha.. the pork soup is delicious.. even veggies cooked in it was great. ( and I always choose the spicy soup first)  We got there early and had terrific service.   GOGOGO!
author: Ellen C.

description:
have you ever wondered why my nickname is lilftkd2?

O-M-G

O-M-G

i can't eat another bite

O-M-G

ooh, is that more prime rib? yeah, i'll have a slice

O-M-G

seriously, i don't even know where to start with this one. i am a BIG fan of hot pot, and i mean true chinese style hot pot, not shabu shabu or "mongolian hot pot".  this place ROCKS!!!  the owner says they are looking for a daytime chef so hopefully they will be offering a lunch soon (altho i can't gorging on such a large amount of food at lunch). what a great deal at $22 for weeknights. seniors are half off at $11. what a deal!!!

i just absolutely loved the combination of the 1. all you can eat with 2. order off the list and have it brought to your table with 3. choose your own broth and 4. everything being of top quality. another place that we went to recently was more expensive and had a cool men with theme like "bangkok" and "tokyo" fire pot but you were restricted to the broth with the offering and it wasn't all you can eat.  

the broth offerings were really appealing. there were the non-spicy ones made with chicken pork or parsley and preserved egg, and the spicy ones. we chose the pork and parsley/preserved egg ones. i really really enjoyed the parsley one. good for clearing the body of "heat", if you believe in the whole ying and yang concept of food :) 

there were also some really unique offerings like the taro dumplings and the sweet egg yolk one. wow, were the sweet egg one YUM. i've also never seen such a vast assortment of vegetable options.  the pork and shrimp dumplings were made perfectly!!! i think i had two orders of those myself

i do hope that they do add some dessert options to the menu. i kinda like having the soft serve ice cream, almond jello, shave ice, red bean and fruit etc.  but then the $$$ would probably go up.  i also wish they had a few more items for making my own dipping sauce, particularly satay sauce

they also have a private that holds up to 20.  watch out, it is fully equipped with both the latest in chinese and english karaoke. better order lots of beer LOL 

i know i'm forgetting something else that i loved. i think i'm still in a food coma....

i am sooooo gonna be back to get my grub on
author: joyce l.

description: Many types of selection. Great place for Hotpot Buffet.
author: Victor L.

description: a long line as you would imagine since theres not many chinese hot pot places in town.  compared to the hot pot garden its less quality with the meat sauce and especially the SERVICE bec they dont hire enough waiters!  but all together still reasonably priced and authentic.
author: Shuting Z.

description: My friends and I came here for a large get together. The food was pretty good with a lot of options and good quality. However, the service was pretty slow. It took us forever to get our food. Maybe it was because we were in a private room and they forget about us or they were just understaffed. I really enjoy hotpots but I think they are missing some sauce to dip the hotpot stuff in. Just my personal preference i guess
author: Pin X.

description:
Yep..quite disappointing...

The food was a little on the lower mediocre side. Frozen fish balls, taro dumplings, ...basically there weren't many items that were fresh. The fatty beef and lamb was decent. I would not come here again for $25 a person. Koi Palace or Asian Pearl has fresher, more diverse seafood selection. Between this and Coriya...for the price, I'd still go to Coriya for $15/pp. 

Oh, and the ambiance was the worse. Sure it's all modern decor but the lack of ventilation in the steam filled arena...man, it wasn't comfy! And the place gives a very desolated vibe.

We didn't get the service some people did. Service was not efficient. A very young staff. We had to ask why our greens weren't out yet and they proceeded to finally tell us they're sold out.
author: Abc D.

description: the people working here were really nice and i love how there is a huge selection of items here, but  i experienced a huge msg attack after eating dinner here tonight. i don't know what other artificial flavorings they added to the food, but i have never felt this sick before after eating at a restaurant. i had a headache, felt nauseous, and just plain weird. unfortunately, i will not be returning and do not recommend this place to anyone who is sensitive to msg.
author: Robbie R.

description:
what great reviews for a not so good little sheep. $23 dollars all you can eat, 18% gratuity for a 6 or more party = $30/31 a person. For $30 dollars you could go to little sheep mongolian hotpot in san mateo and eat the best hotpot ever and be full. 

What's supposed to make a hotpot place special from places like Coriya is the soup. And the soup isn't nearly as good. It tasted homemade. The meats aren't as good. Sometimes they don't give you the food you request. (Waitresses were nice though)

I'm glad I know now.  If I had to go in the city to get hotpot, I'd go to one of those shabu shabu places. Save your money, and get te good stuff at little sheep.
author: Garrett W.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmm.........hot pot! I crave for hot pot on those cold winter days and since my bf and I was in the neighborhood, I really wanted to try this place. However, my rating is really 3.5 stars. I've had better hotpot at Little Sheep but this is a good alternative if you don't want to go out of SF. 

First thing I notice is that the service was friendly. It was probably because we were the first ones there but friendly nonetheless. 

We got the non-spicy broth and ordered an assortment of prime rib meat, lamb, beef balls, veggies, tofu, mussels and shrimp! Since they use the simple gas stoves, it does take awhile for the water to boil up. The beef slices were good and so were the lamb slices although I wish there was more of a variety of dipping sauces. Everything was very fresh and I like how they bring you the food when you order it, instead of having to pile on things yourself at other hot pot buffet joints. 

They do have a 2-hour limit as to how long you can stay. But we were overwhelmingly full at 1.5 hours which is plenty of time to cook and eat. Also, complimentary sesame ball desert at the end!!!!
author: Crystal C.

description:
Seen so many businesses come and go that I thought this location was cursed or haunted. I think this place may last. Other than growing marijuana or running a massage parlor, opening up a hot pot place in cold-ass, foggy, predominantly Chinese, Sunset district is genius!

For about $30/person, you get all-you-can-eat. And they bring the food to you. Not bad. Quality could be better but I would come again.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
Not bad, not bad.  For the notoriously bland taste of Outer Sunset.

Definitely accommodates large parties.  The waiters were above and beyond helpful - even though they probably hate us.  We definitely broke even or even came out on top by the way we ordered.  You must get the buffet price ($22 Mon through Thurs, $25 Fri through Sun).

The decor is modern trendy - not Osha Thai fancy, but more of a middle ground between West Elm and Ikea.  It was clean, very high ceilings, a couple of dining areas, well light (maybe too bright?), and graciously very good ventilation.  

The food was actually above average - they give you a dim sum format menu and you pick away.  However, it proved to be inefficient, as once you start eating, you bark at the waiters.  Then they have a hard time remembering, since it's not written down.  They did eventually get your order, it just takes some time and reminding.  We ordered all sorts of meats, fish balls, minced meat balls (really good), veggies, and other home ingredients.  Some must orders were the yam noodles, the meatballs, the taro, the lotus, the won tons, and the lamb.  They were not stingy on the the orders at all and they brought it out without any glances.   Oh, don't forget the sesame balls at the end.

I have to say the service was 5 star.  Really patient, cool, fast, and smiley.  They never curbed our orders nor complained.  I have to admit our table was definitely not shy about ordering.  At no point did they give us the evil eye.  The evil Chinese eye.  Oh how I hate THAT one.

They did lack on the sauces tho.  They provide hot sauce, satay (had to ask), garlic, cilantro, hot peppers, and green onions.  But that's about it.  I usually like peanut butter, sesame oil, peanuts, and other condiments, but they did not offer it.  I think they mimic more of a Mongolian hot pot?  Not too sure.   They have a dual pot bowl, but watch out, they tacked on an additional fee for it, so be sure to ask.  

Another thing was that they did not have a lot of seafood - perhaps why they were able to offer such low prices for the buffet.  But everything else was pretty fresh - meats came out cold / firm, veggies were snappy, the fishballs and other fish cake products were frozen.  No need to worry about salmonella.

Definitely a good experience overall.  The range of offerings were a little limited compared to other places in Richmond or in the Peninsula.  But the place was easy to get to, clean, and not crowded.   If you want to get your basic hot pot on but don't want the added stress of driving too far or paying too much, this is your place.
author: Isaac L.

description:
Pros: 
1.) Fresh fresh fresh ingredients. This is very important for good hot pot.
2.) Good Service. This makes experience better
3.) Good variety. Spicy for mild. Lean or fatter. There's something for everyone.

Cons:
1.) More sauces would be nice.

The best hot pot in the city. A good find introduced to me by a friend. In a city as diverse as SF its sometimes surprisingly hard to find certain ethnic/more exotic foods that are not watered down. The Pots is an exception. The spices are there and you choose your own level of adventure which I feel is important since people have different tastes & thresholds for such things. Thumbs up.
author: ashton l.

description:
Best Chinese hotpot place I've been to yet.

Pros:
~ fresh meat/food in general
~ TONS of food options
~ you order from a menu and they bring you what you want
~ they have the stuffed shrimp balls that I love so much
~ there are 5 different soup bases to choose from (includes: clear base, Szechuan hot & spicy, satay, tomato and potato, and some cilantro thing I forget)
~ very clean place (no sticky tables/floors for sure)
~ clean restrooms (at least the ladies' room was clean)
~ friendly service (even though we stayed past 2 hours, they didn't rush us to leave or anything)
~ relatively easy to find parking

Cons:
~ more expensive than the other hot pot places in the city ($23/person Thurs-Sun and $25/person Fri & Sat)
~ they allow you to choose two soup bases but they charge an extra $1/person
~ they have some specials of the day (i.e. fresh oysters, scallops) but they charge those per order
~ they refill the pot with clear broth instead of the soup base you choose
~ since it's not self-serve, you can't control how much of what you get
~ drinks are extra
~ no dessert bar
~ they don't have satay sauce =(

Boyfriend and I chose the half satay and half hot & spicy soup base.  Satay one was very yummy but the spicy one was okay as well.  I was very pleased with the quality of the food and the overall service of this place.  I can't wait to share this place with my family...
author: Katelynn L.

description:
This is the place to eat  if you ever want your Taste Buds to go through some Orgasmic experience!  After you're done eating, you'll be like "wow... wow"... like you just went through some euphoric experience.

AMBIANCE: This place is total an upscale Fobby restaurant.  It feels like a place in Taiwan or Hong Kong.  Bright colors, fruity Hong Kong music blasting from the screens, and a very cliquish Chinese crowd.  All this makes this place just more classic and authentic. 

QUALITY: Hot pot is all about two things: 1) Freshness  2) The Soup.  Their food is extremely fresh.  The meat is thinly sliced with minimal fat and all the other stuff (fish balls, lettuce, catfish, and etc) taste like it was just bought.  They have over 5 flavors of soup and their burners are quite up to date.  It is all electronic

SERVICE: Top Notch.  The owner is really attentive to your needs.

HOURS: This place is open until 2am on Friday and Saturday.  Only in Asia do they open Hot Pot places that late.  OH yeah, they have VIP rooms...I think they even have Karaoke in the rooms. Can you imagine, gorging yourself with hotpot while Karaoking???  ahhhhh fantasy come true! 
Overall, $23 all you can eat Hot Pot is a bargain.  I will never go anywhere else in the Bay.  I think this place is well worth the drive if you are ever in the Bay.
author: Mike L.

description:
PROS: All you can eat hot pot.  Extensive selection of veggies and meats.  Great for groups of friends. Parking available in surrounding area.

CONS: Leads to stomach ache. Questionable hygiene. Slow service. Loud and obnoxious crowd.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Well I was always skeptical of hot-pot. Why am I paying exuberant prices to a restaurant to cook a meal myself? That being said, I have never actually tried hot-pot before. 

My boyfriend had recently tried hot pot with a few of his friends and I was naturally jealous that he had gone and tried it first, without me. 

I suggested that we eat here since I see it every day as I drive by to work. It is expensive (we went on a Saturday) at 24.99 a person, all you can eat. Which sounds nice, the 'all you can eat part' but how much can you really eat when most of it is soup, or soupy.

The service was great. The waiter walked me through how to order and suggested what might be good. We got the pork broth soup with a basket of spices (it was weird because they later took the spices away even though I wanted to flavour the broth more as I went along). 

Now here's the thing I didn't factor into my "I don't want to cook my own food while dining out" factor. It was pretty fun! The food was good, seeing as how I tricked myself into thinking I was the awesome chef that night. 

The portions were large and the selection huge. The restaurant itself was nice and clean and the staff was attentive. 

I would probably go back but it's just too expensive for my budget at the moment. 

Great way to introduce myself to hot-pot.
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
Pretty freakin awesome!
$23 for sun-thurs, $25 for fri-sat for all-you-can-eat.
Pretty standard for all you can eat but I gotta admit I was pretty satisfied with this restaurant. The service was a bit lacking when it came to serving, we had to wave them down for everything. Depending on the size of your party, the 2 hour dining limit may be a bit too short. I had a party of 3 and we took two hours and fifteen minutes. 
The greatest part of this is that the food comes relatively quick and the selection is large and specific. Probably over 40 items to choose from, all inclusive in the all-you-can-eat price. 
The size of the vegetables are MASSIVE. They need to be cut down, I don't want to be throwing an entire lettuce head into my soup. Speaking of soup, the soup base is great but the spicy is DAMN spicy. I can't handle hot cheetos and I damn well couldn't handle the spicy broth. 
Everything was surprisingly good, no regrets on any orders... well the only regret would be ordering too much food. It would be smart to order in two intervals instead of piling on a buttload of food at the beginning.

Loved it, definitely recommend it, will come again.
author: Ryan L.

description:
There wasnt anything here I couldnt get at sunset super...I go to restaurants because i want to order something i cant make myself! Not pay more for food that cost less and i have to cook it myself.  
Yes, it is AYCE, but the first plate of meat they bring you is HUGE, then the 2nd gets smaller, and 3rd gets even smaller. lol. genius.

OH, the custard balls were good. Those were different. 

A few days later, i went to china and had the best hot pot in my life. of my life?
author: kim w.

description:
Went to this hot pot place cuz cold weather these days..
the restaurant is really clean and the waiting staff were friendly, unlike typical Chinese restaurant.

4 stars for restaurant cleaniness
4 stars for its waiting staff
2 stars for its shrimp balls or other meat balls, not very impressive
4 stars for sliced lamb and beef, they were very tender after cooking, can still taste own sweetness of it.
author: Rukawa J.

description: Very clean! Good food with a lot of variety. One price for all you can eat. Have a great time with my friends there, I like here!
author: ThinkTank Learning I.

description:
$24.95 all you can eat hotpot for dinner.
Start with picking out your broth: spicy, pork soup,  or clear soup than there is the meats, lamb, prime rib grade beef, and chicken.
then your veggies: napa cabbage, collard greens and other various types. 
What is the BOMB is their dumplings which they make and stuff themselves.  So yum. 
Pork filled, shrimp filled, shrimp balls, fish fillets, and stuffed cheese tumplings. I can't even list it all because there was alot to be had. 
Service was also impeccable, they would come a appropriate times to refill water, sodas, offer more meats or veggies whatever the desire might be. I'd go back again.
author: J. C.

description:
I saw this place in a commercial on Jade channel and decided to make a trip here for our CNY dinner. I normally don't give five stars to a restaurant but this place really deserves it. This place is clean, new and spacious. There are VIP rooms which can hold private parties there. The food was great!!! We ordered mostly meat and seafood. Between my husband and me, we had 3 plates of thinly sliced beef, 2 plates of pork, veggies and some seafood. The pork was sooo good..I never knew pork can taste this tender. The hand-beaten cuttlefish ball was another slam dunk..but my favorite was definitely the soup base. We ordered 1/2 pork bone soup and the other 1/2 spicy soup. The flavor of the pork bone soup tasted just right..it wasn't salty nor tasteless. It kicked everything up a notch!!! Even the dipping soy sauce was prepared just right. 

Now, the service. The waiter/waitresses were friendly and attentive. They kept asking if we needed any refills. They were polite and always carried a smile when they approached us. 

I rarely experience good service and good food at the same time in a chinese restaurant. This is definitely a recommendation to family and friends.
author: Bon T.

description: All you can eat hot pot! Food is always fresh and yummy!
author: Helen L.

description:
This is a great Chinese hot pot place with amazing dumplings and various types of meat and fish balls. It is a little pricey but I think the price is fair considering the all-you-can eat handmade dumplings and fresh meats and vegetables. I agree with Amy C. that some of their other items make them an average hot pot place. I would come back again but due to the price, only on special occasions with lots of friends.

You choose what type of soup stock you want at your table and you cook whatever you want off of their menu. I simply love the flavor in the handmade dumplings that they prepare the items themselves. They had two dumplings on their menu that can really be considered a desert: taro and the custard. It blew my mind away that it tasted so sweet and good even after warmed up in our beef stock. Amazing!

The owner was really friendly and gave us extra desert fried dumplings.
author: H L.

description: 1st time back since Christmas day in 2012. We came here for girl's night out because Hot Pot Garden is Temp closed. Why do I not learn from my lesson from the last time we were here? We got the 1st set of food and they didn't bring 1/2 the stuff. They had 2 people working and the service was so slow. They did not give us the new order form after taking it for our 1st go round. We finally got the new order form and put in for our 2nd round. After 15 mins, we told them that we still haven't gotten our food and they said they'll be right with us. 30 mins later, we were still waiting. My friend had had enough of the terrible service so we just gave up. That is not the way to treat people. They shouldn't have to scream and yell or make a scene. Feel free to hire more employees. All You Can Eat means All You can Eat.
author: Theresa W.

description:
yummmmm

i love this place. i'm not even a big fan of hot pot, but i really like their wide selection of food and the broth is really good. its not too expensive and everyone there is very nice and accommodating.
author: Linh P.

description:
The spicy broth is REALLY SPICY, so kudos on truth in advertising!

Came with a bunch of vegitarians so it didn't make sense to order all we can eat (since we'd spend less just ordering the items a la carte) and the server was *really* pushing the all-you-can-eat despite the part where we said we didn't want to do it (I could have done without the sales pitch) Service was slow, but everything came as we ordered it.

Flavor of the broth was good, though. And the ingredients themselves were good. I'll have to try again some night.
author: Erin W.

description:
The most recent inhabitant of this space -- I hope it sticks around for awhile. They say that instead of having a bar/lounge area attached to the restaurant like there has been in the past, a wall is going up and they are putting in (another) Nail + Facial Spa (there's one right acrossed the street now). 

We live around the corner and have been watching the space waiting for the new eatery to open up. Didn't realize it was a hot-pot restaurant when we decided to eat there, but it was a pleasant surprise. I've actually never had Chinese hot-pot before, but I have had Japanese shabu-shabu several times before. 

The staff were all very attentive, and like the other reviewer, our waiter was the owner as well. He seemed very interested in feedback from the diners and also a little nervous. Our party of 3 included one vegetarian, so we were given a pot that accommodates 2 broths (one meat, one not). There is a really great variety to choose from -- several types of broth (we had pork, I want to try Hot+Spicy next time); many different vegetables (Taro -- yum!); noodle varieties; fresh meat and seafood; plus dumplings (loved the Shrimp+Pork) and tofu items. 

Our friend asked for a small bowl and spoon so that she could make her own cup of soup from the broth and boiled items and I think that was a really good idea. 

We ate there during the first week or two that they were open and the owner mentioned that the menu was a work-in-progress, so I am curious to see what stays and what new items are added in the future. 

It's fun and interactive and I would suggest going here in a group so that you can try everyone else's ingredients :)
author: Jessica L.

description:
So we haven't had a hot pot in years and decided to try it on mother's day of all days.  We did not have reservations and had to wait like 20-30 minutes.  It was worth the wait.  We got the clear broth and the sichuan broth and the sichuan broth showed up with a ton of hot red chili peppers, peppercorns and star anise.  Needless to say, I did not touch that one.  The clear broth was flavorful and not like the other hopt pot places that are all water down.

Since it was our first time, we wanted to try a bunch of stuff but didn't want to over order and waste food.  We got a bunch of different stuff including prime rib beef, chicken, shrimp, variety of dumplings, handmade fish ball, tofu and variety of vegetables.  The meat was fresh and did not taste frozen and I am not a red meat person.  The chicken was tender, shrimp was ok.  I wasn't a big fan of the various dumplings, but I reall liked the various tofu items we ordered (fresh tofu, tofu roll and stuffed tofu).  The vegetables were fresh (watercress, Chinese lettuce which I thought were just green leaf lettuce, and spinach).  They unfortunately were sold out of dessert (sesame balls) so we didn't get any dessert, but we were so full I don't know if I could eat it anyways.

Overall, the food was good and worth the wait.  This is one Chinese restaurant I think I am willing to go back to and agree with the other yelpers:)  And it was actually quite clean for a Chinese restaurant.
author: Eva Y.

description:
I came here twice in one week. My favorite broth is the Satay, kinda spicy and very flavorful. The Pork Bone was a little salty for me and the Potato & Tomato was too bland. I think the next time I come, I'll just get the Satay since they charge $1 per person if you want to two different broths. 

The dumplings are all yummy, veges are fresh (not wilted), the seafood I can't say much about since I don't eat it, and the prime rib is tender. The service is very prompt, although I notice they tend to serve the protein last so you can fill up on the cheaper foods. Unfortunately, they don't know that my fiance and I are beasts so we still end up eating about 4+ plates of prime rib. The staff is very friendly, which is highly unusual for an Asian restaurant. Oh, and the Coke isn't flat like most Chinese restaurants. Very important point.

It's $25 for all you can eat, which is totally worth it, especially if you're comparing them to Little Sheep Hot Pot. They're also really good, but they charge each item individually so it adds up. The last time my fiance and I went, our bill was about $70. 

I'm so glad The Pots has converted my fiance into a hot pot lover. We'll be back soon since winter is setting in!
author: Freckles H.

description:
All you can eat 24.99 ... when they are not too busy to bring you your food. We came here for dinner today and was situated in a corner table, possibly the worst table if you want to get the waiters' attention. After receiving our first order, we filled out and turned in a second order form - 20 minutes after we finished our first order we were wondering where the second one was. When we finally flagged down a waiter, they asked us to fill another form because our original one was lost in the shuffle!

After going to get the condiments and water for ourselves we then proceeded to patiently wait as our second order went in. After a good 20 minutes we asked two more waiters about our order, which they finally brought out 10 minutes later. I guess they had a busy night because everything was SLOOOOOOOOOOOOOOW.

The food was fresh enough... but after reading some yelp reviews about the freshness I was mislead to think that they were growing their own veggies or slicing the meat right off of a freshly killed animal in the back.

I would recommend this place if it wasn't so busy.. or if they had better sauces and condiments. I felt similarly satisfied after a $15 dollar set meal at any other shabu house.
author: Colin H.

description: Delicious fresh selection of items, definitely make reservations or risk a long wait. Service can be a bit slow when they are busy so order what you think you will want and just add to your soup as you go. If you're a sauce person ask for thr satay sauce - they only bring it to you upon request and its not on the menu. Theres an additional charger per person for 1/2 and 1/2 soup but its worth it to try the different flavors. Location is a bit strange and parking is a walk but overall delicious fiod. Recommended - house made ramen, lamb, homemade fishcakes, cabernet beef, shiu mai, xiao long bao and prime rib. Enjoy!
author: Christina L.

description: It was eek for me. Do I wanna pay $30 for plain water, frozen meat and frozen meat balls? The dipping sauce is not a special sauce, it's just a regular soy sauce.  I prefer to buy the ingredients at a Chinese supermarket and cook them myself.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description:
wow! where should i even start with this place. 

First off, this place offers ALL YOU CAN EAT hot pot for less than $30. They have different soup base, and the best part is you can get the split pot. If you like spicy but some of your friend doesn't. No problem, just split the soup base in half so everyone gets to enjoy their meal! I normally go for the SPICY base because I LOVE SPICY food..! But their pork bone soup base is really good for the non-spicy lovers. 

They have a HUGE variety of meat to choose from. the Fatty beef is a MUST get! I can easily finish 3 plates myself=P They have different kinds of vegetables, dumplings, balls, and noodle to choose from. The lobster ball is really good! it's a must get every time my friends and i come here.
author: Jenny G.

description:
This was a really good experience.  They're pretty new, so be prepared for the usual "bugs" being worked out in a new restaurant, but they were cheerful and willing, if a bit flustered.  They were super-busy, so we had to wait a few times, but not past the point of tolerance.  We thought they might be able to save themselves some of the pressure by placing some of the options on a steam table or on ice (depending on what, of course), and allowing customers to select their own.  As it is you order from a menu by placing slash marks next to what you want to eat, as in some sushi restaurants, and they deliver it to the table.

The way this works is, you are seated at a table with a hot plate on it.  You order a soup base from various options.  You can get a side-by-side of two soup bases for $1 extra.  We did that and got a clear soup base and a terrifically spicy Sichuan base.  Both were yummy.  You then use your chopsticks or a wire basket thing to place the uncooked items in the soup base and cook them to your personal preference, then dip them out and munch.  This is great fun and also delicious.

Go when you're hungry and get the "all you can eat" option.  There are other possibilities, but this is the best value if you're going to really chow down.  There is a really interesting array of vegetables, dumplings, noodles, and meats.  There are also seafood and tofu options.  Most of the other tables we observed were ploughing through huge platters of meat.  We stuck to seafood, tofu, veggies and dumplings and came away happily full.

We will definitely go back.
author: Angela M.

description:
I always walk by this place when I come home and I always smell that AMAZING spicy aroma (especially on a cold foggy evening) that instantly makes me hungry. One day, I caved in and went with my SO.

We got the all you can eat for $23 ea but since we wanted to split the soup pot (2 flavors rock!), we had to pay an extra $1 each. We got the hot and spicy soup and pork bone soup. The soups already had some tofu and veggies in it. 

We got all the meat: lamb, chicken, prime rib and pork. Tasty tasty tasy, especially in the spicy soup. The chicken was nothing special, in fact, it took a longer to cook compared to the thinly sliced meats. We also ordered their homemade dumplings and they were delicous. It was a mistake to order shrimps because they came with the shells on and I don't really like to peel my shrimps and flick soup particles around. 

Caution: The hot and spicy soup has dried peppers/chilies in them. Those things constantly release spicy oil into the soup. Cooking tong ho in spicy soup = soaking up the spicy oil = painful mouth. 

We also got a free dessert resembling the Malaysian bubur chacha. Yummy.

- 1 star for taking away the spice basket mid-meal. I thought they were going to refill our garlic and green onions but it never came back.   BOO!
author: Gene L.

description:
comparisons with little lamb? well of course. we got to do some comparisons here. as chinese, we grew up comparing between which is good and bad. as a result, while using my comparison skills. 

THIS PLACE IS BETTER THAN LITTLE LAMB. 
Shockingly, I had to use all caps because it was a statement of truth. They quality of meat and the use of vegetables are all better than Little Lamb. I think Little Lamb has established their chain and they no longer need to provide quality food to satisfy their customers. This place on the other hand has been giving pretty damn good stuff. 

Meat quality is definite win over Little Lamb. It was still tender and plenty juicy compared to the dark meat that Little Lamb sometimes serve. They don't skimp out on the portion either. It's always a large plate. 

Vegetable quality is good too. We don't see any vegetable that looked like it was already bite on by little pesky bugs. These were very clean and fresh. Large portions also. 

Soup base (spicy) was super! not overloaded with herbs or spices, but it got to the point and made the stuff we put in taste good. No need to use sauces or dips because the spicy MA LA flavor brings you some adrenaline rush. 

I definitely wouldn't mind driving here vs San Mateo. The only problem with this place is that it has horrible ventilation, slow service, and hard to find parking.
author: Eric Y.

description:
This is by far, the most I've eaten at a hot pot restaurant.  Granted, it's all you can eat for 2 hours, traditionally, at my parents' home, I can eat...take my time, and relax.  Here, it's definitely worth the wait of dinner. SO DON'T EAT ALL DAY.

On the serious side, hot pot/foodie lovers, your experience here is only limited to how much you can check off the menu...and how adventurous you feel (although the degree of exoticism of food isn't great).  Be prepared for raw meat though..and of course raw and uncooked seafood as well.  It's great for folks who love meat, love seafood, only seafood diets...and of course veggie folks too.

Around $25 dollars a person...and they count each person, so you can't just sit there and hope to eat for free.  There's a closed section for large groups and karaoke for those who sing and eat.  

I've been there a few times, no wait when you get there by 6:30pm, usually can sit right when you walk in for small groups of 4.  it's an experience for those interested in hot pot, but are intimidated by going to more traditional places.  Young crowd generally here...but still safe for families.

Eat here when it's chilly and cold!!!
author: felix c.

description:
Hm..I guess if you live in the sunset area and wants somewhere close by, then it's alrite. The owner was very friendly and helpful. The beef was pretty good and that's all about it for me. Most of other dishes that I like wasn't on the all you can eat menu. The soup base is the most important foundation for a delicious hotpot and I was quite disappointed. There sure was a-whole-lot of dry red pepper on the soup but somehow the soup tasted SWEET! I thought I lost my taste bud for a sec that I had to ask my friend that doesn't eat spicy to verify the taste of the soup for me. That kinda ruined my appetite. 
I live in the sunset area but I don't mind at all driving a little further distance to little sheep in San Mateo. Their soup base far out beats any hotpot places in SF for sure!
author: Robert D.

description:
Ok, i decided to come here again since someone wanted to treat me to dinner. I wouldn't pay $25 on my own here although the food itself IS pretty good as mentioned in my previous post. 

So we get there and there's a crowd in the front of the black peacoat, gelled hair smoking cigs wannabe underground mob type of dudes yaking outside blocking the entrance. But we make it in and see all the side tables empty.

Good, I though, there's seats. I see the "PLEASE WAIT TO BE SEATED" sign so we wait there. The two guys working there give us looks. Some third guy who's dressed like he works there also gives us looks. Turns out he was just a customer coming from the bathroom.... But anyways... the actual workers just look over ever few seconds.. not a word or acknowledgement. 

I look over at the sign up list with all the names crossed off, then the 6 or so empty clean tables... and wonder WTF??!!

I just put my name down and sat down.. waited... nothing.... for a about 10 minutes. So you know what.. forget it. There's other places that more deserving of my money.
author: Johnny D.

description:
Surprisingly great hot pot.  Most hot pot places seem to run by an Asian mantra of profits first, food second.  The Pot's has clearly focused on delivering freshly made, delicious and reasonably priced "fire pot" fair w/ great aplomb and success.  

As a shab snob myself, I was happy to find high grade cuts of meats coupled with mushroom-stuffed dumplings, fresh vegatables and even "ni wong bao" (custard filled dumplings)

Service was attentive and prompt, with all you can eat items arriving even before we had finished the last plate.  It was as if they had eyes in the sky delivering hot pot goodness on demand.

Will definitely come back here on a cold day.
author: J L.

description:
3.5 stars
I looove hot pot, especially on cold nights in SF. My friend frequents this place so she recommended we come here. For $22 (roughly $30 after tax and tip), it's all-you-can-eat, which is a mighty fine deal since it includes a large variety of meats, veggies, and even hand-wrapped dumplings. Service is a bit slow and MIA at times, as it takes a bit of prodding at the people working to bring out everything you ordered and we were constantly out of iced water. The place also gets pretty stuffy since they lack a true ventilation system. Regardless, it's a good deal and a fun experience with friends/family.
However, it's probably a sign that I'm getting old, but for the rest of the night and the morning after eating at The Pot's, I suffered from a migraine from the MSG in their broth like a hangover ):. So beware if you have sensitivities to MSG. If anything, I'd recommend Little Fat Sheep in SM since I've never had any problems there.
author: Jen T.

description: Enormous amount of food for little itty bitty price. Had dinner with a friend, we sat and ate for two hours until we could not fit another bit and it came out to $25 pp. They have some great broths to choose from, the spicy one is like a kick in the pants once the peppers heat up. Service was meh, but to be expected. Could be a long wait if you happen to come right after everyone just seated.
author: Kristine T.

description: Good hot pot.  Service spotty.  I was dying of thirst all night.  I couldn't sleep.  lame
author: Fatty A.

description: Great hot pot. Tasty broth which is essential to a good hot pot dish. Lots of selections of meats, dumplings and veggies. When you run low on the broth, they will be happy to fill up the pot!
author: Cindy W.

description: Love this place! Fresh food that you cook at your table ... I usually get the split broth to cook my food in. Half of my pot is spicy broth, the other half is pork broth.. Decor is modern and even has a private room on the side for a large group... Super friendly staff that brings more food to you as you go along. This is the spot to go on a cold or rainy night...
author: Vincent Q.

description:
+ more selection and food options than anywhere 
+ Inside is comfortable and adorned modernly 
+ Love the option of having 2 different types of broth 
+ friendly service
- Beef is Pho Beef. I personally enjoy Kobe beef, but understand that "all you can eat" would be very pricey if they did Kobe.

I recommend this place. Tastes great, and I love the selection. Veggies come from a farmers market daily, can't beat that.
author: Miss J.

description: Our favorite hot pot spot.  Beef, pork or lamb for meat.  Very large selections of extras such as tripe, dumplings, fish balls, veggies, noodles, and on and on.  Service is good for hot pot, remember this isn't Per Se.  For 24.99 you get to eat all you want, and get a free hot pot coma afterwards.  Try it if you haven't, you will like it.
author: Danny M.

description: This place is solid for a hot pot place, selection is plentiful and everything from the meat to the veggies is always fresh. Love the pork bone and satay soup base and the best of all, unlimited prime rib. I get little embarrassed when I'm about to ask for my 5th or 6th plate of beef. I'm also amazed with the the little taro and custard balls that are cooked in the soup, it tasted really well with a hint of salty flavor then the gewy custard or taro.
author: John W.

description:
this place is yummy on a cold day. i usually get satay broth which is only the best in the beginning, because once the broth starts looking low, the servers come by with hot water to pour it in and then it becomes bland.

I love the udon and ramen noodles. SOOO much variety. the dumplings, spam, hot dog, beef, and all types of balls are soo good. I know some of the balls are frozen ones, because my mom has brought them home for hot pot before. The price is okay for all you can eat. I usually hoard when its all you can eat! lol
author: Nancy T.

description:
It was a cool and foggy night in outer sunset, which is a perfect time for hot pot. Being a recent transplant from Los Angeles, we don't always get the chance to have hot pot, mainly because it's never really that cold. But the good thing about SF, and outer sunset especially is that it's usually cold....even in the summer, which means i can have hot pot year round.

With that said, i'm a big fan of hot pot. It brings back good memories, and The Pot's is a place that definitely brings back those good memories. The service is amazingly friendly, especially for a Chinese all-you-can-eat place. The wait staff is very attentive and always smiling. Quite rare, but very appreciated. 

In terms of the food, there is a nice variety of broths, fresh meats, seafood, and vegetables. I just wish there were more ingredients besides just garlic, chili sauce, green onions, and cilantro for when you customize your soy sauce. Other than that, the food is the standard fare for hot pot.

If the price was cheaper, i'd be frequenting The Pot's regularly. But $25 per person is a little steep, especially because you're cooking the food yourself. So now, i'll frequent it only when i'm really craving it, willing to splurge a little, and it's cold and foggy outside.
author: Ernest N.

description: Went here once, it was OKAY the first time so I decided to come again with an even larger group of people. The service hovered from around mediocre to okay. The price was ridiculous. Not recommended for teens or people who don't plan on spending a whole lot.
author: Kevin W.

description: Our friend suggested this place a few weeks back and since the weather is beautiful, we decided to give it a try.  We had the dual pork broth and spicy szechuan hot pot.  The meat is beautifully thinly sliced (as it should) and all the ingredients are extremely fresh.  The service is excellent as well.  We will definitely go back again.
author: Jack M.

description:
This is probably the best deal you can get for hot pot-ting in the city. $23 per person for all you can eat. The service is great. Their variety of dishes is large compared to most.  The meat is very fresh. They have tons of soup selections. 

The place is still new as I've went there 3 times since opening. We'll see how well it can keep up.
author: Ian C.

description: Awesome place, perfect for a group outing, the food is fresh and tasty.
author: Kate J.

description: I was here twice this weekend, (I liked it that much). I think we ordered the sautay (sp?) broth and it had the perfect amount of spiciness. The first time I went I threw everything into the pot at one time (which worked) and the second time i mimicked everyone else and threw in pieces(which wasn't as fun). The lamb and the tarra root chips are my favorite. Keep in mind, if you order too much food it's much harder to find the stuff  you want in the pot. You can order whatever you want for $24.99/person. Oh, and don't ask them for a to-go box (even though you'll want to bc it's THAT good) they will laugh.
author: Maggie L.

description:
My faves about this place: clean (major plus in my book), nice decor, warm. food was good, not excitingly good, but good. i like the dipping sauce. the availability of a variety of different menu items. all you can eat! super super friendly staff.  i really enjoyed myself here. so much that i got heartburn. 

negatives: it was busy when we got there so it took a while for us to get a seat. our bok choy never came. the spicy broth was just a little too spicy for my taste, but i really enjoyed the standard simple clear soup base. although the servers were very friendly, kind of slow, and we had to ask for our water two times. 

i remembered that I don't like cooking, at home or in other places, so maybe we will not be back for a while... BUT the food was good and i liked the asian food channel that was on tv. 

actually, i'm kinna feenin for it now as i write this so.... meet ya there?
author: RACHELLE T.

description: Really solid place, with decently fresh ingredients at good prices. Friendly staff. You might want to call ahead and make reservations.
author: Guillermo K.

description: Not bad for hot pot. Lots of variety in meats, vegetables, etc. Clean place with decent service. For the amount that I eat it's def more economical eating here than making hot pot at home.
author: Ngoc N.

description:
3.50 stars.

I came here with a group of 5 during The Pot's grand opening period. The place is fairly large, and it got packed pretty quickly. We went back when it was "freezing" in SF (40s F), so it was nice to have hot food in our system quick style.

We ordered the all-you-can-eat system, and the food was good. We were all very full afterwards. The service wasn't that great, but it was their grand opening period, so we cut them some slack. But the staff was very nice towards us.

Come hungry and eat all you can! I would say try it. I liked it.
author: Sam W.

description:
Being one that only had hot pot at home and likes to cook, I never really had the urge to try places that served hot pot. It's nothing special and I like doing it at home w/family & friends since it's more cozy. My bf's sis had a huge craving hot pot since she was feeling sick and told us of this place where it's all-you-can-eat hot pot for around $20-25 and that she really enjoyed it. I had a friend in town so I thought it'd be a great way to kill two birds w/one stone: satisfy my bf's sis' craving and hang out w/a friend of ours. Since my friend eats a lot, I was certain that it would be money well spent as well and boy was I right!

We went on a weekday so parking wasn't too bad for us (luckily we found parking right in front!) because that area is very notorious for having troubles in finding parking on the weekends (or holidays). The place on the outside really doesn't look like much, but the inside is quite cozy and warm.

The selection they have is pretty good and fresh. They even have a special menu that you pay for additional items to put in such as scallops, oysters, chicken feet, etc. but unless you have to have them, what they have set for the all-you-can-eat is pretty good to satisfy everyone's tastes. And whenever you need to order more food, you just ask for another menu. After ordering, they bring out the soy sauce (which is slightly sweet and tastes great for dipping) and the basket of condiments to enhance your sauce that consists of red chili sauce, garlic, green onion, and cilantro. You can add as much (or as little) as you want, but be sure to taste and have it the way you like it because they take the basket away as soon as the food arrives.

Ok so onto what we ordered. For our broth, we picked the pork bones since that's what we are most familiar with. Our pick for veggies: bok choy and  lettuce (too full to get the chinese broccoli). For noodles we had the bean vermicelli and the taro noodles. Meats were the slices pork and beef. We had one order of hot links but they were too spicy for us (for health reasons we can't eat the stuff). For dumplings we ordered shu mai (which were decent, nothing extraodinary), stuffed shrimp balls (shrimp balls w/fish egg inside), and the custard. Our favorites were the stuffed shrimp balls and the custard dumplings. We had to keep ordering those cuz we all loved them! We also had an order of pork liver, tofu and the enoki mushrooms wrapped w/beef. For dessert we each had a sesame ball w/red bean inside (which is automatically given to you at the end of your meal).

Service was alright. It was pretty busy so we had to remind our waiters to bring us the stuff we asked, but they were usually pretty quick. You just gotta keep in mind that they have to juggle a lot of things at a time.

The only real issue I had was that after you start cooking, and your soup base gets low, they re-fill it with hot water which waters down all the flavors and doesn't taste as good. So I suggest getting all the real good stuff eaten before the broth is re-filled with the water.

Overall we had a great time and definitely got our money's worth. We didn't feel guilty eating all that food either since it's all either seafood or lean meat. And everything's boiled! Best decision we made! Will definitely make another trip when we have friends visiting. ^_^b
author: Kitty K.

description: Very good restaurant. The services are very good. They have all you can eat option or order by items. I usually get the all you can eat. There's a lot of options for the all you can eat and didn't feel like I am restricted to order some cheap dishes. The house meatballs are the best. One of the best hotpot place in San Francisco. Will definitely go again.
author: Gina L.

description: My friends have been raving about this chinese hot pot restaurant so I decided to give it a try. Maybe we went on a bad day because I thought this place was just okay.  There was nothing special about the spicy soup base and the ingredients were not fresh.  I'll pass.
author: Lisa Z.

description: Service is good but they are also very busy so you must cut them some slack. They have a variety of soup bases and they have satay sauce when you ask them. They also have other drunk avaialble other than soda, water and tea. The servers there are very nice and the food are ok. They are kareoke if you have a large group party like i did. You can close the door and make as much noise as you want. Well not really a lot of noise but you know what i mean.
author: Jan H.

description: The wait was confusing. I was in a group of four; a group of three went before us and a group of six went before us, we were there first. When we were seated, we were given a paper to pick what we want. Useless. The waiter gave us three dishes. We had to keep asking them for stuff and they do not tell you when something is out. You just keep waiting. What DID come was pretty good though. Service sucks. Decor is nice. Food's alright. Not sure if I would go again.
author: Stacy C.

description:
My sister and her friends have been coming here religiously and I finally came here last night after visiting SFSU. The location of this restaurant is odd but it's perfect for it's neighborhood. I like how the restaurant is clean and nicely decorated. The bathroom is also spacious and clean which is a total plus for chinese restaurants. Went around 7:15 on a Friday night and luckily there was no wait. Restaurant is pretty big with two private rooms for karaoke (very interesting). During dinner you will often hear obnoxious loud noises coming from those rooms with people cracking up their voices, annoying but funny at the same time. 
There are many broths to choose from, i recommend at least getting half portions of the spicy broth. $25 all you can eat. Their menu is pretty simple and it has almost all the ingredients that you usually eat at a hotpot so it's really nice. Some things aren't as fresh so be sure you check them prior to eating it. soft drinks are free and make sure you order yourself some sweet custard balls at the end of the meal.
